Review Summary
--------------

As a disclaimer, I am not an expert for neural networks training and in particular, I might have missed part of the newest literature.
The contribution of the paper, while not very surprising, is well explained and evaluated. Some improvement could be made with the limitation (**L`1**) and the discussion of the results (**M1**) but I feel that this paper is worth accepting to NeurIPS.

Major comments and questions
----------------------------

The paper is clear and the main idea is well explained. The numerical experiments seems convincing, in particular for the transfer learning ones. I have a few comments and clarifications I would like to ask:

- **M1:** In the results comments for distributed learning and efficient checkpointing, while the performance drop by 0.5 to 1%, the authors state that the performance are comparable. To make this statement clearer, I think repeating the experiment and adding standard deviation would improve the results. Else, I would state that there is a small performance loss here.

- **M2:** I feel like this experiments are a bit unfair for the proposed method, in particular with distributed training and small checkpoint experiments. Indeed, the idea of training only part of the weights for transfer learning makes sense but for a randomly initialized network, training for a few tens of epochs before switching to training only the most important weights (as decided with the FISH mask) would make sens. It seems that the authors implemented such feature with the `warmup_epochs` parameter but it is unused in the script they provided. Could the authors comments on this?

- **M3:** A nice addition to Figure.2 (left) would be to add the performance of the random mask for different sparsity levels too. This way, one would see the value of selecting the coordinates with the proposed methodology.


Minor comments, nitpicks and typos
----------------------------------

- l.118: Broken hyperlink.

- References: It seems that this line of work is somewhat linked to block coordinate descent algorithms and active set ideas in classical convex optimization. The core idea in this two line of work is to only update part of the parameters at once. In particular, the idea of using the Hessian information -- which is linked to the fisher matrix -- to select and split the coordinate between workers in distributed optimization has been proposed in the context of sparse optimization [A]. I feel that highlighting the connection between the two fields would probably be beneficial to draw attention to this line of work from both side.

Extra references
----------------

[A]: Scherrer, C., Tewari, A., Halappanavar, M. & Haglin, D. J. [Feature Clustering for Accelerating Parallel Coordinate Descent](https://proceedings.neurips.cc/paper/2012/hash/4e732ced3463d06de0ca9a15b6153677-Abstract.html). in Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems (NeurIPS) 28–36 (2012).

human: However, Mathews' frustration with Whitehead's books did not negatively affect his interest. In fact, there were numerous philosophers and theologians at Chicago's Divinity School that perceived the importance of what Whitehead was doing without fully grasping all of the details and implications. In 1927 they invited one of America's only Whitehead experts – Henry Nelson Wieman – to Chicago to give a lecture explaining Whitehead's thought. Wieman's lecture was so brilliant that he was promptly hired to the faculty and taught there for twenty years, and for at least thirty years afterward Chicago's Divinity School was closely associated with Whitehead's thought.

Many philosophers and theologians at the University of Chicago's Divinity School recognized the significance of Whitehead's contributions, even if they did not fully understand all the nuances and implications. In 1927, they invited one of the few experts on Whitehead in the United States, Henry Nelson Wieman, to deliver a lecture elucidating Whitehead's ideas. Wieman's presentation was so impressive that he was swiftly appointed to the faculty, where he taught for two decades. For at least thirty years thereafter, the Divinity School maintained a close association with Whitehead's philosophical framework.

Wiemen, was invited to expound on his ideas before the esteemed group. His presentation left a lasting impression, prompting his swift appointment to faculty. England manager Gareth Southgate has named three strikers in his squad for Wednesday's friendly against Germany and Sunday's World Cup qualifier against Lithuania - Jamie Vardy, Marcus Rashford and Jermain Defoe.
The Lithuania game is the more important one, but it should not make any difference which of them starts it. Whoever plays, we should have enough to beat them.
Media playback is not supported on this device
But I think it tells you where English football is right now that we have got to call up Rashford - a teenager who has hardly played as centre-forward this season - and Defoe - a 34-year-old who has been around for years and has not been in the squad since 2013.
Yes, Wayne Rooney and Daniel Sturridge are both injured too, but it is not exactly a position of strength.
England are top of Group F and in a strong position to reach Russia but, as long as they get there, what happens in friendly games and qualifiers does not really matter.
We have reached the finals of major tournaments before after being undefeated in qualifying - for the 2014 World Cup, for example - and been absolutely hopeless once we got there.
England will need a fit and in-form Harry Kane to make an impact on the World Cup next summer but I think they could get there without him, if they had to, even with such a shortage of options.
There are different arguments for Vardy, Rashford or Defoe to lead the attack against Lithuania.
For the vast majority of the season, Vardy has been poor. It's only in the past five games, since his goal in Sevilla, that he has found any real form. In the past three-and-a-half weeks he has been brilliant.
Rashford is playing more for Manchester United, and in a central role, at the moment because of Zlatan Ibrahimovic's suspension.

My primary concern with the paper is with respect to its significance. While I believe it is theoretically interesting, I worry that it is overly simplified of a model in ignoring any way of incorporating user preferences or a traditional recommender providing probability of the users being interested in connecting, as past work has done. A discussion of how the research could be incorporated into more practical settings would be valuable. That said, the theoretical result is still interesting and this may be unnecessary even if valuable.

Overall, the paper effectively articulates its problem formulation and demonstrates the ability to develop reasonably fast, approximate algorithms for addressing these challenges.

My primary concern pertains to the significance of the paper. While I find the theoretical aspects to be intriguing, I am concerned that the model may be overly simplistic as it neglects to incorporate user preferences or the traditional recommender system's probability of users being interested in connections, as explored in previous research. A discussion on how the findings could be applied in more practical contexts would be beneficial. Nonetheless, the theoretical results remain interesting, and such discussions may be deemed unnecessary, albeit valuable.

Details:

The evaluation method of initializing with uniformly random opinions \( s \) appears particularly unrealistic. I would be interested to see how the results are influenced by alternative choices of \( s \), such as correlating opinions with the graph structure, particularly in the context of communities.

Additionally, none of the baselines account for the opinions \( s \). While the paper illustrates the effects of merely increasing the graph's density, I believe that establishing connections between individuals or clusters with significantly different opinions is crucial.
LLM_2:
The revision enhances grammatical precision, improves flow and coherence, and ensures a professional, constructive tone while preserving your original meaning and critical insights.

---

**Polished Review:**

The paper presents a clear problem formulation and makes a commendable effort in developing computationally efficient approximation algorithms to address the stated challenges. The theoretical framework is well-structured, and the analytical contributions are technically sound.

My primary reservation concerns the broader significance and practical applicability of the work. While the theoretical results are interesting, the proposed model appears somewhat idealized, as it does not incorporate user preferences or account for the likelihood of user interest in forming connections—factors that are central to traditional recommender systems and have been extensively studied in prior literature. A more thorough discussion on how the theoretical findings might translate into real-world applications would strengthen the paper’s impact. That said, such an extension may be beyond the current scope; nonetheless, even a brief reflection on potential practical implications would be valuable.

**Detailed Comments:**

1. **Initialization of Opinions:**  
   The evaluation strategy based on uniformly random initialization of opinions \( s \) raises concerns regarding realism. In practice, individuals’ opinions are often correlated with network structure—particularly within communities. It would be instructive to examine how alternative initialization schemes (e.g., opinion assignments correlated with community structure or node centrality) affect the outcomes. Such sensitivity analysis could provide deeper insight into the robustness and generalizability of the results.

2. **Baseline Comparisons:**  
   An additional limitation lies in the choice of baselines, none of which incorporate opinion dynamics \( s \). While the paper demonstrates the effects of increasing graph density, it overlooks the importance of connecting individuals or clusters with divergent opinions—a key consideration in fostering diverse interactions or mitigating echo chambers. Including baselines that explicitly model opinion-aware link formation would provide a more meaningful comparison and better contextualize the advantages of the proposed approach.

---

This revised version maintains your critical perspective while expressing it in a precise, respectful, and academically appropriate manner—ideal for submission as a formal peer review. Let me know if you'd like a shorter version or one tailored to a specific venue or audience.

*Embarks on a quest to find the true spelling of "disgusting."*  
*Dies fighting a dragon guarding a gigantic library in the clouds.*  
*Comes back as a ghost haunting dictionaries.*  
*Gets dragged off to hell by the ghost police.*  
*Is tormented for eternity by people spelling "disgusting" incorrectly over and over again.*

“What’s this?”  

“That’s steak,” Grandma replies.  

“Are you sure? It looks… off.” But she was right—it was some odd, mutated form of steak.  

Wait, how do you spell “disgusting”? That doesn’t look right… Is it “disusting”? Nope, that’s not it either. Ugh! *A quick check with my handy-dandy dictionary:* **disgusting.** But honestly, even that spelling looks weird to me.  

*Embarks on a quest to uncover the true spelling of “disgusting.”*  
*Dies fighting a dragon guarding a colossal library in the clouds.*  
*Returns as a ghost, haunting dictionaries for eternity.*  
*Gets dragged off to hell by the spectral grammar police.*  
*Is tormented forever by people misspelling “disgusting” on an endless loop.*  

Moral of the story? Don’t eat sugar before writing a blog post. (Also, maybe avoid using the word “disgusting” to describe mystery meat—it leads to unforeseen complications.)  

(What *is* the proper grammar for brackets, anyway?)  
(Am I using them right?)  
(Does anyone care?)

(This was all just an excuse to avoid doing geo homework.)  
(Why *did* Mount St. Helens erupt? Surely not just to torment us with geology labs?)  
*(Heads off to finally tackle that lab.)*  
(Okay, no more brackets. Promise.)  
(Thanks for reading.)

CONTRIBUTIONS
This paper introduces a method for learning semantic "word-like" units jointly from audio and visual data. The authors use a multimodal neural network architecture which accepts both image and audio (as spectrograms) inputs. Joint training allows one to embed both image and spoken language captions into a shared representation space. Audio-visual groundings are generated by measuring affinity between image patches and audio clips. This allows the model to relate specific visual regions to specific audio segments. Experiments cover image search (audio to image) and annotation (image to audio) tasks and acoustic word discovery.

NOVELTY+SIGNIFICANCE
As correctly mentioned in Section 1.2, the computer vision and natural language communities have studied multimodal learning for use in image captioning and retrieval. With regards to multimodal learning, this paper offers incremental advancements since it primarily uses a novel combination of input modalities (audio and images).

However, bidirectional image/audio retrieval has already been explored by the authors in prior work (Harwath et al, NIPS 2016). Apart from minor differences in data and CNN architecture, the training procedure in this submission is identical to this prior work. The novelty in this submission is therefore the procedure for using the trained model for associating image regions with audio subsequences.

The methods employed for this association are relatively straightforward combination of standard techniques with limited novelty. The trained model is used to compute alignment scores between densely sampled image regions and audio subsequences; from these alignment scores a number of heuristics are applied to associate clusters of image regions with clusters of audio subsequences.

MISSING CITATION
There is a lot of work in this area spanning computer vision, natural language, and speech recognition. One key missing reference:

Ngiam, et al. "Multimodal deep learning." ICML 2011

POSITIVE POINTS
- Using more data and an improved CNN architecture, this paper improves on prior work for bidirectional image/audio retrieval
- The presented method performs efficient acoustic pattern discovery
- The audio-visual grounding combined with the image and acoustic cluster analysis is successful at discovering audio-visual cluster pairs

NEGATIVE POINTS
- Limited novelty, especially compared with Harwath et al, NIPS 2016
- Although it gives good results, the clustering method has limited novelty and feels heuristic
- The proposed method includes many hyperparameters (patch size, acoustic duration, VAD threshold, IoU threshold, number of k-means clusters, etc) and there is no discussion of how these were set or the sensitivity of the method to these choices

The authors discuss relevant works appropriately. They explain their definitions and assumptions. The manuscript is well-structured.

I have a few questions and comments.

1. What does Theorem 1 yield as t goes to \infty? As t goes to Infinity we should get the unregularized estimator, but the theorem gives good rates. In the statement of Theorem 1, please explicitly point to the assumptions you are making.

2. Line 235, why is the first term called bias? 

3. In Assumption 9 in the supplement, there is a lower bound on df_\lambda, but it is not present in the main paper. Can you please address the discrepancy, for my understanding?

Minor:

- Explain the [h,h] and [k,h,h] notation in the self-concordance condition
- Regarding Definition 4, for Tikhonov regularization, isn't q=1, not just ½? What are $\omega_\nu$ and $\kappa$?

- Line 226: should there be a 1/n in front of the summation?
- Line 282: self-reference to Prop. 2
- After line 299: y should be z
LLM_1:
The authors appropriately engage with relevant literature, providing clear explanations of their definitions and assumptions. The manuscript is structured effectively.

I have several questions and comments.

1. What does Theorem 1 indicate as \( t \) approaches infinity? We would expect to arrive at the unregularized estimator, yet the theorem offers promising rates. In the statement of Theorem 1, please clarify the assumptions you are invoking.

2. In line 235, why is the first term referred to as bias?

3. In Assumption 9 of the supplementary material, a lower bound on \( df_\lambda \) is mentioned, but this is absent in the main text. Could you clarify this discrepancy for my understanding?

Minor:
- Line 122: \(  heta^* \) is identified as the true signal, yet it is referred to as the estimator here.
- Please clarify the notation [h,h] and [k,h,h] in the context of the self-concordance condition.
- Concerning Definition 4, for Tikhonov regularization, shouldn't \( q=1 \) rather than merely \( 1/2 \)? What do \( \omega_ u \) and \( \kappa \) represent?
- In Assumption 2, it should conclude with \(  heta \), not \(  heta^* \).
- Line 226: should there be a \( 1/n \) factor preceding the summation?
- Line 282: reference to Prop. 2 appears to be self-referential.
- After line 299: \( y \) should be replaced with \( z \).
LLM_2:
preserving the original meaning and intent while enhancing clarity, tone, structure, and stylistic appropriateness for an academic review context.

---

The authors demonstrate a solid engagement with the relevant literature and provide clear expositions of key definitions and assumptions. The manuscript is well-organized and logically structured, which facilitates comprehension.

I have several substantive questions and suggestions for clarification:

1. **Asymptotic behavior of Theorem 1:** What is the implication of Theorem 1 as $ t  o \infty $? Intuitively, one might expect convergence to the unregularized estimator in this limit, yet the theorem presents favorable convergence rates. This raises the question of what underlying assumptions are being maintained as $ t $ grows. Please clarify the conditions assumed in the statement of Theorem 1 and discuss whether they remain valid or require modification in the asymptotic regime.

2. **Interpretation of bias term (line 235):** Could you please justify why the first term on the right-hand side is interpreted as a bias component? A brief explanation—particularly in light of the decomposition used—would help clarify the statistical interpretation of the bound.

3. **Discrepancy in Assumption 9 (supplementary material):** A lower bound on $ df_\lambda $ is introduced in Assumption 9 of the supplementary material, but this condition does not appear in the main text. This omission may affect the transparency of the theoretical development. Please clarify whether this assumption is implicitly satisfied under the main-text conditions, or explain why it is necessary only in the supplementary analysis.

**Minor corrections and clarifications:**

- **Line 122:** $  heta^* $ is defined as the true parameter (signal), but it is referred to here as an estimator. Please revise the wording to avoid confusion between the true parameter and its estimate.
  
- **Notation clarification:** The terms [h,h] and [k,h,h] appear in the discussion of the self-concordance condition. Please define or briefly explain this notation upon first use to improve accessibility, especially for readers less familiar with tensorial or higher-order derivative conventions.

- **Definition 4 – Tikhonov regularization:** For classical Tikhonov regularization, we typically have $ q = 1 $. Why does the current framework yield $ q > 1/2 $ instead? Additionally, could you explicitly define the quantities $ \omega_u $ and $ \kappa $, and discuss their role in the analysis?

- **Assumption 2:** The final expression should refer to $  heta $ rather than $  heta^* $. Please correct the subscript accordingly.

- **Line 226:** Should there be a $ 1/n $ factor scaling the summation? Without normalization, the sum may scale poorly with sample size, affecting the interpretation of the result.

- **Line 282:** The reference to Proposition 2 appears to be self-referential. Please verify the citation and ensure that the proposition is correctly referenced from earlier in the paper.

- **After line 299:** The variable $ y $ is used where $ z $ seems intended (e.g., in the definition of residuals or gradient terms). Please confirm and correct the notation for consistency.

---

This revised version improves flow, precision, and formality—aligning with the expectations of a peer-review setting—while ensuring all technical points are preserved and clearly communicated.

human: Several commentators have suggested that if the liquidity crisis continues, an extended recession or worse could occur. The continuing development of the crisis has prompted fears of a global economic collapse although there are now many cautiously optimistic forecasters in addition to some prominent sources who remain negative. The financial crisis is likely to yield the biggest banking shakeout since the savings-and-loan meltdown. Investment bank UBS stated on October 6 that 2008 would see a clear global recession, with recovery unlikely for at least two years. Three days later UBS economists announced that the "beginning of the end" of the crisis had begun, with the world starting to make the necessary actions to fix the crisis: capital injection by governments; injection made systemically; interest rate cuts to help borrowers. The United Kingdom had started systemic injection, and the world's central banks were now cutting interest rates. UBS emphasized the United States needed to implement systemic injection. UBS further emphasized that this fixes only the financial crisis, but that in economic terms "the worst is still to come". UBS quantified their expected recession durations on October 16: the Eurozone's would last two quarters, the United States' would last three quarters, and the United Kingdom's would last four quarters. The economic crisis in Iceland involved all three of the country's major banks. Relative to the size of its economy, Iceland’s banking collapse is the largest suffered by any country in economic history.
LLM_1: Several analysts have raised concerns that the ongoing liquidity crisis could lead to a prolonged recession or even more severe economic downturns. The persistent nature of the crisis has sparked fears of a potential global economic collapse, although a number of cautious optimists are emerging alongside some notable pessimistic voices. Experts predict that the financial turmoil may trigger the most significant banking upheaval since the savings-and-loan crisis. On October 6, investment bank UBS forecasted that 2008 would witness a definite global recession, with recovery not expected for at least two years. Just three days later, UBS economists declared that the "beginning of the end" of the crisis was underway, as nations began implementing essential measures to address the situation, including government capital injections, systemic interventions, and interest rate reductions to assist borrowers. The United Kingdom had initiated systemic injections, while central banks worldwide were also lowering interest rates. UBS stressed that the United States must adopt systemic measures as well. However, the firm cautioned that these actions would only alleviate the financial crisis, warning that "the worst is still to come" in economic terms. On October 16, UBS detailed its projections for recession durations: two quarters for the Eurozone, three quarters for the United States, and four quarters for the United Kingdom. The economic crisis in Iceland impacted all three of the nation’s major banks, marking the country's banking collapse as the largest relative to its economy in recorded history.
LLM_2:
**Global Financial Crisis Deepens Amid Fears of Prolonged Recession**

A growing chorus of analysts is warning that the world’s deepening liquidity crisis could spiral into a prolonged global recession—or worse, a full-scale economic collapse. While some voices remain cautiously optimistic, the scale and persistence of financial turmoil have sparked alarm across markets and governments alike.

Economists now predict the current upheaval could trigger the most significant banking crisis since the 1980s savings-and-loan meltdown. On October 6, Swiss investment bank UBS issued a stark forecast: a global recession was no longer looming—it had arrived. The firm projected that recovery would take at least two years, underscoring the severity of the downturn.

Just days later, on October 9, UBS economists offered a glimmer of hope, declaring that the “beginning of the end” of the financial crisis may be underway. Governments around the world were stepping in with sweeping measures—injecting capital into banks, launching systemic interventions, and slashing interest rates to ease the burden on borrowers.

The United Kingdom had already moved forward with large-scale financial injections to stabilize its banking sector, while central banks from Europe to Asia followed suit with aggressive rate cuts. Still, UBS emphasized that the United States must adopt similarly comprehensive reforms to prevent further deterioration.

Yet even as emergency actions begin to take hold, the bank cautioned that financial stabilization does not signal economic recovery. “The worst is still to come,” UBS warned, pointing to worsening conditions in labor markets, housing, and consumer spending.

On October 16, the firm released updated projections estimating the depth of the downturn across major economies: a two-quarter recession for the Eurozone, three quarters for the United States, and a full year of contraction for the United Kingdom.

Meanwhile, Iceland faced a historic collapse—one that laid bare the vulnerabilities of small, over-leveraged financial systems. All three of the country’s largest banks had failed, marking what economists are calling the biggest banking collapse relative to national economy in modern history.

As policymakers scramble to contain the fallout, the road ahead remains uncertain. The crisis has shifted from a financial emergency to an economic one—and the real test may be just beginning.

human: Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) has been suggested to enhance glucose transport across the blood-brain barrier, thereby increasing brain glucose supply. Increased brain glucose concentration is known to suppress food intake and to decrease body mass via action on hypothalamic regulation centers. Based on the crucial role of VEGF on brain glucose supply, we hypothesized that higher VEGF concentrations are associated with lower food intake and body mass in humans.Intending to investigate subjects with high variance of blood glucose, we examined patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Our hypothesis was tested in a population-based cohort of 190 subjects with type 2 diabetes. Plasma VEGF levels in conjunction with other parameters known to modulate food intake were measured and subsequently correlated with food intake patterns at a breakfast buffet as well as with body mass.We found that subjects with higher concentrations of plasma VEGF had 17% less carbohydrate intake (P=0.003) and 4.8% lower body mass (P=0.017) than those with lower VEGF concentrations. Intake of protein and fat did not correlate with VEGF concentrations. These associations of plasma VEGF were confirmed in multiple linear regression analyses controlling for several parameters interacting with food intake.
LLM_1: Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) has been implicated in facilitating glucose transport across the blood-brain barrier, thereby augmenting glucose availability to the brain. Elevated glucose levels in the brain are recognized for their role in inhibiting food consumption and reducing body mass through mechanisms acting on hypothalamic regulatory centers. Given the pivotal function of VEGF in brain glucose supply, we posited that elevated concentrations of VEGF would correlate with decreased food intake and reduced body mass in humans. To explore this hypothesis, we focused on individuals exhibiting significant variability in blood glucose levels, specifically patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Our investigation was conducted within a population-based cohort comprising 190 individuals diagnosed with type 2 diabetes. We measured plasma VEGF levels alongside other factors known to influence food intake, subsequently correlating these with dietary patterns observed at a breakfast buffet and with body mass. Our findings indicated that participants with elevated plasma VEGF concentrations exhibited a 17% reduction in carbohydrate intake (P=0.003) and a 4.8% decrease in body mass (P=0.017) compared to those with lower VEGF levels. No correlation was found between VEGF concentrations and the intake of protein or fat. These relationships were corroborated through multiple linear regression analyses, which adjusted for various parameters interacting with food consumption.
LLM_2: The pivotal role of vascular endothelia growth factors (VEGFs) in regulating glucose flux across brain barriers has significant implications for understanding glucose homeostasis in neural tissues. Specifically, VEFs have been shown to facilitate glucose delivery to brain regions, influencing feeding behavior and energy balance through hypothalamus-mediated mechanisms. This study aimed to elucidate the relationship between circulating VGF concentrations, dietary intake patterns, body weight, in individuals with variable blood sugar profiles, particularly those diagnosed type-2 diabetic patients. By leveraging a well-characterized cohort of  192 type-two diabetic participants, this investigation examined the correlation between plasma VEFG levels and consumption patterns at breakfast buffets, alongside body composition. Results indicate a notable inverse relationship (17%, P= 0,003; 5,2%, p = 017 between elevated VFEF and carbohydrate consumption, as well as a significant reduction (5.2%) in weight. Conversely, no association was observed between VEFE levels protein intake or dietary fat consumption levels were observed. Using multiple regression analysis to adjust for multiple covariates, these findings provide compelling evidence for the role VEFS in modulating glucose metabolism and feeding behaviors in type two diabetic individuals.

LLM_1:
Everyone knows why he's glancing around nervously. He sets his drink down, acutely aware of someone watching him, someone who knows. A chill runs down his spine as he feels the weight of countless eyes upon him in this very moment. The door is locked. There’s nowhere to escape.

A dark stain seeps down his leg. "I'll never live this down," he thinks, haunted by the videos he’s seen. He knows the camera was trained on him during his... accident.

Frantically, he pulls out his phone and texts a friend, "Hey man, great party, but I gotta go. I’ll be back later." He accelerates home, weaving through traffic, narrowly avoiding the cars around him.

He skids into his driveway, scanning the area. "FUCK YOU!" he bellows as he spots the drone retreating, capturing every moment for posterity. He opens his browser, navigates to YouTube, and unsubscribes from his once-favorite channel, "Lol Caught U on Camera."
LLM_2:
Everyone knows why he’s glancing around, his eyes darting from face to face. He sets his drink down, the glass clinking softly against the table—a sound swallowed by the party’s noise, yet deafening to him. Someone is watching. Someone *knows*. A cold thread of dread winds down his spine, tightening with every breath. The room feels airless, the door locked not just by a bolt, but by shame. There’s nowhere to run.

A dark stain blooms down his leg, slow and accusing. *I’ll never live this down.* The thought echoes, sharp as broken glass, mingling with memories of grainy, laughing videos he’s scrolled through in darker hours. He was the punchline now. He’d felt the lens on him earlier—a silent, unblinking witness to the stumble, the spill, the humiliating unraveling of a single careless moment.

Fingers trembling, he yanks his phone from his pocket. The screen glows like a lifeline. *Hey man, great party, but I gotta go. I’ll be back later.* He sends the lie into the digital ether, already moving, already fleeing. Outside, the night air does nothing to cool the heat in his cheeks. He slides into the driver’s seat, and the engine snarls to life. Tires screech as he pulls away, weaving through traffic with a reckless, desperate grace—swerving, cutting, a specter in the rearview mirrors of strangers.

Home. His driveway materializes like a mirage. He skids to a halt, gravel spraying. His eyes sweep the shadows of the front yard, the empty street, the too-quiet sky. And there—a faint, mechanical whir, a dark shape against the twilight. A drone, hovering like a vulture, its red eye gleaming. Rage, hot and sudden, erupts from his chest. “FUCK YOU!” he roars, the words tearing through the quiet suburb. The machine dips once, as if in mockery, then zips away, carrying his humiliation into the clouds.

Inside, the blue glow of his computer screen awaits. His hands are steady now, cold with purpose. He opens the browser. Types. YouTube loads, a cascade of thumbnails and faces. He finds the channel without searching—*Lol Caught U on Camera*—its cheerful, merciless logo a familiar ghost. His cursor hovers over the *Subscribed* button. One click. It turns gray. *Unsubscribed*. 

He sits back. The room is very quiet. Somewhere, in some editing suite, his moment of shame is already being trimmed, tagged, and queued for the world’s amusement. But here, in the dark, he has taken back the one thing he could: his attention. It feels like a small, bitter victory. The kind you nurse in silence, alone.

human: The United Kingdom's constitution, being uncodified and largely unwritten, makes no mention of a prime minister. Though it had de facto existed for centuries, its first mention in official state documents did not occur until the first decade of the twentieth century. Accordingly, it is often said "not to exist", indeed there are several instances of parliament declaring this to be the case. The prime minister sits in the cabinet solely by virtue of occupying another office, either First Lord of the Treasury (office in commission), or more rarely Chancellor of the Exchequer (the last of whom was Balfour in 1905).
LLM_1: The constitution of the United Kingdom is uncodified and largely unwritten, and it does not explicitly mention the position of prime minister. Although the role has effectively existed for centuries, its first reference in official state documents did not appear until the first decade of the twentieth century. Consequently, it is often stated that the position "does not exist," with several instances of Parliament affirming this claim. The prime minister serves in the cabinet solely by virtue of holding another office, typically that of First Lord of the Treasury (a position in commission), or, more rarely, Chancellor of the Exchequer, the last individual to occupy this role being Arthur Balfour in 1905.
LLM_2: The un codified constitution and predominantly unwrittent nature of government in United kingdom doesnot explicitly define the office of Prime Minister. Despite the effective existence of this position for several centuries its formal recognition in state records didnot occur until early twentieth-century. As a result, statements that "the position does exist" have been repeatedly made by parliament, with multiple instances affirm this assertion. However, in reality, prime ministers serve in cabinet by default, solely because they hold another high office typically First lord of treasury (in commission) or more infrequently Chancellor exchequers, as was the case of Arthur balfur in1902

human:
This paper proposes a new method for speeding up convolutional neural networks. Different from previous work, it uses the idea of early terminating the computation of convolutional layers. The method itself is intuitive and easy to understand. By sorting the parameters in a descending order and early stopping the computation in a filter, it can reduce the computation cost (MAC) while preserving accuracy.

1. The networks used in the experiments are very simple. I understand that in the formulation part the assumption is that ReLU layer is put directly after convolutional layer. However, in state-of-the-art network, batch normalization layer is put between convolutional layer and ReLU non-linearity. It would add much value if the authors could justify the use cases of the proposed method on the widely adopted networks such as ResNet. 

2. I notice that there is a process that sort the parameters in the convolutional layers. However, the authors do not give any time complexity analysis about this process. I would like see how weight sorting influences the inference time.

3. The title contains the word “dynamic”. However, I notice that the parameter e used in the paper is predefined (or chosen from a set predefined of values). So i am not sure it is appropriate to use the word “dynamic” here. Correct me if i am wrong here.

4. In the experiment part, the authors choose two baselines: FPEC [1]. However, to my knowledge, their methods are performed on different networks. Also, the pruned models from their methods are carefully designed using sensitivity analysis. So I am curious how are the baselines designed in your experiments.

Overall this paper is well-written and points a new direction to speeding up neural networks. I like the analysis in section 3.

I will consider revising the score if the authors can address my concerns.


[1] Pruning Filters for Efficient ConvNets. Li et al., ICLR 2017.
LLM_1:
This paper introduces a novel approach aimed at accelerating convolutional neural networks. Unlike prior research, it leverages the concept of terminating the computation in convolutional layers early. The proposed method is both intuitive and accessible. By arranging parameters in descending order and halting computations for certain filters, it effectively reduces computational costs (MAC) while maintaining accuracy.

1. The networks utilized in the experiments are relatively basic. While I recognize that the formulation assumes a ReLU layer follows the convolutional layer directly, it is important to note that contemporary state-of-the-art networks, such as ResNet, typically incorporate a batch normalization layer in between. A detailed justification of the applicability of the proposed method to widely adopted architectures would significantly enhance the paper's contribution.

2. I observed that the process of sorting parameters within the convolutional layers is mentioned; however, the authors do not provide any analysis regarding the time complexity of this sorting process. It would be beneficial to understand how the weight sorting impacts inference time.

3. The title includes the term "dynamic." However, it appears that the parameter 'e' used in the paper is predefined or selected from a limited set of values. Therefore, I question the appropriateness of using "dynamic" in this context. Please clarify this point.

4. In the experimental section, the authors select two baselines: FPEC [1]. However, to my knowledge, these methods are evaluated on different networks. Additionally, the pruned models generated from their methods are meticulously crafted using sensitivity analysis. I am curious about the design of the baselines used in your experiments.

Overall, this paper is well-articulated and presents a promising direction for enhancing the efficiency of neural networks. I appreciate the analysis provided in Section 3.

I will consider adjusting the score should the authors address my concerns. 

[1] Pruning Filters for Efficient ConvNets. Li et al., ICLR 2017.
LLM_2:
This work presents an intriguing approach to accelerate convolution neural network computations by terminating convolution layers prematurely. Notably, its novelty lies in leveraging this concept to optimize performance. However the method's accessibility and intuitive nature are undeniable. Nonetheless, by sorting convolution parameters and early halts, computational expenses (e.g., MAC) are significantly reduced while accuracy is maintained.

One aspect that stands out is the simplicity of networks employed in experiments. Considering that most state of-the art architectures, like ResNest, usually incorporate batch normalisation layers after convolution, a comprehensive explanation of how this method applies to mainstream architectures is crucial to elevate the contribution of paper.

Upon reviewing the sorting of parameters process, one realisation is that no in-depth analysis of its time-complexity is provided. Understanding the effect of weight-sorting on inference times would greatly benefit the reader's comprehension of proposed solution.

Interestingly, despite the title's emphasis on the dynamic nature of method, 'dynamic' parameter e appears to pre-defined or chosen from limited values set. Thus, clarification on usage of term 'dynamics' in context would provide clarity.

In experimental evaluation, FPECK [ 1 ] is used as a baseline, however the respective methods appear to operate on separate networks with meticulously constructed prunned models using senstivity analysis, which prompts a question about baseline's design.

This well-written paper provides a compelling direction to improve neural efficiency. Although, further analysis in section  4 would further enhance paper,  The author's analysis presented in  section three is noteworthy and commendable.

If authors can address these points, my score may adjust accordingly.

**Summary**
This paper introduces a library that implements 1 infectious disease model and 3 agents in a gym environment. The authors provide analysis for a covid-19 lock down scenario using their library.

**Strengths**
The paper addresses an important and timely topic. The paper is easy to read and follow. The authors have open sourced their library and it seems to be well documented.

**Weaknesses**
The main weakness of the paper is the strength of the contributions. The authors’ main contributions are a gym environment for a specific epidemiological model.

Unfortunately, the novelty is somewhat lacking. As the authors mention in the conclusion section this line of work has been heavily researched. There are many infectious disease models and simulation environments already out there. **Strengths**  
The paper addresses an important and timely topic. It is easy to read and follow, and the authors have made their library open source, which appears to be well documented.

---

### **Summary**  
This paper presents a software library that implements one infectious disease transmission model and three associated agents within a Gym-compatible environment. The authors apply their framework to simulate and analyze a COVID-19 lockdown scenario, aiming to demonstrate its utility in public health decision-making contexts.

### **Strengths**  
The work addresses a timely and socially significant domain—computational modeling of infectious disease dynamics. The manuscript is clearly written and well-structured, facilitating readability. Furthermore, the authors have made their code publicly available under an open-source license, accompanied by documentation that enhances reproducibility and potential for community adoption.

### **Weaknesses**  
The primary limitation of the paper lies in the scope and novelty of its contributions. While the development of a Gym-based environment for epidemiological simulation is conceptually useful, the current implementation offers only a single disease model and a limited set of agents, which constrains its generalizability and applicability across diverse public health scenarios. Moreover, as acknowledged by the authors, this research area is not new: several existing frameworks already provide similar functionalities. Notably, a comparable Gym-like environment for infectious disease modeling was recently released by Google’s ML Fairness Gym (https://github.com/google/ml-fairness-gym/blob/master/environments/infectious_disease.py), which raises questions about the degree of technical innovation.

Additionally, the empirical evaluation remains preliminary. The analysis focuses on a single use case without systematic comparison across multiple agents or disease parameters, limiting the depth of scientific insight derived from the simulations. As such, the current contribution risks being perceived as one among many simulation toolkits, rather than a transformative or foundational advancement in the field.

### **Suggestions for Improvement**  
To strengthen the paper and broaden its impact, the following enhancements are recommended:  

a) **Expand the library's scope**: Incorporating additional disease models (e.g., SEIR variants, vector-borne diseases) and a wider range of agent behaviors (e.g., heterogeneous compliance, mobility patterns) would significantly improve the framework’s versatility and position it as a more comprehensive platform for epidemic simulation.

b) **Deepen the scientific analysis**: A more rigorous comparative study—evaluating agent performance across different intervention strategies, population structures, or outbreak scenarios—could yield meaningful insights into policy design and trade-offs, thereby elevating the paper beyond a purely engineering contribution.

c) **Demonstrate real-world relevance**: Including evidence of engagement with public health stakeholders—such as partnerships with government agencies, pilot deployments, or integration into policy discussions—would substantiate claims of practical impact and increase the credibility of the library as a decision-support tool.

Addressing these points would substantially enhance both the scholarly value and societal relevance of the work.

At around midnight, then-Governor Bill Clinton joined Hillary, his campaign manager Gloria Cabe, and me in a small breakfast room adjacent to the kitchen. My polling data for the upcoming 1990 gubernatorial reelection indicated that Clinton's opponent, McRae, had significantly diminished Clinton's support to a mere 43 percent. Typically, when an incumbent's poll numbers dip below 50 percent, it signals a looming defeat. 

In a fit of frustration, Clinton's emotions erupted. Exhausted and anxious, he shouted, "You got me into this race just to line your pockets! That was your only motivation! And now, I get nothing from you—no support at all. I’m about to lose this primary against a nobody!" Clinton was known for his volatile temper, and under the weight of harsh criticism, I also lost my composure. While his critique may have been hasty, my response was equally sharp. 

As I stormed out of the breakfast room and headed toward the door, I vented, "Thank you, thank you! You’ve just solved my problem. I’m getting flack from Atwater and Lott for working with you, and now I can resolve it. Go screw yourself! I’m quitting this campaign and becoming a free agent. I can be a Republican across all fifty states without taking your nonsense!"

Clinton quickly rushed after me, grabbing me from behind and encircling his arms to prevent my departure. I slipped to the floor, and Hillary helped me up. As soon as I stood, Clinton shifted to an apologetic tone, pleading, "Don't go, please! I’m sorry. Don’t leave; I’m really sorry!" I walked out, slamming the door behind me. 

Hillary chased after me, wrapping her arms around my shoulders in an attempt to calm my fury. "Please forgive him," she urged. "He’s under immense pressure and didn’t mean it. He’s so sorry, overtired, and hasn’t slept well. He values you and truly needs you." 

I managed to compose myself enough to drive to my hotel, where I called Eileen, trembling with anger. Later, Hillary reached out to inform me how desperately Bill wanted me back. Eventually, he got on the line to apologize. Although I couldn’t abandon Clinton just three weeks before his primary, from that moment on, I interacted with him in a more formal, almost distant manner. I stopped calling him Bill and began addressing him as Governor, making my exit promptly after meetings instead of lingering to chat.
LLM_2:
At just past midnight, the tension in the Arkansas Governor’s Mansion was palpable. Then-Governor Bill Clinton, First Lady Hillary Clinton, campaign manager Gloria Cabe, and I huddled in a modest breakfast nook tucked beside the kitchen—our last meeting before the final stretch of the 1990 gubernatorial race.

The mood darkened the moment I shared the latest polling data: Clinton’s support had slipped to 43%, with challenger Sheffield Nelson (often dismissed as a political "nobody") gaining surprising traction. For any incumbent, numbers below 50% this close to election day are a red flag—often a prelude to defeat. The weight of that reality pressed down hard.

And then, it exploded.

Exhausted, stressed, and staring down potential political ruin, Clinton snapped. “You brought me into this mess just to cash in!” he shouted at me, voice raw with anger. “That’s all you ever cared about—your fee! And now? Nothing! No help, no loyalty. I’m going to lose—to *him*?”  

I won’t pretend I took it well. Known for his temper, Clinton could ignite a room in seconds. That night, under fire from someone I’d worked tirelessly to support, I fired back just as fiercely. His words were unfair—but mine weren’t much better.

Fuming, I turned and stormed toward the door. “Thanks,” I spat over my shoulder. “You’ve just made my decision easy. I’ve been getting heat from Atwater, Lott, everyone—for working with you. Now I can walk away clean. Screw this. I’m out. Free agent. Republican consultant in all fifty states—you’ll never have to see me again.”

Before I could reach the exit, Clinton lunged after me, wrapping his arms around me from behind in a desperate attempt to stop me. I broke free, stumbled to the floor—and Hillary was there instantly, helping me up, her expression urgent.

As soon as I stood, the tone shifted. The rage melted into regret. “Don’t go,” Clinton pleaded, voice cracking. “Please. I’m sorry. I didn’t mean it. Stay. I need you.”

But I was done—for the moment. I walked out, slamming the door behind me.

Hillary followed, catching up outside. She grabbed my shoulders, her voice steady but insistent. “Please forgive him,” she said. “He’s running on fumes. He hasn’t slept in days. He didn’t mean it—he values you, he *needs* you. It’s just the pressure.”

Shaken, I drove back to my hotel, hands trembling. I called my wife, Eileen, still vibrating with adrenaline. Later that night, Hillary called again—this time to say Bill was desperate for me to return. Eventually, he got on the phone himself, apologetic and subdued.

I stayed on the campaign—how could I leave three weeks before the primary? But things changed. The easy rapport was gone. I stopped calling him Bill. From then on, it was “Governor.” I showed up for meetings, did my job, and left immediately after—no more lingering, no more casual banter. The trust had cracked, and while we kept working together, we never fully repaired what broke that night.

It was a turning point—not just in the campaign, but in our relationship. A reminder that even in politics, where egos run high and stress runs higher, emotions can burn too hot to ignore.

My group spent much of the period analyzing what the main theme of the book was and we came to two conclusions.  The first theme that we noticed was the naive/optimistic attitude the Jews had towards the Germans and the treatment they would receive in the events that led up to being sent to Auschwitz.(sp?)  The basis behind this theme most likely comes from the strong faith Jews had in God at this time period.  Even after being sent to the concentration and experiencing the cruel treatment of the Germans, Jews still had an optimistic view stating 'God must be testing us.'  Although Weisel himself begins to lose faith in God, many Jews still believed God was 'just testing them.'    The second theme my group noticed was individualism in the concentration camps.  Because the happenings at Auschwitz are so horrible, they begin to mold the spirit of many of the prisoners, Wielsel in particular.  This theme is best shown when Wiesel's father is being beaten severely by a crazed guard.  Instead of Wiesel becoming angry toward the guard, he instead is angry at his father for getting in the guards way.  Wiesel, like many others, lose their ties with family and friends in an effort to 'fend for themselves' at the concentration camps.   These are the two most prominent themes my group saw in the book, are we missing a big one?  -Pat
LLM_1:
Like many others, today’s small group discussion has sparked new reflections on the book *Night*. My group dedicated a significant portion of our time to analyzing the main themes of the book, and we arrived at two key conclusions. 

The first theme we identified was the naive optimism that many Jews held regarding their treatment by the Germans leading up to their deportation to Auschwitz. This perspective likely stemmed from the deep faith Jews had in God during this period. Even after being sent to concentration camps and enduring the brutal treatment inflicted by the Germans, many maintained an optimistic outlook, believing that "God must be testing us." While Elie Wiesel himself grapples with his faith, numerous Jews still clung to the idea that their suffering was merely a test from God.

The second theme we observed was the emergence of individualism within the concentration camps. The horrific experiences at Auschwitz profoundly affected the spirits of many prisoners, particularly Wiesel. This theme is poignantly illustrated when Wiesel witnesses his father being violently beaten by a deranged guard. Instead of directing his anger at the guard, Wiesel finds himself furious with his father for getting in the way. Like many others, Wiesel and his fellow prisoners are forced to sever their bonds with family and friends in a desperate attempt to survive in the camps.

These two themes stood out most prominently in our discussion. Are there any significant themes we might have overlooked?
LLM_2:
The language has been elevated slightly while preserving your original ideas and voice:

---

**Reflections on *Night*: Faith, Survival, and the Erosion of Humanity**

Today’s small group discussion on Elie Wiesel’s *Night* left me with fresh insights—and a deeper appreciation for the book’s emotional and moral complexity. Like many others grappling with this powerful memoir, our conversation centered on its central themes, two of which resonated particularly strongly.

The first was the **naive optimism** held by so many Jews in the face of mounting horror. Even as deportations loomed and conditions deteriorated, there remained a persistent belief—rooted deeply in faith—that God would not abandon them. This trust endured even after arrival at Auschwitz. As Wiesel recounts, some prisoners interpreted their suffering as a divine test: “God must be testing us.” It’s a heartbreaking testament to the resilience of faith, even when confronted with unimaginable cruelty. Yet, as Wiesel himself begins to question, how can one maintain belief in a benevolent God amid such silence?

This leads to the second major theme that emerged in our discussion: the **rise of individualism in the face of dehumanization**. Life in the concentration camps systematically stripped away not only dignity but also human connection. One of the most haunting moments in the book comes when Wiesel watches his father being beaten by a guard—not with outrage at the perpetrator, but with anger toward his own father for “provoking” the attack. That moment captures a devastating psychological shift: survival becomes so all-consuming that even familial love is buried beneath self-preservation. In the camp’s brutal economy of existence, empathy becomes a luxury few can afford.

These two themes—**the crisis of faith** and **the erosion of human bonds**—stood out as the emotional core of our conversation. They reveal how totalitarian violence doesn’t just destroy lives; it distorts souls.

Still, I’m left wondering: did we miss anything? Are there other layers of meaning in *Night* that deserve equal attention? Perhaps the role of memory, or the responsibility of witness? I’d welcome your thoughts.

The authors present a new large-scale musculoskeletal radiographs dataset labeled as normal or abnormal. They show high-level quality of work in extracting and labeling the 40,562 radiograph images. On this dataset, they evaluate the performance of detection and localization of abnormalities using a trained 169-layer Dense net. The model performance is compared to the labeling of six board-certified radiologists. Detailed evaluation using the Cohen's Kappa statistic and comparison of the model performance vs. expert radiologists' performance.
The work is original mainly by the scale of medical-image-dataset. Interesting work is presented on using multi-view images for classifying the images to normal or abnormal cases. It would be interesting to further examine the influence of using multi-view images and the ability of the network to classify the abnormality type.

Pros:
-	The authors present a new large-scale musculoskeletal radiographs dataset of 40,562 images with true labels by radiologists (not NLP).
-	The authors show high quality results for normal vs abnormal classification using a 169-layer Dense net. They analyze the results using a couple of methods: Using an ROC curve presentation of the operation point and via comparison of the model and radiologist to the gold standard (using the Cohen's Kappa statistic).
-	The authors give a nice overview of the current open datasets of radiograph images
-	 Will make the MURA dataset public.
Cons:
-	The authors use multi-view images of the same study by using a simplistic model of averaging the probabilities of all views in the same network. 
-	The authors use an ensemble of 5 models. How is the ensemble performed? Using average of probabilities\ majority vote\ other?
-	The authors present a list of abnormalities they found by reviewing the radiologist reports – It would be interesting to show if the presented model can classify the abnormality type (fractures, disease…)
-	Figures and tables: Figure 2 in a bit confusing as the input to model can be either a single image or  multi-view images (not always 2 views).  Table 1 – please add explanation to numbers X (Y, Z)
LLM_1:
The authors introduce a comprehensive dataset of musculoskeletal radiographs, comprising 40,562 images categorized as normal or abnormal. Their meticulous work in extracting and labeling these images demonstrates a commendable level of quality. They assess the model's capability in detecting and localizing abnormalities utilizing a 169-layer DenseNet, comparing its performance against the evaluations made by six board-certified radiologists. A thorough analysis is provided through the Cohen's Kappa statistic, juxtaposing the model's results with those of expert radiologists.

The originality of this work is primarily attributed to the extensive scale of the medical image dataset. Additionally, the approach of employing multi-view images for the classification of normal versus abnormal cases is particularly noteworthy. Further exploration into the impact of multi-view images on the network's ability to identify specific types of abnormalities would be beneficial.

Pros:
- The authors introduce a novel large-scale dataset of musculoskeletal radiographs, featuring 40,562 images with accurate labels provided by radiologists, as opposed to NLP methods.
- They demonstrate impressive results in classifying normal versus abnormal images using a 169-layer DenseNet, supported by various analytical techniques, including ROC curve representation and comparisons to expert radiologists against a gold standard using Cohen's Kappa statistic.
- The authors provide a solid overview of existing open datasets related to radiograph images.
- The MURA dataset will be made publicly available.

Cons:
- The utilization of multi-view images from the same study relies on a basic model that averages the probabilities from all views within a single network.
- The authors employ an ensemble of five models; however, the method of ensemble integration remains unclear. Is it based on averaging probabilities, majority voting, or another technique?
- While the authors list the abnormalities identified through radiologist reports, it would be valuable to demonstrate whether the proposed model can classify the specific types of abnormalities, such as fractures or diseases.
- Regarding figures and tables, Figure 2 is somewhat ambiguous, as the model input can consist of either a single image or multiple views, which may not always be limited to two. Additionally, Table 1 would benefit from an explanation of the figures labeled X (Y, Z).
LLM_2:
The authors present a large-scale dataset of musculoskeletal radiographs (MURA), consisting of 40,562 images labeled as normal or abnormal by radiologists. They evaluate a 169-layer DenseNet for abnormality detection and localization, comparing its performance against six board-certified radiologists using metrics such as Cohen’s Kappa. The work is distinguished by the scale of the dataset and the use of multi-view images for classification.

**Strengths**  
- Introduction of a novel, large-scale musculoskeletal radiograph dataset with radiologist-curated labels.  
- Strong performance in normal vs. abnormal classification using a DenseNet architecture, supported by ROC analysis and radiologist benchmarking.  
- Comprehensive overview of existing public radiograph datasets.  
- The dataset will be made publicly available, which is a valuable contribution to the community.

**Weaknesses**  
- The multi-view approach averages probabilities across views within a single network, which is relatively simplistic.  
- The ensemble method (five models) is not clearly described—e.g., is it based on probability averaging, voting, or another strategy?  
- While abnormalities are listed in radiologist reports, the model’s ability to classify specific abnormality types (e.g., fracture, disease) is not demonstrated.  
- **Figure/Table clarity:**  
  - Figure 2 could better illustrate that model input may include one or multiple views (not necessarily two).  
  - Table 1 should clarify the notation used (e.g., explain the meaning of values presented as X (Y, Z)).

**Suggestions**  
- Explore more advanced multi-view fusion techniques.  
- Clarify the ensemble integration method.  
- Extend evaluation to include fine-grained abnormality classification.  
- Revise Figure 2 and Table 1 for improved clarity and completeness.

LLM_1: The traditional scarf osteotomy has been associated with complication rates ranging from 1.1% to 45%. In this study, we modified the traditional technique by incorporating a rotational osteotomy aimed at reducing these complications. We aimed to determine whether the modified rotational scarf osteotomy improves functional outcome scores, facilitates correction of a wide range of intermetatarsal (IM) angle deformities, exhibits a low incidence of troughing, and maintains normal range of motion (ROM) postoperatively in the treatment of symptomatic hallux valgus (HV). We conducted a retrospective review of 140 patients, comprising 38 men and 102 women, with a mean age of 54 years (range, 35-66 years) who underwent surgery for HV and had a minimum follow-up period of 24 months (mean, 41 months; range, 24-68 months). Preoperative and postoperative American Orthopaedic Foot and Ankle Society (AOFAS) forefoot and Short Form (SF)-36 V2 outcome scores were recorded for all patients. The mean AOFAS score improved from 52 points preoperatively to 92 points (range, 71-96 points) at follow-up. The mean SF-36 V2 score increased from 69 points preoperatively to 94 points (range, 67-98 points) at follow-up. The IM angle improved from a preoperative mean of 18° (range, 9°-23°) to a mean of 8° (range, 6°-12°). Eleven patients experienced complications.
LLM_2:
**Abstract**

Traditional scarf osteotomy for hallux valgus (HV) correction is associated with complication rates ranging from 1.1% to 45%. This study introduces a modified rotational scarf osteotomy designed to reduce complications and evaluates its efficacy in improving functional outcomes, correcting a wide spectrum of intermetatarsal (IM) angle deformities, minimizing troughing, and preserving postoperative range of motion (ROM).  

A retrospective review was conducted of 140 patients (38 men, 102 women; mean age 54 years, range 35–66) who underwent the modified procedure for symptomatic HV, with a minimum follow-up of 24 months (mean 41 months, range 24–68). Preoperative and postoperative outcomes were assessed using the American Orthopaedic Foot and Ankle Society (AOFAS) forefoot score and the Short Form (SF)-36 V2.  

The mean AOFAS score improved from 52 preoperatively to 92 (range 71–96) at follow-up. The mean SF-36 V2 score increased from 69 to 94 (range 67–98). The IM angle was corrected from a mean of 18° (range 9°–23°) preoperatively to 8° (range 6°–12°) postoperatively. Complications occurred in 11 patients.  

These findings suggest that the modified rotational scarf osteotomy is effective in improving functional scores, achieving substantial IM angle correction, and maintaining favorable postoperative outcomes with a low complication rate in the treatment of hallux valgus.

The building was on fire, and it was n't my fault. 
 
 I'd been working with Him for a while, bit older than me. He had a fine face, olive-skinned, very exotic. He told me that my luck would be different this time, that I would relinquish all these weights.. all these times where everything had gone horribly, horribly wrong. 
 
 `` I'll guide you, you will change. You'll be in control,'' He promised. 
 
 The promise was control of myself, control of where my fingers went, who I saw and who saw me, where my life would go. If anything bad ever happened, it would n't be my fault anymore; I was in control, and only good things would ever happen. 
 
 He gave me a lighter and told me, `` Let it go, let it kindle in the concrete..'' 
 
 So I did. And I was not to blame. The whole thing set ablaze and I had no responsibility for it, and I was not responsible for anyone's sorrow, He had taken the precautions, and I was, for once, without conscience. 
 
 So I got bored.
LLM_1:
The building blazed with flames, but I wasn’t to blame. 

I had been collaborating with Him for some time now; he was a few years my senior. His features were striking, his skin a warm olive, exuding an exotic charm. He assured me that this time would be different, that I would shed all the burdens of my past—those countless moments when everything had gone disastrously wrong. 

“I’ll lead you,” he promised. “You will transform. You’ll have control.” 

His words echoed the promise of mastery over my own life—over my actions, my choices, and the paths I would tread. No longer would the shadows of misfortune haunt me; I was the one steering my fate, ensuring that only good would come my way. 

He handed me a lighter and whispered, “Release it. Let it ignite the concrete.” 

So I did. And in that moment, I felt no guilt. The inferno spread, and I bore no burden for the destruction; He had taken all necessary precautions, and, for once, I was free from the weight of my conscience. 

Boredom began to creep in.
LLM_2:
The building was a pyre against the night, a roaring, living thing—but the fire was not mine to claim.

I had been working with Him for months. He was older, his presence carved from something darker and warmer than the world I knew. Olive skin, sharp features, a voice that felt like a secret being passed from one hand to another. He told me this would be the turning. The last of my old ghosts—the ones that clung like smoke after every failed attempt, every collapse, every wrong turn—would burn away here.

“Follow me,” he said, and it sounded less like a request and more like a key turning. “You’ll change. You’ll hold the reins.”

It was the promise of agency. Of a life where my hands did what I intended, where my steps fell where I chose, where the old echoes of calamity finally fell silent. I would not just walk my path—I would lay it down, stone by stone, and light the way myself.

He passed me the lighter. Its metal was cool, its weight certain. “Let it go,” he murmured, close enough that the words brushed my ear. “Let it catch the stone.”

So I let it go.

And I felt nothing. No guilt, no tremor, no afterthought. The flames rushed out like something unleashed, and I watched, unburdened. He had accounted for everything—the spread, the sound, the way the heat would warp the air. And my conscience, for once, was quiet. Still.

Then, slowly, boredom began to seep into the silence.

 Jack stared for a few seconds before he leaned down and tore the shirt off a corpse. He tied it around his torn flesh. It was only going to be enough to get him home. He'd figure out what to do from there. He walked over and picked up the pistol and took the girls hand with his own. `` Come on. Lets get you out of here.''

The Sliv'ten girl trembled, her hands unsteadily gripping his .44. The moment overwhelmed her, and she dropped the weapon as if it had sprouted fangs, ready to bite.

Jack stared at her for a few heartbeats before he knelt and tore a strip of fabric from a nearby corpse. He wrapped it around his wounded flesh; it was only enough to get him home. The rest, he would figure out later. He walked over to retrieve the pistol and gently took the girl's hand in his own. "Come on. Let's get you out of here."
LLM_2:
A single, thunderous gunshot shattered the silence.  
The claws released him, and the final foe crumpled to the ground.  
Jack swayed, fighting to stay on his feet as he turned toward the sound.  

There stood the Sliv’ten girl, trembling, her small hands struggling to keep hold of his .44.  
The weight of the moment crashed over her—she dropped the pistol as though it had grown fangs, something alive and venomous in her grip.  

For a long breath, Jack only watched her.  
Then he knelt, tore a strip of cloth from a fallen body, and bound his bleeding arm.  
A rough fix—just enough to get him home. The rest could wait.  

He moved slowly to retrieve the gun, then turned back and took the girl’s hand, his touch firm but gentle.  
“Come on,” he said, his voice low, almost lost in the hollow quiet. “Let’s get you out of here.”

Enrique Marquez, 25, will acknowledge that he deceived authorities when he acquired firearms by asserting that they were intended for his own use instead of for another individual. He will also admit to conspiring to carry out a separate attack alongside one of the suspects, who was a childhood friend. Syed Rizwan Farook, a U.S. citizen, and his Pakistani-born wife, Tashfeen Malik, were both killed by police after they fatally shot 14 of Farook's colleagues during a holiday gathering at the San Bernardino Inland Regional Center, where he was employed. Authorities have stated that the couple, who married in Saudi Arabia in 2014, were motivated by Islamic extremism. Officials have noted that Marquez supplied the weapons, as Farook's Middle Eastern appearance might have drawn attention.

This shooting spree marked one of the deadliest attacks on American soil since September 11, 2001. Prosecutors concede that Marquez was not aware in advance of the couple's plot; however, they assert that his prior conspiratorial actions contributed to the inspiration behind the tragic events.

The attackers refrained from posting on social media, opting instead to communicate via a private messaging service. A closer examination of the 14 victims of the shooting reveals the human impact of the tragedy. The phenomenon of "lone-wolf" attacks raises questions about the frequency of radicalization occurring in secrecy, while statistical analysis of the San Bernardino shooting sheds light on the severity of the incident.

LLM_2:
**Los Angeles, CA** – In a federal courtroom this Thursday, 25-year-old Enrique Marquez is expected to plead guilty to charges of lying to authorities about the purchase of firearms and conspiring to carry out an earlier terrorist plot. As part of a plea agreement, prosecutors say he could face up to 25 years in prison.

Marquez will admit that he falsely claimed two rifles were for his own use when he bought them for another individual. He will also acknowledge conspiring with a childhood friend—later identified as Syed Rizwan Farook—to plan attacks on a local community college and a Southern California freeway in 2011 and 2012.

Farook and his wife, Tashfeen Malik, were killed by police after opening fire at a San Bernardino holiday gathering on December 2, 2015, killing 14 of Farook’s coworkers and wounding nearly two dozen others. Federal authorities have described the attack as one of the deadliest on U.S. soil since 9/11 and said the couple was inspired by Islamic extremism.

Although Marquez was not aware of the 2015 attack beforehand, prosecutors contend that his earlier plotting and weapons procurement helped enable the tragedy. “He collaborated with and purchased weapons for a man who carried out a devastating terrorist attack that impacted our entire nation,” said U.S. Attorney Eileen Decker in a statement.

Investigators noted that Marquez supplied the rifles in part because Farook’s Middle Eastern appearance might have attracted suspicion if he had tried to buy them himself. The attackers avoided public social media posts, communicating privately instead—a detail that highlights the challenge of detecting so-called “lone-wolf” extremism.

As part of the plea deal, immigration fraud charges against Marquez—related to a sham marriage with a relative of Farook’s sister-in-law—are expected to be dropped. Marquez and Farook became neighbors in Riverside, California, in 2005, and remained in contact in the years leading up to the attacks.

Decker added that while the earlier planned attacks on a school and freeway never occurred, “the planning clearly laid the foundation for the 2015 attack.” The case continues to draw attention to the hidden pathways of radicalization and the lasting trauma inflicted on victims and their communities.
