LLM_1:
Good morning, everyone! It’s been a few days since my last post, but honestly, not much has been happening. I attempted to fly to LA for a fraternity event the other day, but all the flights were fully booked. No big deal, though—I really couldn’t afford the trip anyway. While I was in DC for Valentine’s Day, I completely overshot my budget for the last half of the month and totally forgot about my car payment. Classic me!

On my flight back from DC, I ended up on a plane filled with 13-year-olds. Let me tell you, that experience definitely reinforced my belief that more people should consider "eating their young." I have a newfound respect for teachers in today’s world.

Recently, I’ve been chatting on gay.com, which isn’t something I usually do since I tend to reach my social saturation pretty quickly. However, I figured it wouldn’t hurt to be a bit more outgoing. My screen name there is yngPOZcentaur, and my profile clearly states I’m not looking for a hookup. Yet, it never fails—within the first five minutes of chatting with someone, they always ask if I’m a top or bottom. I don’t mind answering that when I'm interested in something more, but usually, I just humor them. 

One guy pushed it a bit further when I answered his question, and he followed up with, “Great, are you clean?” I responded jokingly, “Yes, I just got out of the shower and am all douched up... I’m never a dirty fuck.” Apparently, he didn’t catch my humor and said, “I mean, are you disease-free?” I replied, “What part of yngPOZcentaur are you not getting? It’s all over my profile!” He apologized and said he could deal with poz guys, to which I quipped, “You’re in luck, because I can’t deal with stupid people.” 

Another guy reached out just to say he was sorry. Being a glutton for punishment, I asked him why. He said, “I’m sorry that you’re HIV+ and just wanted to make you feel better.” I appreciated his concern—I hadn’t realized I was feeling down until he pointed it out! I mean, I was just waiting for a complete stranger to tell me everything would be okay so I could get on with my life. It makes me wonder where some people learn their manners. When did it become acceptable to open a conversation with a total stranger like that? I quickly realized that my mission in life isn’t to educate the chatroom on etiquette, so I just ignore those fools and hope they’ll eventually understand how ridiculous they sound.

On another note, the boys are approaching their final assessments, and I’ve been worried about whether they’re truly prepared for brotherhood. I constantly remind myself that we (the mentors) aren’t just a chapter bringing in a pledge class—our focus should be on quality, not quantity. These guys hastily organized a fundraiser, and honestly, it hurt them more than it helped. Many of them can’t afford the fees required to become brothers.

What really troubles me is that there are seven out of seventeen pledges with whom I’ve never spoken. That’s a significant issue because it shows they haven’t fulfilled their commitment to becoming brothers. By ignoring me, they’re sending a clear message that they’re not fully engaged. This situation upset me and led to an argument with Andrew, which is rare for us. He pointed out that I’m “out of sight, out of mind” and that I’m not as available as the other mentors. While that’s true—I’m not physically present much—I do email the group frequently, offer alternatives to reach me, and make myself available at all times.

My concern is if they’re forgetting me now, how will they treat alumni in the future? Will they forget they have brothers once they graduate? Clay, their president, just got accepted for a study abroad semester—will they lose touch with him too because he’s “out of sight”? 

Then, the final straw came when a few pledges requested that the mentors not attend the rush event on Friday night at Dream. I’ve known Andrew for a while and have seen him upset, even a bit angry, but he reached new levels with this request. The boys came back with excuses like, “What we meant was that we want you guys at our events... someone misunderstood.” Or, “We just don’t want you doing it for us,” which feels like they’re shifting the blame onto the mentors. The truth is, the event is at a nightclub, and many of them planned to drink, knowing that it would create chaos for underage drinking—and they were right!

I know there are plenty of them eager to get their interviews done with me to avoid missing points. Unfortunately, instead of using the interview as a chance to get to know me, it’s become just another assignment. I’m granting the interviews as long as I have time, but it feels like they’re now on my schedule. As Andrew said, it’s unfortunate that some of them have overlooked me as a resource. I think it’s even sadder that they haven’t taken the time to know me as a friend. I like to think I’m pretty cool!

Well, that’s enough rambling for now. I’ll write more as thoughts come to me!
LLM_2:
**A Week in Review: Lessons Learned and Growing Concerns**

It's been several days, or so it seems, since our last update. To be honest, life has taken a backseat, with nothing too exciting happening in my corner of reality. A planned trip to Los Angeles was foiled by booked flights, a harsh reality check on our family's budget, courtesy of my DC escapades, left me scrambling to cover essential expenses. Another reminder that adulting isn't always easy!

My recent flight from the nation's capital to our hometown was a wild ride, literally. Sharing a cramped space with rowdy teenagers was an experience I won't soon forget. On the bright side, this encounter reinforced the importance of teacher appreciation in our society.

To shake things up, my online presence has expanded to gay. com, an unusual move for someone like me who values social balance. Under the screenname ynp0ZCentaur (my attempt at creativity), my intentions are clear: no hookups, please. Despite this, some users still find ways to dive into sensitive topics, like HIV status. One guy took the bait, only to realize my lighthearted response, before eventually apologizing for his misstep. Not all interactions are as fruitful, however.

Another conversation that left a lasting impression was with an individual who apologized for making assumptions about me. His genuine concern touched my heart, reminding me that empathy can go a long way.

This brings us to more pressing matters. With the semester's end approaching, our young brothers are preparing for their assessments. Our focus as mentors should remain on building meaningful relationships, rather than just filling spots. Recent events have shown that quantity over quality can lead to unintended consequences. An ill-conceived fundraiser has left some members struggling to afford their fees.

As we move forward, one issue that's kept me up at night is the fact that seven of our seventeen pledge members have yet to establish a genuine connection with us as their mentors (or so they claim). This lack of engagement sends a concerning message about their willingness to participate in brotherly activities. Even more disheartening is their apparent disregard for our presence and contributions.

Andrew, in his characteristic calm, pointed this out, suggesting that our absence from their lives might lead them to forget their brothers and alumni once we're no longer physically there. Meanwhile, requests for mentor absence at an upcoming event left us feeling perplexed.

It seems that, as we near the end of this semester, we have some work to do in terms of building genuine relationships and fostering a sense of brotherliness among our pledge group. Time will tell if we can turn this around and create a more positive experience for everyone involved. Until then, let's keep pushing forward. More to come in future updates!

human: The efficacy of coronary stenting of aorto-ostial atherosclerotic lesions is still unclear. We investigated the frequency and mechanism of stent restenosis at this particular lesion.Fifty-five consecutive patients with 64 native aorto-ostial lesions in the right coronary artery (RCA, n = 38) and the left main trunk (LM, n = 26) were treated by conventional stenting. Determinants of angiographic restenosis were established. The mechanism of stent restenosis was evaluated using post-stenting and follow-up intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) findings.Restenosis was more frequent in the RCA than in the LM (50% compared with 19%, P < 0.03) and determinants included diabetes mellitus (63% compared with 21%, P < 0.03), calcium deposition (58% compared with 5%, P < 0.003), smaller stent cross-sectional area (SA) (as demonstrated by post-stenting IVUS studies, 8.1 +/- 1.4 mm compared with 10.2 +/- 2.2 mm, P < 0.01), larger plaque burden (64 +/- 6% compared with 57 +/- 8%, P < 0.03) and less circular expansion at the aorto-coronary junction. Serial IVUS examination was performed in 11 patients with restenosis of the right coronary ostium. The mean reduction in the SA was 21% at the aorto-coronary junction (6.4 +/- 1.9 mm, P < 0.003), whereas the SA at the distal edge was unchanged. Thirty-three per cent of late luminal loss was due to chronic stent recoil.
LLM_1: The efficacy of coronary stenting for aorto-ostial atherosclerotic lesions remains uncertain. This study aimed to investigate the frequency and mechanisms of stent restenosis associated with these lesions. We analyzed 55 consecutive patients with 64 native aorto-ostial lesions, comprising 38 in the right coronary artery (RCA) and 26 in the left main trunk (LM), all treated with conventional stenting. Determinants of angiographic restenosis were identified, and the mechanisms underlying stent restenosis were evaluated using post-stenting and follow-up intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) findings. Restenosis occurred more frequently in the RCA compared to the LM (50% vs. 19%, P < 0.03). Significant determinants of restenosis included diabetes mellitus (63% vs. 21%, P < 0.03), calcium deposition (58% vs. 5%, P < 0.003), a smaller stent cross-sectional area (SA) as measured by post-stenting IVUS (8.1 ± 1.4 mm vs. 10.2 ± 2.2 mm, P < 0.01), a larger plaque burden (64 ± 6% vs. 57 ± 8%, P < 0.03), and reduced circular expansion at the aorto-coronary junction. Serial IVUS examinations were conducted in 11 patients with restenosis at the right coronary ostium, revealing a mean reduction in SA of 21% at the aorto-coronary junction (6.4 ± 1.9 mm, P < 0.003), while the SA at the distal edge remained stable. Notably, 33% of late luminal loss was attributed to chronic stent recoil.
LLM_2:
The long-term efficacy of coronary stenting for aorto-ostial atherosclerotic lesions remains uncertain. This study aimed to evaluate the incidence and mechanisms of in-stent restenosis (ISR) in such lesions. We analyzed 55 consecutive patients with 64 native aorto-ostial lesions—38 in the right coronary artery (RCA) and 26 in the left main trunk (LM)—all treated with conventional stenting. Determinants of angiographic restenosis were identified, and the mechanisms of ISR were assessed using post-stenting and follow-up intravascular ultrasound (IVUS). Restenosis occurred more frequently in the RCA than in the LM (50% vs. 19%, *P* < 0.03). Significant predictors of restenosis included diabetes mellitus (63% vs. 21%, *P* < 0.03), lesion calcification (58% vs. 5%, *P* < 0.003), smaller post-stenting stent cross-sectional area (SA) by IVUS (8.1 ± 1.4 mm² vs. 10.2 ± 2.2 mm², *P* < 0.01), greater plaque burden (64 ± 6% vs. 57 ± 8%, *P* < 0.03), and incomplete circular stent expansion at the aorto-coronary junction. Serial IVUS in 11 patients with RCA ostial restenosis demonstrated a mean 21% reduction in SA at the aorto-coronary junction (6.4 ± 1.9 mm², *P* < 0.003), while the distal stent edge remained stable. Notably, chronic stent recoil accounted for 33% of late luminal loss.

---

**Key Improvements:**

1. **Clarity & Precision:**  
   - Specified “in-stent restenosis (ISR)” for clinical accuracy.  
   - Replaced “frequency” with “incidence” and “mechanisms of stent restenosis” with “mechanisms of ISR” for consistency.  
   - Changed “calcium deposition” to “lesion calcification,” a standard term in cardiology.

2. **Academic Tone:**  
   - Used formal phrasing (“evaluate,” “assessed,” “predictors,” “demonstrated”).  
   - Ensured consistent reporting of statistical significance (*P* values).  
   - Added units (mm²) for cross-sectional area where appropriate.

3. **Flow & Readability:**  
   - Improved sentence transitions for logical progression.  
   - Condensed descriptions without losing detail (e.g., “serial IVUS examinations were conducted in 11 patients” → “serial IVUS in 11 patients”).  
   - Clarified anatomical and procedural context concisely.

4. **Terminology Standardization:**  
   - “Reduced circular expansion” → “incomplete circular stent expansion.”  
   - “Late luminal loss” retained as a standard metric in interventional cardiology.

This version maintains the original meaning while enhancing academic rigor, clarity, and flow, suitable for publication in a medical or cardiovascular journal.

human: Rather than teach small parts of a large number of subjects, Whitehead advocated teaching a relatively few important concepts that the student could organically link to many different areas of knowledge, discovering their application in actual life. For Whitehead, education should be the exact opposite of the multidisciplinary, value-free school model – it should be transdisciplinary, and laden with values and general principles that provide students with a bedrock of wisdom and help them to make connections between areas of knowledge that are usually regarded as separate.
LLM_1: Whitehead proposed a departure from teaching numerous minor topics, advocating instead for a focus on a limited number of significant concepts. He believed that these concepts should enable students to connect various fields of knowledge and recognize their real-world applications. For Whitehead, education should stand in stark contrast to the traditional, multidisciplinary approach that lacks intrinsic values. Instead, he championed a transdisciplinary model enriched with values and overarching principles, providing students with a solid foundation of wisdom that facilitates connections across typically isolated areas of study.
LLM_2:
# Education Reimagined: Whitehead’s Call for Depth Over Breadth in Learning

Renowned philosopher and educator Alfred North Whitehead challenged conventional teaching methods by urging a shift away from covering countless minor subjects. Instead, he argued for concentrating on a select few fundamental ideas that help learners link different domains of knowledge and see their practical relevance.

Whitehead viewed traditional multidisciplinary education as often fragmented and devoid of deeper meaning. In contrast, he promoted a **transdisciplinary approach**—one infused with core values and guiding principles. This model, he believed, equips students with a foundational wisdom that bridges disciplines usually taught in isolation.

By focusing on significant, connective concepts, Whitehead envisioned an education that not only informs but also unifies, preparing students to apply learning in coherent, meaningful ways.

human: In response to pro-Tibet and pro-human rights protests, the Chinese media focused on the more disruptive protesters, referring for example to "a very small number of 'Tibet independence' secessionists and a handful of so-called human rights-minded NGO activists" intent on "disrupting and sabotaging the Beijing Olympic Games". However, the Chinese media published articles about crowds supporting the torch relay.
LLM_1: In the wake of pro-Tibet and human rights demonstrations, Chinese media spotlighted the more disruptive elements among the protesters, labeling them as "a very small number of 'Tibet independence' secessionists and a handful of so-called human rights-minded NGO activists" who were allegedly trying to "disrupt and sabotage the Beijing Olympic Games." Conversely, the media also showcased articles highlighting the crowds that supported the torch relay.
LLM_2:
**Beijing Olympics Torch Relay Draws Contrasting Public Responses**

Amidst demonstrations centered on Tibet and human rights issues during the lead-up to the 2008 Beijing Olympics, Chinese state media presented a sharply divided narrative. Reports emphasized what authorities described as a fringe element among protesters, referring to them as “a very small number of ‘Tibet independence’ separatists and a handful of so-called human rights NGO activists.” Official outlets alleged these individuals aimed to “disrupt and sabotage” the Games.

At the same time, media coverage prominently featured scenes of public support for the Olympic torch relay. Images and stories highlighted enthusiastic crowds lining the relay routes, underscoring national pride and popular backing for the event. This dual portrayal sought to balance the narrative by contrasting isolated protests with widespread domestic enthusiasm for the Olympics.

human: To study the effect of polygoni multiflori total glycosides (PMTG) on the expressions of ICAM-1 and VCAM-1 in the apoE-deficienct (ApoE-/-)mice with experimental atherosclerosis (AS) and underlying mechanism.Thirty-two female apoE-deficienct mice were randomized into four groups: high dose PMTG group (150 mg x kg(-1) x d(-1)), low dose PMTG group (25 mg x kg(-1) x d(-1)), atorvastatin positive control group (5 mg x kg(-1) x d(-1)) and model group. At the end of the tenth week of treatment, all mice were killed. The serum levels of total cholesterol (TC), triglyceride(TG), high-density lipoprotein-cholesterol (HDL-C) were measured by enzyme dynamics method. Light microscopy were adopted to assess the degree of atherosclerotic plaque of aortic wall and image analysis was performed with computer. The expressions of ICAM-1 and VCAM-1 were studied by SABC imunohistochemistry.In comparison with the model group, (1) PMTG reduced the levels of serum TC and TG significantly (P < 0.01), but elevated HDL level obviously (P < 0.01) . (2) PMTG increased the levels of serum NO and the anti-oxidation capacities significantly (P < 0.05 and P < 0.01), but reduced the levels of serum MDA markedly (P < 0.01). (3) PMTG reduced also the extent of atherosclerotic plaque of aorta areas were (P < 0.05). (4) PMTG deregulated the expressions of ICAM-1 and VCAM-1 in aortic wall.
LLM_1: This study investigates the effects of polygoni multiflori total glycosides (PMTG) on the expressions of intercellular adhesion molecule-1 (ICAM-1) and vascular cell adhesion molecule-1 (VCAM-1) in apolipoprotein E-deficient (ApoE-/-) mice with experimental atherosclerosis (AS), along with the underlying mechanisms. Thirty-two female ApoE-deficient mice were randomly assigned to four groups: a high-dose PMTG group (150 mg/kg/day), a low-dose PMTG group (25 mg/kg/day), an atorvastatin positive control group (5 mg/kg/day), and a model group. At the conclusion of the tenth week of treatment, all mice were euthanized. Serum levels of total cholesterol (TC), triglycerides (TG), and high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C) were measured using an enzymatic dynamic method. Light microscopy was employed to assess the extent of atherosclerotic plaque in the aortic wall, followed by image analysis using computer software. The expressions of ICAM-1 and VCAM-1 were evaluated through SABC immunohistochemistry. Compared to the model group, findings indicated that (1) PMTG significantly reduced serum levels of TC and TG (P < 0.01) while markedly increasing HDL levels (P < 0.01); (2) PMTG significantly elevated serum nitric oxide (NO) levels and antioxidant capacities (P < 0.05 and P < 0.01), while significantly decreasing serum malondialdehyde (MDA) levels (P < 0.01); (3) PMTG also reduced the extent of atherosclerotic plaque areas in the aorta (P < 0.05); and (4) PMTG downregulated the expressions of ICAM-1 and VCAM-1 in the aortic wall.
LLM_2:
**Abstract**

This study investigates the effects of *Polygoni multiflori* total glycosides (PMTG) on the expression of intercellular adhesion molecule‑1 (ICAM‑1) and vascular cell adhesion molecule‑1 (VCAM‑1) in apolipoprotein E‑deficient (ApoE⁻/⁻) mice with experimental atherosclerosis (AS), and explores the underlying mechanisms. Thirty‑two female ApoE⁻/⁻ mice were randomly divided into four groups: high‑dose PMTG (150 mg/kg/day), low‑dose PMTG (25 mg/kg/day), atorvastatin positive control (5 mg/kg/day), and model control. After ten weeks of treatment, serum levels of total cholesterol (TC), triglycerides (TG), and high‑density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL‑C) were measured enzymatically. Atherosclerotic plaque area in the aortic wall was quantified by light microscopy and computer‑assisted image analysis. ICAM‑1 and VCAM‑1 expression was assessed using SABC immunohistochemistry. Compared with the model group, PMTG treatment (1) significantly reduced serum TC and TG levels (P < 0.01) and increased HDL‑C (P < 0.01); (2) elevated serum nitric oxide (NO) levels and antioxidant capacity (P < 0.05 and P < 0.01, respectively), while lowering malondialdehyde (MDA) (P < 0.01); (3) reduced atherosclerotic plaque area in the aorta (P < 0.05); and (4) downregulated ICAM‑1 and VCAM‑1 expression in the aortic wall. These results suggest that PMTG attenuates atherosclerosis in ApoE⁻/⁻ mice, potentially through lipid‑modulating, antioxidant, and anti‑inflammatory mechanisms involving the suppression of adhesion molecule expression.

human: Hyperammonaemia is a serious metabolic disorder commonly observed in patients with hepatic failure. However, it is unknown whether hyperammonaemia has a direct adverse effect on the hepatocytes and thereby serves as both a cause and effect of hepatic failure.The purposes were to determine whether hepatic injury can be caused by hyperammonaemia, and if so, screen the key genes involved in hyperammonaemia.Hyperammonaemic rats were established via intragastric administration of the ammonium chloride solution. The liver tissues were assessed via biochemistry, histology, immunohistochemistry and microarray analysis. Selected genes were confirmed by quantitative RT-PCR.Administration of the ammonium chloride caused the hyperammonaemia, accompanied with the changes of plasma markers indicating hepatic injury. A pathological assessment demonstrated increased apoptosis and higher level of cyclin D1 and cyclin A in hyperammonaemic rat liver. Microarray was performed on the liver samples and 198 differentially expressed genes were identified in hyperammonaemic rats and validated by quantitative RT-PCR. These genes were associated with many vital functional classes and belonged to different signal transduction pathways.
LLM_1: Hyperammonaemia is a serious metabolic disorder frequently observed in patients with hepatic failure. However, the direct adverse effects of hyperammonaemia on hepatocytes, and its role as both a cause and consequence of hepatic failure, remain unclear. This study aims to determine whether hyperammonaemia can induce hepatic injury and, if so, to identify the key genes involved in this process. Hyperammonaemic rat models were established through intragastric administration of ammonium chloride solution. Liver tissues were evaluated using biochemical assays, histological analysis, immunohistochemistry, and microarray analysis. Selected genes were further validated by quantitative RT-PCR. Administration of ammonium chloride effectively induced hyperammonaemia, which was associated with changes in plasma markers indicative of hepatic injury. Pathological assessments revealed increased apoptosis and elevated levels of cyclin D1 and cyclin A in the livers of hyperammonaemic rats. Microarray analysis of liver samples identified 198 differentially expressed genes in hyperammonaemic rats, which were subsequently validated by quantitative RT-PCR. These genes were linked to various critical functional classes and were involved in multiple signal transduction pathways.
LLM_2: Hyperammonaemia is a serious metabolic disorder commonly observed in patients with hepatic failure. However, the direct adverse effects of hyperammonaemia on hepatocytes, as well as its dual role as both a cause and consequence of hepatic failure, remain poorly understood. This study aimed to investigate whether hyperammonaemia can induce hepatic injury and to identify key genes involved in this process. Hyperammonaemic rat models were established via intragastric administration of ammonium chloride solution. Liver tissues were assessed using biochemical assays, histological analysis, immunohistochemistry, and microarray analysis, with selected genes further validated by quantitative RT-PCR. Ammonium chloride administration effectively induced hyperammonaemia, which correlated with alterations in plasma markers indicative of hepatic injury. Pathological evaluation revealed increased apoptosis and elevated levels of cyclin D1 and cyclin A in the livers of hyperammonaemic rats. Microarray analysis identified 198 differentially expressed genes in hyperammonaemic rats, subsequently validated by quantitative RT-PCR. These genes were associated with critical functional classes and implicated in multiple signal transduction pathways.

---

**Jackasses and Jazz Hands: A Night to Remember at the Musical Marathon**

Ah, jackasses… we all know one. Or perhaps, if we’re being honest, *are* one from time to time.

As you may have heard, today was the much-anticipated musical marathon—a vibrant showcase featuring every volunteer who’s poured their heart into the production. It was a night of passion, pitch-perfect (and not-so-perfect) notes, and yes, a few dramatic behind-the-scenes moments worthy of their own subplot.

Ben and I took the liberty of throwing together a little act—and I’m thrilled to report it was an absolute hit. Cheers, applause, maybe even a standing ovation (okay, maybe not that last part, but a guy can dream). All in all, mission accomplished.

That said, getting there wasn’t exactly smooth sailing. Take, for example, the certain *individual*—we’ll call him Mr. K—who managed to forget the music for our performance… at *Ben’s house*… despite me physically placing it in his hands earlier that day. Classic. Now, I won’t name names (partly because I value my peace and partly because he’ll inevitably read this and leave a passive-aggressive comment), but let’s just say Mr. K continues to keep things interesting. Bless his chaotic soul.

None of this would have mattered, though, without the incredible support from all of you who showed up. To everyone who came out to cheer on your friends, lend energy, and turn an ordinary rehearsal space into something electric—thank you. Your presence made all the stress, the forgotten sheet music, and the last-minute key changes worth it.

Until the next curtain rises…  
Cheerio, my lads!

human: Maladaptive right ventricular (RV) hypertrophic responses lead to RV dysfunction and failure in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension, but the mechanisms responsible for these changes are not well understood. The objective of this study was to evaluate the effect of treatment with bosentan on RV hypertrophy (RVH), fibrosis and expression of protein kinase C (PKC) isoforms in the RV of rats exposed to chronic hypoxia.Adult Sprague-Dawley rats were housed in normoxia or hypoxia (FIO(2) = 10%) and administered vehicle or 100 mg/kg/day bosentan. After 3 weeks, echocardiographic and hemodynamic assessment was performed. PKC, procollagen-1 and collagen expression levels were assessed using immunoblot or colorimetric assay.RV systolic pressure (RVSP) and RVH were higher in hypoxic compared with normoxic animals (RVSP: 72 ± 4 vs 25 ± 2 mm Hg, p < 0.05; RVH: 1.2 ± 0.06 vs 0.5 ± 0.03 mg/g body weight, p < 0.05). Bosentan had no effect on RVSP or mass in normoxic animals, but did attenuate RVH in hypoxic animals (hypoxic/vehicle: 1.2 ± 0.06; hypoxic/bosentan: 1.0 ± 0.05 mg/g body weight; p < 0.05). Hypoxia increased RV procollagen-1, and total collagen expression, effects that were attenuated by bosentan treatment. Hypoxia increased RV total and cytosolic PKC-δ protein expression, but had no effect on PKC-α or -ε isoforms. Administration with bosentan did not affect total PKC-δ protein expression. However, animals treated with bosentan had an increase in membranous PKC-δ when exposed to hypoxia.
LLM_1: Maladaptive right ventricular (RV) hypertrophic responses contribute to RV dysfunction and failure in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension. However, the underlying mechanisms responsible for these alterations remain inadequately understood. This study aimed to evaluate the effects of bosentan treatment on RV hypertrophy (RVH), fibrosis, and the expression of protein kinase C (PKC) isoforms in the RV of rats subjected to chronic hypoxia. Adult Sprague-Dawley rats were maintained in either normoxic or hypoxic conditions (FIO(2) = 10%) and were administered either vehicle or 100 mg/kg/day bosentan. Following a 3-week treatment period, echocardiographic and hemodynamic assessments were conducted. The expression levels of PKC, procollagen-1, and collagen were evaluated using immunoblotting and colorimetric assays. Results indicated that RV systolic pressure (RVSP) and RVH were significantly elevated in hypoxic animals compared to their normoxic counterparts (RVSP: 72 ± 4 vs. 25 ± 2 mm Hg, p < 0.05; RVH: 1.2 ± 0.06 vs. 0.5 ± 0.03 mg/g body weight, p < 0.05). While bosentan did not influence RVSP or mass in normoxic animals, it significantly mitigated RVH in hypoxic animals (hypoxic/vehicle: 1.2 ± 0.06; hypoxic/bosentan: 1.0 ± 0.05 mg/g body weight; p < 0.05). Hypoxia was found to increase RV procollagen-1 and total collagen expression, effects that were alleviated by bosentan treatment. Furthermore, hypoxia enhanced both total and cytosolic PKC-δ protein expression, with no significant changes observed in PKC-α or -ε isoforms. Although bosentan administration did not alter total PKC-δ protein expression, it was associated with an increase in membranous PKC-δ in hypoxic-treated animals.
LLM_2: Maladaptive right ventricular (RV) hypertrophic responses contribute to RV dysfunction and failure in pulmonary arterial hypertension, though the underlying mechanisms remain incompletely understood. This study investigated the effects of bosentan treatment on RV hypertrophy (RVH), fibrosis, and protein kinase C (PKC) isoform expression in rats exposed to chronic hypoxia. Adult Sprague-Dawley rats were maintained under normoxic or hypoxic conditions (FIO₂ = 10%) and administered either vehicle or bosentan (100 mg/kg/day). After three weeks, echocardiographic and hemodynamic assessments were performed. Protein expression of PKC isoforms, procollagen-1, and collagen was evaluated via immunoblotting and colorimetric assays. Results demonstrated that hypoxia significantly increased RV systolic pressure (RVSP) and RVH compared to normoxic controls (RVSP: 72 ± 4 vs. 25 ± 2 mm Hg, p < 0.05; RVH: 1.2 ± 0.06 vs. 0.5 ± 0.03 mg/g body weight, p < 0.05). Bosentan did not affect RVSP or mass in normoxic animals but significantly attenuated RVH in hypoxic animals (hypoxic/vehicle: 1.2 ± 0.06; hypoxic/bosentan: 1.0 ± 0.05 mg/g body weight; p < 0.05). Hypoxia-induced increases in RV procollagen-1 and total collagen expression were also reduced by bosentan. Additionally, hypoxia enhanced total and cytosolic PKC-δ protein expression, with no significant changes in PKC-α or PKC-ε. While bosentan did not alter total PKC-δ expression, it was associated with increased membranous PKC-δ in hypoxic-treated animals. These findings suggest that bosentan ameliorates hypoxia-induced RVH and fibrosis, potentially through modulation of PKC-δ subcellular localization.

**What If the BMV Was Actually Fun?**

Imagine this: going to the BMV and *actually* looking forward to it. Picture walking into a place that feels less like a government office and more like Dr. Jones’s orthodontist—complete with an arcade, a legit snack bar (or at least vending machines worth their salt), public internet stations, and a play area for kids. Instead of groaning, “Ugh, I have to go back to the BMV,” we’d be saying, “Yes! We get to go back! I’m so excited!”

Seriously—does some obscure bureaucratic rulebook mandate that all motor vehicle departments must be soul-crushingly dull? Because if so, I’d like to see a waiver form.

Everyone dreads the BMV. But making it even slightly more pleasant wouldn’t take a miracle—just a little imagination and basic human empathy. A comfortable chair. Natural light. Maybe a decent playlist. Is that too much to ask?

Anyway, full disclosure: I just got my learner’s permit today. That was literally the only thing I accomplished—but it took me about six hours from start to finish. Six. Hours. For a piece of paper.

After surviving the ordeal, we spent some time driving around the parking lot. Let me tell you, driving is *not* as easy as it looks when someone else is doing it. Turns out, steering, braking, checking mirrors, and not panicking simultaneously requires actual skill. Who knew?

On the drive home, we listened to a tribute special on Ray Charles—and his version of “Imagine” stopped me in my tracks:  
*"Imagine all the people (all the little people) living… living their whole lives… just for today…"*  
Chills. What a once-in-a-lifetime artist.

That’s about it for now. Oh—but Michael, could you send me the link to your *West Wing* script archive? I’m feeling lazy and nostalgic. Much appreciated!

And Mario… yeah, sorry, but your princess is in another Chinese restaurant.

---

These instruments aggregate cash flows from various mortgages and other debt obligations into a single pool, from which specific securities are issued in a predetermined order of priority. LLM_2:
# How Complex Financial Instruments Fueled the Housing Bubble

**Collateralized debt obligations (CDOs)** emerged as a key mechanism that enabled financial institutions to channel investor funds into financing subprime and other high-risk loans. This process not only helped inflate the housing bubble but also generated significant fees for the institutions involved.

At their core, CDOs work by bundling cash flows from a wide array of mortgages and other debts into a single pooled investment. From this pool, securities are issued in a structured sequence of priority. Those securities in the top tiers—considered the safest—typically received investment-grade ratings from major credit agencies.

Meanwhile, lower-priority tranches carried higher risk and lower credit ratings, but they promised investors the possibility of greater returns. This layered risk-and-reward structure attracted a broad spectrum of investors, ultimately amplifying the flow of capital into the mortgage market and contributing to the run-up in housing prices before the 2008 financial crisis.

Subset analyses after stratifying by Masaoka stage and WHO cell type demonstrated that the 10-year disease-specific survival rate for patients without postoperative radiation therapy with Masaoka stage I and II, as well as those with WHO cell types A, AB, or B1, was 100%, which was satisfactory. LLM_1: Postoperative radiation therapy for thymoma is commonly employed, although its clinical benefits remain a topic of debate. To the authors' knowledge, the relationship between postoperative radiation therapy and cell types classified by the World Health Organization (WHO) has not been previously established. The records of 324 patients (ages 17-83 years; mean age, 51 years; 160 males and 164 females) who underwent complete resection of a thymoma between 1970 and 2005 were reviewed. Mediastinal postoperative radiation therapy was administered to 134 patients. Survival rates and recurrence patterns were analyzed based on Masaoka stage and WHO cell type. The 10-year disease-specific survival rates for patients with and without postoperative radiation therapy were 92.8% and 94.4%, respectively (P = .22). Further analyses stratified by Masaoka stage and WHO cell type revealed that the 10-year disease-specific survival rate for patients without postoperative radiation therapy with Masaoka stage I and II, as well as those with WHO cell types A, AB, or B1, was 100%, indicating a favorable outcome. Additionally, the survival rates for patients with Masaoka stage III/IV and those with WHO cell types B2/B3 did not differ significantly, regardless of postoperative radiation therapy. Among the 24 patients with disease recurrence, pleural dissemination was the most frequently observed pattern, followed by distant metastases; local recurrence without other involvement occurred in 2 patients.
LLM_2:
---

**Abstract**

Postoperative radiation therapy (PORT) is commonly administered in the management of thymoma, yet its clinical benefit remains controversial. To the authors’ knowledge, the association between PORT and World Health Organization (WHO) histologic classification has not been systematically evaluated. This study retrospectively reviewed the records of 324 patients (160 male, 164 female; age range: 17–83 years; mean age: 51 years) who underwent complete resection of thymoma between 1970 and 2005. Of these, 134 patients received mediastinal PORT. Survival outcomes and recurrence patterns were analyzed according to Masaoka stage and WHO histologic subtype. The 10-year disease-specific survival rates for patients receiving and not receiving PORT were 92.8% and 94.4%, respectively (*P* = 0.22). Stratified analysis by Masaoka stage and WHO type demonstrated that patients with stage I or II disease and those with WHO types A, AB, or B1 exhibited 100% 10-year survival without PORT, suggesting excellent prognosis in these subgroups. No significant survival difference was observed in patients with Masaoka stage III/IV disease or WHO types B2/B3, regardless of PORT administration. Among the 24 patients who experienced recurrence, pleural dissemination was the most common pattern, followed by distant metastases; isolated local recurrence occurred in only two cases.

---

# U.S. Recession Officially Ended in June 2009, Marking End of Financial Crisis

**WASHINGTON** — The United States’ most severe economic downturn in decades, which began in December 2007, officially came to an end in June 2009, according to a determination by the National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER). The announcement caps a period of intense financial turmoil that reshaped the global economy and triggered unprecedented government intervention.

The recession’s conclusion coincided with the gradual easing of the broader financial crisis. By April 2009, *TIME* magazine had declared, “The Banking Crisis Is Over, More Quickly Than It Began,” signaling a turning point in market confidence. The U.S. Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission later pinpointed 2008 as the critical year when the crisis reached its peak.

In a statement on January 27, 2010, President Barack Obama pointed to significant progress in stabilizing the economy. “The markets are now stabilized,” he said, “and we’ve recovered most of the money we spent on the banks.” His remarks underscored a cautious optimism as the nation began its path toward recovery.

---

**Four years ago, it began.**

At first, I ignored the sound—a faint *tap-tap* against glass—nothing more than a rogue branch tapping at the pane, or so I told myself. A trick of the wind. A figment of fatigue. I didn’t investigate. Not then.

Not until the morning after the blackout, when I woke with a skull full of nails and my stomach twisting like wet rope. I staggered into the bathroom, bile rising in my throat, and as I knelt before the porcelain altar of my own undoing, the knocking came again—louder this time. Sharper. Deliberate.

I blamed it on the spiral—the one I’d been tumbling down since she died. Since the world went quiet and hollow, like a house emptied of its soul. Nothing had felt real since. But this… this was different. The knock echoed not from beyond the window, but from *within* the room. From the mirror.

Curiosity flickered—cold and insistent. I dragged in a breath, wiped my mouth, and lifted my head. The reflection staring back wasn’t mine. Or rather, it was—but warped. Gaunt cheeks. Sunken eyes. A man half-drowned in grief and gin. And yet… he looked *awake*. Aware. As if he knew something I didn’t.

I stumbled back. My pulse hammered in my throat. Our eyes locked—mine wide with fear, his gleaming with something darker. Before he could speak—if he even opened his mouth—I fled. Left the bathroom door swinging behind me like a wound left open.

For days, I avoided mirrors altogether. I let my beard grow wild. Brushed my teeth in the dark. Drank from plastic cups so I wouldn’t catch my silhouette in the sink. But every night, the knocking returned: *knock, knock, knock*. Three measured raps, like a visitor waiting at a door only I could hear.

And sometimes—worse—there was the scrape. The slow, grating drag of fingernails across slate. I squeezed my eyes shut, prayed for it to be the pipes, the floor settling, anything but *him*. But denial wears thin when the nightmare keeps perfect time.

By week’s end, I started inventing reasons to stay away. Late meetings. Drinks with friends who barely knew me. I drank until the world blurred, until I couldn’t tell where reality ended and delirium began. Still, I always came back.

Because fear, after a while, curdles into curiosity. And curiosity becomes a kind of hunger.

So I resolved to face it. To stand before the mirror and prove—to myself, to Wolf—that it had all been a fever dream. A ghost conjured by grief and cheap whiskey.

When I stepped through the front door that evening, an unnatural chill seized me. Outside, New York sweltered under a late August sun—nearly thirty degrees, the air thick as tar. But inside? Ice. My breath fogged. Gooseflesh rose along my arms, my neck, as if unseen fingers had trailed over my skin.

*"Don’t feed the fire, Nick,"* I whispered. *"There’s nothing here."*

But the voice that answered wasn’t mine.

*"How can you be so sure?"*

Ah, Wolf.

We’ve always shared this skull, him and I. Wolfgang—the name I gave him long ago, when the voices first tangled in my mind. He never shuts up. Never lets me forget. We bicker like old lovers, two halves of a broken whole: Nicholas, trying to hold on; Wolf, daring me to let go.

*"I don’t know for sure,"* I said aloud, shrugging off my coat, hanging it on the rack with careful precision, *"but I know whatever you think is in here… can’t get out. And there’s nothing here. Chill out."*

Wolf laughed—a dry rustle in the back of my mind.

*"You keep saying that. But you’re still trembling."*

I stepped forward, breath shallow. The house held its silence like a secret.

*"Whatever you think might happen,"* Wolf murmured, almost gentle now, *"definitely isn’t going to happen. Not tonight. You’re safe."*

I didn’t believe him. Not entirely. But he’s usually right. When I saw her ghost—my wife, standing in the hallway in her blue dress, humming that old jazz tune—I would’ve screamed, collapsed, maybe ended it all. But Wolf stayed calm. Guided me through. Told me to breathe. To wait. To watch.

Sometimes, he’s the reason I’m still alive.

Other times… he’s the reason I’m not.

*"Why wouldn’t it happen now?"* I asked, stepping deeper into the living room.

The space felt heavier. Older. As if the walls remembered.

Above the couch, the wall was bare. A pale rectangle in the dust marked where the mirror used to hang. I’d taken it down the morning after the knocking started. After I saw *him*.

But I knew—deep in the marrow—that tearing down one mirror wouldn’t stop what was already awake.

It wasn’t about reflections anymore.

It was about who was watching from the other side.

And whether he was trying to get in…

…or I was already letting him out.

---

LLM_2:
# Olympic Torch Relay Kicks Off in Hong Kong with Historic Flair

**HONG KONG** — The 2008 Olympic torch relay commenced in Hong Kong on Friday, May 2, in a ceremony blending tradition, spectacle, and patriotic display. The event began at the Hong Kong Cultural Centre in Tsim Sha Tsui, where Chief Executive Donald Tsang handed the flame to local Olympic windsurfing medalist Lee Lai Shan.

The relay route showcased Hong Kong’s iconic landmarks and inventive spirit. Bearers carried the torch along bustling Nathan Road, across the Lantau Link, and—in a first for Olympic relay history—over the Shing Mun River by dragon boat. Later, the flame crossed Victoria Harbour aboard the *Tin Hau*, a government marine vessel, before reaching its final destination at Golden Bauhinia Square in Wan Chai.

A total of 120 torchbearers participated, featuring celebrities, athletes, and political figures aligned with pro-Beijing circles. No representatives from the city’s pro-democracy camp took part. One scheduled bearer missed the event due to a flight delay.

Crowds estimated at over 200,000 lined the streets, many dressed in red and waving large Chinese national flags. To ensure safety and order, Chief Secretary for Administration Henry Tang confirmed that 3,000 police officers were deployed throughout the relay.

The Hong Kong leg, marked by its unique aquatic segments and enthusiastic public turnout, served as a vivid prelude to the torch’s ongoing journey toward Beijing.

Kenny MacAskill is pushing ahead with plans for single police and fire services instead of regional bodies.
The UK government argued the single services would not be eligible for VAT refunds, worth more than £30m a year.
Mr MacAskill said the policy was in contrast to Westminster's treatment of Academy schools in England.
He said the rules for the government-funded schools were changed to allow VAT to be reclaimed.
Under Section 33 of the VAT Act 1994, local authorities can recover the VAT they pay for supplies, which relate to their non-business activities.
A letter from Mr MacAskill said he had not received any formal reasons for the UK Treasury decision not to allow the new Scottish Police Authority to reclaim VAT but he understood it was because it would be "funded by central government".
Mr MacAskill said the decision would mean the police and fire services in Scotland would be the only ones in the UK unable to recover VAT.
He said: "This decision by the Treasury is unacceptable, unjustifiable and manifestly unfair. This charge on Scottish public sector reform is not levied on similar reforms in the rest of the UK."
Mr MacAskill said the UK government had changed the rules on VAT for Academy schools - which are entirely funded by central government.
He added: "It also ignores the fact that the new Police Authority will continue to be able to receive funding from Scottish local authorities to pay the costs of agreed local priorities.
"This provides a direct link with local taxation, which we consider meets the Treasury's policy on VAT recovery."
The Police and Fire Reform Bill reaches Stage 3 in the Scottish Parliament this week and the new single services are scheduled to begin in April 2013.
The Treasury insists that the Scottish government knew all along that their model for service reform would lead to the loss of VAT exemption.
Public sector union Unison claimed the ending of the exemption would cost the police £26m a year and the new national fire service between £4m and £10m.
A union spokesman said: "It appears that Scotland's public services are going to have to pay a high price for allowing greater ministerial control of our police and fire services."

LLM_1:
It’s been a while since I last blogged, and I’ve been meaning to dive into some serious topics. However, I’ll save those thoughts for after my summer class wraps up. In this case, I believe professional knowledge will serve me better than my past experiences. For now, I’m simply enjoying the changes happening around me. It feels as though I’ve been transported to India, with temperatures soaring to 99°F in this scorching heat. But the silver lining is the stunning flowers and plants blooming everywhere, adding a touch of beauty to the summer.

Recently, I attended the Mormontrek Heritage Festival. While it wasn’t the most exciting event, it did have its interesting moments. For those who aren’t familiar, Mormons were among the first European settlers, traveling in handcarts to establish communities across the United States. Last week was quite busy for me, juggling classes and working at the International Center. One of the summer clinic activities involved introducing ourselves to the class in a unique and amusing way. Each student shared something about themselves and presented three cherished artifacts. I found it funny because revealing three items hardly scratches the surface of someone’s personality.

Nevertheless, everyone brought their items to class. I noticed that about 80-90% of my classmates showcased pictures of their loved ones, memorabilia related to sports, their favorite books, or T-shirts representing their schools or workplaces. It seemed like everyone shared similar interests. I, too, wanted to stand out, as that’s always my goal. I’m not a big fan of cricket or any ball games, and I don’t have a family of my own. While I would love to show pictures of my parents and siblings, I didn’t have any. So, I pondered what I could bring to share.

Then I remembered the straw hat given to me by a girl from Mizoram during my visit to Delhi. We became close friends, and on my last day there, she left me the hat as a keepsake. I’ve carried it with me across the U.S., and although I don’t wear it often, it holds sentimental value. I also packed my diary, which is quite old but significant to me. It captures my fears, exciting moments, and important reflections throughout my life, offering a glimpse into my experiences over time.

Additionally, I have a habit of collecting unique flowers and leaves from different places. I managed to press some of them and keep them in my book, so I decided to take those along as well. Lastly, I included a T-shirt I received for tutoring undergraduate psychology students. So here I was, armed with more than three artifacts to share with the class. I tried my best to be unique in my presentation. But did I truly convey who I am? Not at all. I am much more than what I displayed. 

It struck me that everyone likely has more depth than what their artifacts reveal. While these items do represent something about them, they certainly don’t portray the complete picture. I find myself puzzled about why I care so much about understanding each person’s true identity. It’s curious to think about why we all seem to have similar thoughts or, conversely, why we differ so much. This could lead me down a rabbit hole of discussing cultural diversity and related topics. It’s late now, so I’ll wrap it up here.
LLM_2:
**A Summer of Self-Discovery: Moments from the Journey**

It's been far too long since my pen last touched this blog, leaving me with a longing to delve into the depths of meaningful conversations. Yet, for now I'm choosing to savor the present, allowing the vibrant energy of summer to guide my thoughts. As I immerse myself in the warmth of this Indian summer, where temperatures soar to sweltering highs of 39°C, my senses come alive. Amidst the scalding sun, an explosion of colors and scents unfolds – a kaleidoscope of flowers, bloomed in every corner, painting the landscape with their beauty.

My recent excursion to attend the historic Mormantrek (or rather) Heritage festival was a thought-provoking experience. A journey through time, this event transported me to an era when the early European Mormon settlers first arrived in America, traversing the country in carts. Though not the grand spectacle I had envisioned, each moment was infused with its own unique charm. My days have been filled with classes at my university, coupled with my work at The International Centre. Among the numerous activities I've participated in, one particular event stands out – the introduction of ourselves in an innovative and entertaining manner.

Each student brought forth three treasured possessions that showcased a piece of themselves. Upon witnessing this, a reflection struck – how little these objects truly reveal about a person's identity, despite their significance. Some 70-80% or so of our classmates proudly displayed cherished photographs of loved-ones, sports memorials, favorite novels, T-Shirts symbolizing their alma maters, schools, workplaces, etc. – it was almost as if we shared a common thread. Feeling a little out of sync, given my lack of affinity for cricket and my family ties being distant, at first I thought I'd struggle to find something unique to contribute.

However, memories from a trip to Mumbai, India resurfaced, reminding me of a straw sun hat gifted to by an acquaintance from Mizo, during a visit in Delhi, that held immense sentimental worth. Additionally, there's the journal, now a bit worn but still valuable – an accumulation of reflections, fears and exhilarating experiences from my journey, providing a candid glimpse of who and what shaped me over the years. Furthermore, throughout the places I travel, collecting unusual flowers is a cherished pastime – I even have some pressed between the pages of an old book. And lastly, another memento that stood out to bring along – my t-shirt, received as an award for the tutoring work I did for undergraduate students.

Here I stood, clutching more items than the three requested. Still, in trying to express my unique qualities, did my heart truly shine through? The answer, no – there was still more to explore about me beyond what was on display. Then it hit me – everyone might have hidden depths that their chosen artifacts couldn't reveal, not even a fragment of it. Why should I be so intrigued about the intricacies of human identity? And it’s not just about differences; perhaps our shared thoughts and distinct experiences all blend together. That, perhaps, is why the discussion on cultural differences is so complex and so enticing. Well, time for this summer reflection to come to rest. Let's meet again. (Note that I used the convention of Indian naming for Mizorama and the temperature was converted to Celsius for better readability).

SAA did not correlate with performance on tests of working memory.
LLM_1: This study investigated the relationship between age-related declines in basic cognitive resources, specifically information-processing speed and working memory, and the use of anticholinergic medications, as measured by serum anticholinergic activity (SAA). Additionally, it explored whether the impact of these cognitive decrements could be mitigated by caffeine consumption. Conducted as a cross-sectional observational study at a university medical center, the research involved 152 normal elderly community volunteers. Participants underwent two assessments each of information-processing speed and working memory, and blood samples were collected before and after cognitive testing to measure serum levels of anticholinergic activity and paraxanthine, a caffeine metabolite. The findings revealed that elevated SAA was associated with a significant yet modest increase in information-processing time, particularly in individuals with low serum paraxanthine levels. However, no correlation was found between SAA and performance on working memory tests.
LLM_2:
This investigation examined the association between the age-graded diminution of basic cognitives resources - specifically, information processing speed, working, memory - and antiholinergics drug use, quantified by measurements of serum (anticholinerigc activity, or SAAA). Moreover, this study explored the potential mitigating effect of caffeine ingestion on the cognitive decrement. In a retrospective observational design conducted at an academic medical centre, 162 normal ageing community participants were recruited. These volunteers underwent paired assessments of their information-processsing speed as well as working-memory capacity, with blood sampling performed prior to and following cognitive evaluation to determine serum concentrations of SAAAA and, paroxanthin, its metabolites of a caffein. 

The findings demonstrated that Saaa was significantly correlated with an increase, albeit modest, in the time required for information processsing, especially in subjects with relatively low paraxonathine serum values. Conversely, there was no observed association, between serum Saa and cognitive performance in working memorandum. & nbsp; 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; **The Fire** 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; The kitchen stove is on fire, but I ca n't put it out. I can hardly see it from where I lay – everything is milky and blurred – but I can make out the orange embers glowing above the stovetop. It's all I can discern in the darkness of this room, that orange light, but I ca n't get up to put it out. 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; I do n't know why I'm lying here, or why my arms and legs refuse to move. I must have tripped and cracked my head on the tile – I'm paralysed. I extend my arms in front of me, but my arms remain at my sides. I will my legs to stand, the way I've stood a million times before, but nothing happens. I ca n't even turn my head. I yell at my limbs to function, but I ca n't speak, and my body wo n't listen. 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; The stovetop glows orange and red. I can still fix this. I swear there's a fire extinguisher underneath the sink, I swear I've seen it there. The fire is small – it barely reaches above the burners – and I could snuff it now without triggering the fire alarm. I could put it out without calling the fire trucks and the firemen, without the embarrassment of standing outside in the street, draped in blankets as the neighborhood watches smoke billow from my home. I could stop it before I have to pay to repair the kitchen, before it burns down the range and the hood and my countertops. 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; I hear crying from the other room. Oh God, Xavier sees it too. I remember that I left him in his playpen beside the open door. His cries sound distorted, as though the sounds must pierce through thick fog to reach my ears, but I hear him and he's afraid. I jerk the muscles at the base of my spine; I order them to hoist me up, to put out the fire and save my son. But nothing happens. The stovetop glows orange and red. 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; Xavier's wails fill my ears. I beg my body to move, and in my frustration I want to cry. The embers must be dancing across the burners now. They'll flick themselves onto the countertop where they'll catch on the spice rack and spread into the cabinets. They'll engulf the wall and fan out into the doorway, and they'll carry themselves into Xavier's room. 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; He's so small that the smoke wo n't asphyxiate him, no. The fire will creep toward him along the doorframe; the smoke will rise up and cover the ceiling. He'll cry and shriek and press himself frantically against a corner of his playpen farthest from the flames. The ash and smoke will descend on him like a veil; the fire will catch onto a nylon wall of his playpen and in a flash he'll scream. The fire will melt his onesie into his skin and enter his mouth and scorch his throat and eat his lungs and none of this will happen if I could just fucking MOVE. 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; *Get up! * 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; God, please, help us. I do n't want to be a terrible father. I do n't want Ruth to come home to police tape and to see black corpses, unidentifiable and twisted into gnarled husks by flames. I can still fix this, I swear I can, but I ca n't even turn my head. The stovetop glows orange and red. 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; *Get up! * 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; To my right, I spot it. My eyes can move, ever so slightly, and in the milky haze of my peripheral vision, I see it and my heart stops beating. A foot away, beside me, a light glows orange and red. The fire has spread. Xavier is still crying. 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; *Get up, Peter! * 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; A shadow moves across my vision. The living room light turns on above me and casts away the darkness. My shoulder shakes. 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; “ Peter, get up. Now! ” 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; I sit upright on the couch and blink away the haze from my eyes. Bewildered, I turn to my right and look up at my wife. 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; “ Peter, ” Ruth says, “ I asked you to clean the dishes while I went out, and you promised that you would, but you haven't. ” She leans over and turns off the lamp on the table beside the couch. She sits down next to me and smiles. 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; “ You even fell asleep with the stove light on, you silly man, ” 
 she says. “ Peter, you know that if you lie down after you eat, you wo n't get up. ”

The kitchen stove blazes, yet I find myself powerless to extinguish it. From my prone position, the scene is a blur, the details wrapped in a milky haze, but I can just make out the flickering orange embers dancing above the burners. That glow is my solitary beacon in the oppressive darkness surrounding me, but my body refuses to respond.

Panic tightens its grip around me as I grapple with the confusion of why I lie here, immobilized. Perhaps I stumbled and struck my head against the unforgiving tile—whatever the reason, I feel paralyzed. I strain to extend my arms, yet they remain stubbornly at my sides. I summon the strength to rise, as I’ve done countless times before, but my legs betray me. Even turning my head feels like an impossible task. I want to scream at my limbs to obey, but my voice is trapped within me, silenced.

The stove flickers with a fierce orange and red glow. I still have a chance to salvage this. I can almost picture the fire extinguisher beneath the sink; I know I've seen it there before. The fire is small, barely licking above the surface of the burners, and I could snuff it out without triggering alarms. I could extinguish it, avoiding the embarrassment of fire trucks and neighbors watching me, wrapped in blankets as smoke pours from my home. I could save my kitchen from the devastation of flames, preserving my range, hood, and countertops.

Suddenly, I hear cries from the adjacent room. Oh God, Xavier sees it too. I remember leaving him in his playpen next to the open door. His wails seem distorted, muffled as if they must cut through thick fog to reach my ears, but I hear him; he’s terrified. I attempt to command my muscles to lift me, to extinguish the flames and protect my son, yet nothing happens. The stovetop continues to glow ominously.

Xavier's cries echo in my ears, and frustration wells up within me, threatening to spill over into tears. The embers must be leaping across the burners now, ready to ignite the spice rack and spread into the cabinets. The flames will consume the wall, spill into the doorway, and creep toward Xavier’s room.

He’s so small that the smoke won’t suffocate him, not yet. But the fire will inch toward him, along the doorframe; the smoke will rise and blanket the ceiling. He’ll cry out in fear, pressed against the far corner of his playpen, desperate to escape the flames. Ash and smoke will envelop him, and the fire will catch onto the nylon fabric of his playpen. In an instant, he’ll scream as the flames melt his onesie into his skin, invade his mouth, scorch his throat, and consume his lungs. None of this has to happen if I could just move.

*Get up!*

Oh God, please help us. I don’t want to be a terrible father. I can’t bear the thought of Ruth coming home to find police tape and the charred remains of our lives, twisted into unrecognizable shapes by the fire. I can still fix this, I know I can, but I can’t even turn my head. The stovetop glows a fierce orange and red.

*Get up!*

Then, in the corner of my eye, I spot it. My gaze can shift, just a fraction, and through the milky blur of my vision, I see it, and my heart drops. Mere feet away from me, a light flickers orange and red. The fire has spread. Xavier is still crying.

*Get up, Peter!*

A shadow flits across my vision. The living room light flickers to life above me, casting away the darkness. My shoulder shakes.

“Peter, get up. Now!”

With a jolt, I sit upright on the couch, blinking away the haze clouding my vision. Confused, I turn to my right and look up at my wife.

“Peter,” Ruth says, her voice a mix of concern and annoyance, “I asked you to clean the dishes while I was out, and you promised you would, but you haven’t.” She leans over and switches off the lamp on the table beside the couch before settling down next to me, a smile breaking across her face.

“You even fell asleep with the stove light on, you silly man,” she says, her tone playful. “Peter, you know that if you lie down after eating, you won’t get up.”
LLM_2:
The flicker of orange flames danced before me like a taunting specter, mocking my helplessness. As I lay prone, my gaze struggled to pierce the veil of milking haze that shrouded the kitchen, rendering the world around a disjointed blur. Yet, even in this state of paralysis, one beacon of hope remained: the fiery glow of emblazoned emblems above my stove, an otherworldly siren calling me to salvation. 

Fear's icy grip constricted around my chest as panic wrestled its way to dominance. How had I ended up in such a predicament? Perhaps the careless stumble against tile had triggered this descent into chaos, or maybe something else was at play. Whatever the cause, it was clear that my physical form had betrayed me.

With every strained effort, limbs that should have responded to every command remained stubborn, refusing to budge. Rising, something I'd done a thousand times, now felt like scaling an insurmountable mountain. Every movement – the simple act of turning towards my child – seemed an Herculean feat. Trapped within my silent scream, frustration boiled over, begging my recalcitrant limbs for the impossible.

Through the swirling chaos of smoke and fire, images of rescue flickered before my eyes. Snatching the extinguishing agent, its reassuring shape beckoned me towards safety. This was my chance, before flames could engulf everything – kitchen counters, stove range and hood – leaving nothing but ashes behind.

Then I heard it – a mangled cry from next door, torn from Xavier's fragile form. Ruth had left him by our open doorway. Fears twisted themselves into knots as reality dawned – I had to save him. With each surge of adrenaline, muscles that refused to move now strained to break free. Nothing happened. Flames danced closer to our kitchen cabinets, then the emigration towards Xavier began.

Cries pierced the fog in me – my only hope. Then I remembered – he was too small to suffocation, for now. Smoke would soon engulf him and ash would smother him – but fire would inch closer. It would lick the doorknob, spew flames into our living space, until he would be trapped. No, this could not happen. Not with my life. *Get Up!* 

Oh, God help me! How could I be so powerless? Ruth would return to char and chaos. Police tape would wrap our home in an inescapable shroud, forever silencing our laughter. All this I couldn't bear. If I just could... *Rise!* The stove glowed like hell's mouth.

A fraction of a second of clarity – and there it stood – mere feet from where my face lay. A light – orange, red – glinted, sizzling as our world disintegrated. And I saw it: Xavier, still wailing.

*Rise, Get Up, Now!* A flick of darkness – light. Our living-room lamp burst forth, banishing shadows. "Peter," Ruth said softly, concern mixed with annoyance. She leaned in, switched off our table lamp, settling beside me with an unwavering smile.

"You promised to do the chores, fell fast asleep – with stove still on." A playful smile adorned her lips. Her voice pierced through my disorientation. Slowly, confusion dissipated. What had happened?

human: Anastomotic leakage remains a frequent and serious complication in gastrointestinal surgery. In order to reduce its incidence, several clinical and experimental studies on anastomotic sealing have been performed. In a number of these studies, the sealing material has been fibrin glue (FG), and the results in individual studies have been varying. The positive effect of anastomotic sealing with FG might be due to the mechanical/physical properties, the increased healing of the anastomoses or both. The aim of this systematic review was to evaluate the existing evidence on the healing effects of FG on gastrointestinal anastomoses.PubMed, EMBASE and the Cochrane databases were searched for studies evaluating the healing process of gastrointestinal anastomoses after any kind of FG application. The search period was from 1953 to December 2013.Twenty-eight studies were included in the qualitative synthesis. These studies were all experimental studies, since no human studies used histological or biochemical evaluation of healing. In 7 of the 28 studies, a positive effect of FG on healing was found, while 8 studies reported a negative effect and 11 studies found no effect. Furthermore, 2 studies reported unclear results. The difference in the study outcome was independent of the study design and the type of FG used.
LLM_1: Anastomotic leakage is a common and significant complication in gastrointestinal surgery. To mitigate its occurrence, various clinical and experimental investigations into anastomotic sealing have been conducted. Fibrin glue (FG) has been utilized as the sealing material in several of these studies, yielding inconsistent results. The beneficial impact of FG on anastomotic healing may stem from its mechanical and physical properties, enhanced healing processes, or a combination of both. This systematic review aims to assess the current evidence regarding the healing effects of FG on gastrointestinal anastomoses. A comprehensive search of the PubMed, EMBASE, and Cochrane databases was conducted for studies examining the healing process of gastrointestinal anastomoses following FG application, spanning from 1953 to December 2013. Twenty-eight studies were included in the qualitative synthesis, all of which were experimental in nature, as no human studies employed histological or biochemical assessments of healing. Among the included studies, seven demonstrated a positive effect of FG on healing, while eight reported a negative effect, and eleven indicated no effect. Additionally, two studies yielded inconclusive results. The variability in outcomes was not influenced by the study design or the specific type of FG employed.
LLM_2:
**Abstract**

Anastomotic leakage represents a frequent and clinically consequential complication following gastrointestinal surgery. In efforts to reduce its incidence, diverse clinical and experimental approaches to anastomotic sealing have been explored. Fibrin glue (FG) has been employed as a sealing agent in a number of these investigations, though reported outcomes have been inconsistent. The potential therapeutic benefit of FG in anastomotic repair may derive from its mechanical sealing capacity, its influence on biological healing pathways, or an interplay of both mechanisms. This systematic review evaluates existing evidence pertaining to the effects of FG on the healing of gastrointestinal anastomoses. A thorough literature search was performed across PubMed, EMBASE, and Cochrane databases for studies investigating healing outcomes after FG application in gastrointestinal anastomoses, covering publications from 1953 through December 2013. Twenty-eight experimental studies met inclusion criteria for qualitative synthesis; no human studies utilizing histological or biochemical healing assessments were identified. Of these, seven studies reported a positive effect of FG on healing, eight indicated a negative effect, and eleven found no significant effect. Two further studies yielded equivocal results. Outcome variability appeared independent of study design or the specific formulation of FG used.
