This is an interesting policy-as-inference approach, presented in a reasonably clear and well-motivated way. I have a couple questions which somewhat echo questions of other commenters here. Unfortunately, I am not sufficiently familiar with the relevant recent policy learning literature to judge novelty. However, as best I am aware the empirical results presented here seem quite impressive for off-policy learning.

- When is it possible to normalize the non-parametric q(a|s) in equation (6)? It seems to me this will be challenging in most any situation where the action space is continuous. Is this guaranteed to be Gaussian? If so, I don’t understand why.

– In equations (5) and (10), a KL divergence regularizer is replaced by a “hard” constraint. However, for optimization purposes, in C.3 the hard constraint is then replaced by a soft constraint (with Lagrange multipliers), which depend on values of epsilon. Are these values of epsilon easy to pick in practice? If so, why are they easier to pick than e.g. the lambda value in eq (10)?
LLM_1:
This policy-as-inference approach presents an intriguing concept, articulated with reasonable clarity and sound motivation. I have a few questions that resonate with those raised by other reviewers. Regrettably, my familiarity with the recent literature on policy learning is limited, making it difficult for me to assess the novelty of the work. However, the empirical results showcased appear to be quite impressive for off-policy learning.

- Under what circumstances can the non-parametric q(a|s) in equation (6) be normalized? It seems that achieving this normalization would be quite challenging, particularly when dealing with a continuous action space. Is it guaranteed to follow a Gaussian distribution? If so, I am unclear on the reasoning behind this.

- In equations (5) and (10), the KL divergence regularizer is substituted with a "hard" constraint. However, for optimization purposes, this hard constraint is later replaced by a soft constraint (utilizing Lagrange multipliers) in section C.3, which relies on the values of epsilon. Are these epsilon values straightforward to determine in practice? If they are indeed easier to select than the lambda value in equation (10), could you clarify why that is the case?
LLM_2:
---

The policy-as-inference framework proposed in this work is conceptually interesting and well-motivated, presented with generally clear exposition. My concerns largely align with those noted by other reviewers. While I find the empirical results—particularly in the context of off-policy learning—to be quite compelling, my ability to evaluate the paper’s novelty is somewhat limited by my familiarity with recent advances in policy learning literature.

I have a few technical questions that require clarification:

- In Equation (6), the non-parametric form of $ q(a|s) $ is introduced without explicit discussion of normalization. Could the authors clarify under what conditions this distribution remains normalizable—especially in continuous action spaces? Additionally, if the resulting $ q(a|s) $ is assumed or enforced to follow a Gaussian structure, what is the theoretical or practical justification for such an assumption?

- Equations (5) and (10) employ a hard constraint in place of the standard KL divergence regularizer. This is later relaxed into a soft constraint via Lagrange multipliers in Section C.3, parameterized by $ \epsilon $. In practice, how sensitive is the optimization process to the choice of $ \epsilon $? Furthermore, if selecting $ \epsilon $ proves more intuitive or robust than tuning the $ \lambda $ parameter in Equation (10), it would be helpful to understand why this might be the case.

--- 

This version improves precision, maintains a respectful and constructive tone, and structures the feedback in a way typical of peer-review comments.

human: Fetal alloimmune anemia is associated with increased blood flow velocities and cardiomegaly. In severe cases, hydrops can develop. We investigated whether the decrease of red blood cell volume is associated with a reduction or expansion of plasma volume.In 86 alloimmunized fetuses that received a first intrauterine transfusion, we calculated fetal total blood volumes (i.e. fetoplacental blood volumes) using a dilutional principle of fetal hemoglobin with adult hemoglobin. The relation between total blood volume and estimated fetal weight, severity of anemia and hydrops was analyzed.Gestational age ranged from 17 to 35 weeks. Mean hemoglobin deficit was 6.8 standard deviations (range 2.1-11.7) below the normal mean. Fetal total blood volume was significantly related to estimated fetal weight (p < 0.001). Mean total blood volume in nonhydropic fetuses was 123 ml/kg (n = 74) and in hydropic fetuses 144 ml/kg (n = 12). There was a significant relation between total blood volume per kg body weight and hydrops (p = 0.035); however, there was no relation with severity of anemia (p = 0.94).
LLM_1: Fetal alloimmune anemia is linked to elevated blood flow velocities and the enlargement of the heart. In critical instances, it can lead to the onset of hydrops. This study aimed to explore the relationship between a decrease in red blood cell volume and changes in plasma volume, whether that be a reduction or an increase. We evaluated 86 alloimmunized fetuses who underwent their first intrauterine transfusion, calculating the total blood volume (including fetoplacental blood volumes) through a dilution method involving fetal hemoglobin and adult hemoglobin. We analyzed the correlation between total blood volume and factors such as estimated fetal weight, severity of anemia, and the presence of hydrops. The gestational ages of the subjects ranged from 17 to 35 weeks, with a mean hemoglobin deficit of 6.8 standard deviations below the normal average (range: 2.1-11.7). A significant relationship was identified between total blood volume and estimated fetal weight (p < 0.001). The average total blood volume for nonhydropic fetuses was 123 ml/kg (n = 74), whereas for hydropic fetuses, it was 144 ml/kg (n = 12). A significant correlation was also observed between total blood volume per kg of body weight and the incidence of hydrops (p = 0.035); however, there was no significant association with the severity of anemia (p = 0.94).
LLM_2: This study investigated the alterations in total blood volume, including fetoplacental circulation, in relation to red blood cell and plasma volume changes in fetuses affected by alloimmune anemia. A cohort of 86 alloimmunized fetuses undergoing their first intrauterine transfusion was analyzed. Total blood volume was estimated using a hemoglobin dilution method based on fetal and maternal hemoglobin concentrations, and its relationship with estimated fetal weight, anemia severity, and the presence of hydrops fetalis was assessed. Gestational age at transfusion ranged from 17 to 35 weeks, with a mean hemoglobin concentration 6.8 standard deviations below the expected normal mean (range: 2.1–11.7). A strong positive correlation was observed between total blood volume and estimated fetal weight (*p* < 0.001). The mean total blood volume was significantly higher in hydropic fetuses (144 mL/kg, *n* = 12) compared to non-hydropic fetuses (123 mL/kg, *n* = 74), demonstrating a significant association between increased blood volume per kilogram and the presence of hydrops (*p* = 0.035). In contrast, no significant correlation was found between total blood volume and the degree of anemia severity (*p* = 0.94). These findings suggest that while blood volume expansion is linked to fetal hydrops in alloimmune anemia, it is not directly proportional to the extent of anemia, highlighting the complexity of hemodynamic and volumetric adaptations in affected fetuses.

human:
Summary:  This paper presents a method to reduce the bandwidth required to update DNN models on edge devices.   The key insight is that model updates typically incorporate new data (training samples), and that after doing so, a minority of weights capture the majority of change due to retraining.  The authors propose a method by which to identify this weight subset, and compare the relative size (and test accuracy) of that update to that of other solutions (such as sending the entire network or sending a random subset of the weights on each retraining round).  Experiments with a number of existing data sets and models illustrate that the approach reduces update size more than 77% while maintaining reasonable test accuracy. 

=== pros ===

+ Paper is sufficiently motivated.  As edge devices use more (and larger) models and as their count increases, the relevance of partial update techniques to accomodate model decay will remain.   

+ The proposed technique provides a "sister" technique to pruning, not identifying nodes with greatest weights to retain, but identifying weights with the greatest changes to retain.  The policy is informed by choosing weights that minimize the difference in loss between the fully retrained network and its partially updated version.   

+ The paper is rounded out by practical items, such as encoding weight ids, a policy to determine when to retrain the network from scratch 
(re-initialization), and avoiding sending updates when validation error does not significantly change. 

+ The evaluation looks at a variety of angles, the ratio of initial training set to update size, different data sets and architectures, and compares to a random partial update strategy as well as a simplified version of their approach "GCPU".   

=== cons ===

- The overall presentation is difficult to parse.  
- The technique owes much to pruning methods and methodologies.   The technical approach (choosing weights, iterative rewinding) follows from recent work on pruning.  It would be great to have that discussion in related work, moving it out of Section 3.1 and Section 4. 
- Ultimately, existing pruning techniques can reduce networks by 90%.  By Amdahl's law, this implies that these techniques reduce communication by 7-10%, not 70-99%.  
- Equally important, does the technique work well on pruned networks?  Unimportant updates may not be as available in such networks.  On the other hand, if you do the comparison and all updates are important, then over the course of the lifetime of the installed NN, using DPU instead of pruning would be the winner.  
- Experiments in key graphs aren't clear: is there re-initialization in Figure 2?  Figure 3 performance never falls relative to full updating during re-initialization.  While the text (S3.2) makes it seem that the nodes reset all weights, using only 1% of the weights would impact test accuracy relative to full updating.  

=== suggestions / questions === 

Overall, I found the work interesting, useful, and complete (aside from eval sec questions above).   

It would be useful to introduce a metric that combines update size with accuracy loss at the beginning of the paper.  The evaluation does this, but consider pulling it forward and defining it explicitly.  Each round incurs a communication cost in bytes and experiences some accuracy, so, for example, one can capture changes in accuracy per byte, i.e. model improvement by update size.  Since you are comparing to other techniques that can reduce the bandwidth similarly, we want to optimize this ratio.  

Some networks work very well with small k.   But how low can you go?   I.e., how does one choose k?   Perhaps the accuracy/bytes metric could be informative. 

It would be interesting to discuss on why winning lottery ticket theory gets us 80-90% reductions, but this technique admits 99% reductions by retaining information in the rest of the network.    

The startup procedure is not clear.  The graphs and discussion in S3.2 make it sound like the entire network re-initializes.  Can we be clear about what the first network looks like?  I'd assume all the weights.  But if we start from random values (sending the seed), the first round only updates $kI$ weights.  Can the test performance of the network with only 1% of its weights be 65% (Figure 2)?  Similarly, if DPU is re-initializing, why is the test accuracy monotonically increasing -- the installed network would go back to ground zero.  Clearly I'm missing something, or your measuring the performance of the network at the server (w^f) and not the installed network (w^r).

Similarly Table 2 should have a column for the number of rounds that required no communication. 

DPU won't send updates if validation error doesn't decrease significantly.  It isn't clear whether you gave the same benefit to Full Updating. 

=== writing / terminology / notation ===

Overall the presentation is difficult to get through.   For instance, Section 3 has many awkward constructions.  It seems like there's a simple picture here, similar to the Train, Prune, Retrain flow of pruning work.  It seems deeply analogous, with the exception that rewinding replaces pruning.  The evaluation section refers to Alg 1 and Alg 2, but Section 3.0 refers only to "step 1" and "step 2".   Are there better words than step?  This section also refers to the second step as an "optimization" step.   You end P1 by saying you're optimizing eq 1 in step 2, then you say step 1 optimizes the same equation.  The last sentence of the S3.0P3 re-iterates what was said in P1.  I'm sorry, but it's a bit of a slog.

The use of notation is consistent.  There are a couple of things that felt like speed bumps.   I kept wanting to parse \delta W and \delta D using \delta as a variable, like $kI$.  At the end of section 2, introducing a new form of w^r as w~, was confusing.  Do we need w~?    

Sometimes you use L0 norms (S2 eq 2) and other times you use summation (S3.1).  

You use curly braces S4P1 for the sizes of the initial training and updates.  It looks like a set, not a configuration.  The text says the two sizes "represent the available data samples."  But here it's just a configuration -- it's not the set of samples at all (and it wouldn't be b/c not all updates R are present).   

==== nits ==== 

Please learn the difference between that and which.   Remove "in order to."   Capitalize Figure and Section.   

Some references use name style, other use indices. But the bibliography is all by name.  #confused.
LLM_1:
Summary: This paper presents a method to reduce the bandwidth required for updating Deep Neural Network (DNN) models on edge devices. The key insight is that model updates typically incorporate new data (training samples), and that after doing so, a minority of weights captures the majority of changes due to retraining. The authors propose a method to identify this subset of weights and compare the relative size (and test accuracy) of that update to other solutions, such as sending the entire network or sending a random subset of weights during each retraining round. Experiments with various existing datasets and models illustrate that the proposed approach reduces update size by more than 77% while maintaining reasonable test accuracy.

=== Pros ===

+ The paper is sufficiently motivated. As edge devices utilize more extensive models and their numbers increase, the relevance of partial update techniques to accommodate model decay will persist.

+ The proposed technique offers a complementary approach to pruning, focusing not on identifying nodes with the greatest weights to retain, but rather on identifying weights with the most significant changes to retain. The policy is informed by selecting weights that minimize the difference in loss between the fully retrained network and its partially updated version.

+ The paper is well-rounded, addressing practical aspects, such as encoding weight IDs, establishing a policy for determining when to retrain the network from scratch (re-initialization), and avoiding unnecessary updates when validation error does not change significantly.

+ The evaluation examines various factors, including the ratio of the initial training set to update size, different datasets and architectures, and comparisons with a random partial update strategy as well as a simplified version of their approach, termed "GCPU."

=== Cons ===

- The overall presentation is challenging to parse.

- The technique derives significantly from pruning methods and methodologies. The technical approach (selecting weights, iterative rewinding) follows from recent work on pruning. A discussion on this relationship would benefit the paper, potentially moving it out of Sections 3.1 and 4.

- Existing pruning techniques can reduce networks by 90%. According to Amdahl's law, this implies that these techniques reduce communication by only 7-10%, not the claimed 70-99%.

- Equally important is whether the technique performs well on pruned networks. Unimportant updates may be less available in such networks. Conversely, if all updates are deemed important, then over the lifetime of the installed neural network, using DPU instead of pruning would likely be more advantageous.

- The clarity of key experimental graphs is lacking: Is there re-initialization in Figure 2? Figure 3's performance never drops relative to full updating during re-initialization. While the text in Section 3.2 suggests that nodes reset all weights, utilizing only 1% of the weights would impact test accuracy compared to full updating.

=== Suggestions / Questions ===

Overall, I found the work interesting, useful, and comprehensive (aside from the evaluation section questions above).

It would be beneficial to introduce a metric that combines update size with accuracy loss at the beginning of the paper. The evaluation addresses this but consider pulling it forward and defining it explicitly. Each round incurs a communication cost in bytes and experiences some accuracy loss; thus, capturing changes in accuracy per byte—i.e., model improvement relative to update size—would be advantageous. Since comparisons are made with other techniques that can similarly reduce bandwidth, optimizing this ratio is essential.

Some networks perform exceptionally well with small values of k. However, how low can k be set? That is, how does one choose k? Perhaps the accuracy/bytes metric could guide this decision.

It would be interesting to discuss why winning lottery ticket theory achieves 80-90% reductions while this technique permits 99% reductions by retaining information in the rest of the network.

The startup procedure is unclear. The graphs and discussion in Section 3.2 imply that the entire network re-initializes. Can clarity be provided regarding the initial state of the network? I would assume all weights are present. However, if we start from random values (by sending the seed), the first round only updates $kI$ weights. Can the test performance of a network with only 1% of its weights be 65% (as shown in Figure 2)? Similarly, if DPU is re-initializing, why is the test accuracy monotonically increasing? The installed network would revert to its initial state. Clearly, I am missing something, or you are measuring the performance of the network at the server (w^f) rather than the installed network (w^r).

Additionally, Table 2 should include a column for the number of rounds that required no communication.

DPU does not send updates if validation error does not decrease significantly. It is unclear whether the same consideration was given to Full Updating.

=== Writing / Terminology / Notation ===

Overall, the presentation is difficult to navigate. For instance, Section 3 contains many awkward constructions. A clearer framework, akin to the Train, Prune, Retrain flow of pruning work, could enhance understanding. The evaluation section refers to Algorithms 1 and 2, while Section 3.0 refers only to "step 1" and "step 2." Are there better terms than "step"? This section also describes the second step as an "optimization" step. You conclude P1 by stating that you are optimizing Equation 1 in step 2, then assert that step 1 optimizes the same equation. The final sentence of Section 3.0, Paragraph 3, reiterates what was previously stated in Paragraph 1, leading to redundancy.

The use of notation is consistent, but a few elements felt like obstacles. For example, I consistently wanted to interpret \(\delta W\) and \(\delta D\) using \(\delta\) as a variable, similar to \(kI\). At the end of Section 2, the introduction of a new form of \(w^r\) as \(w~\) was confusing. Is \(w~\) necessary?

Sometimes you use L0 norms (see Equation 2 in Section 2), while at other times, you utilize summation (see Section 3.1).

The use of curly braces in Section 4, Paragraph 1, for the sizes of the initial training and updates appears to suggest a set rather than a configuration. The text states that the two sizes "represent the available data samples." However, in this context, it is merely a configuration—it does not represent the set of samples at all (and it would not, because not all updates \(R\) are present).

==== Nits ====

Please ensure a proper distinction between "that" and "which." Remove "in order to." Capitalize "Figure" and "Section."

Some references use name style, while others use indices, yet the bibliography is consistent in being by name.
LLM_2:
Summary:

This paper introduces a novel method, dubbed Dynamic Partial Update (DPUs), to minimize bandwidth requirements for DNN model updating on the edge. By identifying a subset weights responsible for capturing the bulk of updates, DPsUs purportedly reduces the update sizes by over 75% whilst maintaining acceptable test accuracies.

**Pros**

+   The work is adequately motivated, with an increasing reliance on more complex models in edge computing environments driving the need for partial updates.
+  DpsUs provides a distinct alternative to traditional pruning approaches, which focus on retaining weights based on their importance rather identifying the subset with significant updates. Furthermore, its policy selection is guided by minimizing the loss difference between fully and partially re-trained networks.
  +  The presentation covers practical issues, like encoding weights IDs and determining re-training policies, as wells as avoiding redundant updates.

*   A variety of factors are examined in evaluation, covering update ratios, dataset architectures and model comparisons, along with comparisons against random update methods.
*  While some minor issues have been found, they do not detract significantly the overall value of this research.

Cons:

* The structure of paper can make challenging for reader to follow.
The method draws heavily from previous work in pruning.
 Technical approach derives from methodologies like pruning weights selection, hence discussing its relationship could strengthen the manuscript.
Existing pruning can achieve 9% reduction, implying a much lower  10% bandwidth reduction as per Amlhd's Law.
Evaluation lacks clarity in key figures, particularly regarding reinitialization and performance.
Unimportant weights may become less accessible in prunned networks and vice versa.
Performance on such prunen networks has not been addressed.

Suggestions /Questions:

Overall I find the research work engaging, comprehensive and useful aside from evaluation questions.
 Introducing a combined metric of update accuracy and size at start of manuscript would help guide future work.
Comparing this metric with existing techniques would further strengthen this work.

Networks that perform well under small k values, what is minimum k possible?
 Accuracy / bytes metric may guide k selection.

Winning ticket lottery theory can only achieve up to 8% weight reductions, whereas this approach reaches 100% by maintaining information throughout network. Further discussion could be added to understand this difference.

 Initial state network is not clear. Graphs and discussions imply network resets. What is initial weight state? Can performance be measured on installed or server side?

Table  Two should have a "rounds with no updates" column.

Full updating does consider the validation errors.

Writing/Terminology/Notation:

Presentation is hard to read. Section three has many unclear constructions.
 Train Pruning Retain flow could improve understanding.
 Evaluation section mentions Algorithms, however, only Section refers "steps".
   Are steps better term than steps? Section also introduces optimization steps and later reiterate optimisation goal.
   Notations use \delta  consistently, sometimes interpreted as variable.

L0 Norms are used in some places while summations are in others.
 Curly braces are confusing, representing a size or configuration.
 Ensure proper use between that and which. 

References are sometimes cited using name and sometimes index. Ensure consistent citation style.

References:

Please note that references were not provided in original text. If you provide them, we can ensure they are consistent and follow the required citation format.

 Capitalise "figure" "section" properly.
 "In order" to should be removed.
 Proper distinction should exist between 'that' and 'which'.

human:
`` This is command, are you there Captain?'' 
 
 
 Randy stood there by his ship, space helmet fastened firmly to his head. 
 
 
 `` I repeat,'' insisted Gus, `` are you there, Captain?'' 
 
 
 Randy refused to speak. He folded his arms across his chest and looked down at his feet. His ship idled close by, but he refused to embark. The two stood apart from each other on a knoll of the purest green, Gus perched atop the hill, looking down at Randy standing some ten feet away. 
 
 `` Oh come on, Randy, it's no fun if you're not playing!'' 
 `` I do n't wan na play. How come you're always commander and I'm always captain?'' 
 
 Gus sighed. It was so obvious, and yet, Randy always had something to complain about. `` Well, my ship is bigger, so obviously I have to be commander.'' He pointed to Randy's ship. `` You only have three gears on your ship, look at mine!'' 
 
 Randy's frown grew bigger. `` Well that's not fair. Just because you have a bigger ship, that does n't mean you get to be commander all the time.'' 
 
 `` Yes it does,'' Gus replied. `` A commander is a commander because he has the bigger ship.'' 
 
 Randy uncrossed his arms, and looked up at Gus firmly. `` No, you're wrong,'' he said. `` A commander is a commander because other people said he is.'' 
 
 `` Well, *you're* wrong,'' Gus shot back, `` if a commander dies, the next person to be commander is the one that gets the big ship.'' 
 
 Randy's face grew hot. `` That's not right. If my parents bought me a bigger ship, that does n't make me commander.'' 
 
 `` Your parents are never gon na buy you a bigger ship, so I'm still commander.'' 
 
 `` They will if I ask them to!'' 
 
 `` No they wo n't, your parents are poor.'' 
 
 `` They are not!'' 
 
 `` They are too. My dad has two cars, and my mom has two cars. Your whole family put together only has one! I bet you do n't even have a computer at your house!'' 
 
 `` My family is not poor!'' Randy shouted back. 
 
 `` I bet you've never even had lobster! My family went out to eat lobster last night, and poor people do n't eat lobster!'' Gus laughed at Randy's slender frame, his messy hair, his small hands balled up into fists, as the wind blew and swept over the grass around him in unrelenting waves. 
 
 `` I have too! You do n't even know what you're talking about!'' 
 
 `` When was the last time your family ate lobster?'' 
 
 `` Shut up!'' 
 
 `` No you shut up, you're poor and I'm commander.'' 
 
 A spark of fury shot through Randy's body. He threw his bicycle aside and charged up the hill, slipping as he ran, and grabbed Gus by the waist. 
 
 `` Hey -- hey! What are you doing?!'' 
 
 As they fell, Randy blindly pummeled at Gus's body, before he felt a crack to the side of his head. `` I'm commander!'' yelled Gus, holding a rock in his hand, `` you ca n't beat up the commander!'' Randy, dazed, tried to roll away, to stand up and face Gus. Gus brought down the rock again, hard, into Randy's nose. A hot, blinding pain seared through Randy's face, and he felt his mouth fill up with a sticky metallic flavor. He rolled up onto his hands and knees, spat into the grass to find blood, before a foot flew into his side, knocking him over. Pain. Randy was used to pain. But now it was all over, he could n't think straight, much less stand up, and Randy curled up on the grassy bed, shielding himself from Gus's unrelenting blows. After what seemed like forever, Gus stopped, breathing hard. `` My dad was right, poor people like you need to learn your place.'' Gus started back up the hill. 
 
 Randy looked at Gus, vision blurred, and he reached into his pocket. It was n't big, but he held in his hand a small blade that he had bought from a local convenience store. His head was swimming with anger, and he knew if he wanted to hurt Gus, he could hurt him really bad with a knife. So he staggered up, pain shooting through his body, and slowly walked up the hill, knife clenched in a small, furious fist. Gus heard rustling from behind, and turned. 
 
 `` What do you want now --'' he began, before Randy brought down the knife with everything he could muster, jamming it into the space where Gus's neck met the collar of his shirt. A heart-wrenching shriek rang across the knoll, and Gus collapsed. The knife dislodged itself from Gus's tender skin, where blood flowed freely from the wound. `` Nononono,'' Gus whimpered, `` nonononononono...'' 
 
 So much blood. Randy fell beside Gus. He wanted to hurt Gus, but not like this. `` Nonono... help... help...'' Gus pressed his hand against his collarbone, but the blood continued to seep out and stain the grass around him. `` No... no...'' 
 
 Randy did not know what to do. He could n't leave Gus here, not like this, but he needed to get help. `` I'm going to get my dad!'' Randy said, turning to leave, but Gus grabbed him. `` No... do n't leave... I'm scared... no... I'm cold...'' and Randy looked down at Gus. Gus was pale now, his teeth chattering, `` I-I'm... cold... I'm so cold... Randy... help... Please? C-c-c-can you h-help me-e?'' Randy knelt close to Gus, his hands shaking. `` Gus, I... I do n't... Gus! Gus! I... I...'' and hot tears welled up and flowed down Randy's face, stinging against the wounds upon his cheeks and lips. `` Gus... I do n't know what to do... I'm sorry... Gus...'' 
 
 Gus's breathing slowed. `` Randy? A-are... are you there? Randy? No... nonono... Randy... Help... I-I'm... I'm scared...'' 
 
 Randy could n't say anything. 
 
 `` Randy? I'm... I'm really scared... Randy... You... you can be commander next time... Randy...... I promise...'' 
 
 And Gus's breathing slowed... and slowed... until Gus's eyes, frozen open in terror, glazed over with an icy stare, his hands falling limp at his side. 
 
 Randy stared at Gus for awhile longer, his hands still shaking. Somewhere in the back of his head, he knew he was in huge trouble, but he did n't care about that. He could see Gus right here, but somehow, he knew Gus was gone. He took Gus's shoulder and shook it. `` Gus...? Gus?'' 
 
 But there was no response. 
 
 The sun was now setting over the horizon, staining the sky with a violent crimson light. Above, stars began to glitter, and Randy looked at them dance, admiring how playful they looked. 
 
 Randy remained sitting next to Gus, legs curled against his body. And as the sunlight faded, revealing all the little stars and the moon that hung there with a smile on its face, Randy sobbed. 
 
 `` Where is Gus now?'' He wondered. `` I miss him.''

“This is a command. Are you there, Captain?”

Randy stood resolutely beside his ship, his space helmet snugly secured atop his head.

“I repeat,” Gus urged, “are you there, Captain?”

Silence enveloped Randy. He crossed his arms tightly and cast his gaze downward, refusing to look at his ship, which idled patiently nearby. The two boys were positioned on a knoll of vibrant green grass, with Gus perched high up, staring down at Randy, who was a mere ten feet away.

“Oh come on, Randy, it’s no fun if you’re not playing!” 

“I don’t want to play. Why is it that you’re always the commander while I’m stuck being the captain?” 

Gus exhaled in exasperation. The answer seemed so clear, yet Randy never failed to find something to bicker about. “Well, my ship is bigger, so naturally I have to be the commander.” He gestured toward Randy’s vessel. “You only have three gears on yours! Look at mine!”

Randy’s frown deepened. “That’s not fair. Just because your ship is bigger doesn’t mean you automatically get to be the commander.”

“Yes, it does,” Gus replied confidently. “A commander is a commander because he has the bigger ship.”

Randy uncrossed his arms, his eyes locking onto Gus with determination. “No, you’re mistaken. A commander is defined by the acknowledgment of others.”

“Well, *you’re* wrong,” Gus shot back. “If a commander dies, the next one in line is simply the one with the bigger ship.”

Randy felt heat rise to his cheeks. “That’s not right! If my parents bought me a bigger ship, it wouldn’t automatically make me the commander.”

“Your parents will never buy you a bigger ship, so I’m still the commander.”

“They will if I ask them to!”

“No, they won’t. Your parents are poor.”

“They are not!” Randy retorted.

“They are too! My dad has two cars, and my mom has two cars. Your entire family combined probably only owns one! I bet you don’t even have a computer at home!”

“My family is not poor!” Randy shouted defiantly.

“I bet you’ve never even tasted lobster! My family went out for lobster last night, and poor people don’t eat lobster!” Gus laughed, mocking Randy’s slender frame, his disheveled hair, and his small fists clenched tightly as the wind swept over the grass like relentless waves.

“I have too! You don’t know what you’re talking about!”

“When was the last time your family had lobster?”

“Shut up!”

“No, you shut up. You’re poor, and I’m the commander.”

Randy’s fury ignited, and he hurled his bicycle aside, charging up the hill. He stumbled as he ran and lunged at Gus, gripping him around the waist.

“Hey—hey! What are you doing?!”

As they tumbled, Randy struck at Gus blindly until a sharp pain erupted on the side of his head. “I’m the commander!” Gus yelled, brandishing a rock, “You can’t beat up the commander!” Dazed, Randy tried to roll away, to rise and confront Gus. But Gus brought the rock crashing down onto Randy’s nose. A searing pain shot through his face, and a metallic taste filled his mouth. He staggered onto his hands and knees, spitting blood into the grass before a kick sent him sprawling. Pain was familiar to Randy, but this time it overwhelmed him. He curled up on the cool grass, shielding himself from Gus’s relentless barrage. Eventually, Gus ceased his attack, panting heavily. “My dad was right; poor people like you need to learn their place.” He began to ascend the hill.

Randy gazed up at Gus, his vision blurred, and reached into his pocket. It wasn’t large, but he clutched a small knife he had purchased from a local convenience store. Anger coursed through him, and he realized he could inflict serious harm on Gus. With pain shooting through his body, he staggered up the hill, gripping the knife tightly in his furious fist. Gus heard the rustling behind him and turned.

“What do you want now—” he began before Randy struck down with all his might, plunging the knife into the vulnerable space where Gus’s neck met his collar.

A heart-wrenching scream echoed across the knoll as Gus crumpled to the ground. The knife slipped from his skin, and blood poured from the wound. “Nononono,” Gus whimpered, “nonononononono…”

So much blood. Randy fell beside Gus. He had intended to hurt him, but not like this. “Nonono… help… help…” Gus pressed his hand against his collarbone, but the blood continued to flow, staining the grass beneath him. “No… no…”

Randy felt paralyzed. He couldn’t abandon Gus here, not like this, but he needed to seek help. “I’m going to get my dad!” he announced, turning to leave, but Gus’s hand gripped his arm. “No… don’t leave… I’m scared… no… I’m cold…” Randy looked down; Gus was turning pale, his teeth chattering. “I-I’m… cold… I’m so cold… Randy… help… please? C-c-c-can you h-help me-e?”

Randy knelt beside Gus, trembling. “Gus, I… I don’t… Gus! Gus! I… I…” Hot tears streamed down Randy’s face, stinging the wounds on his cheeks and lips. “Gus… I don’t know what to do… I’m sorry… Gus…”

Gus’s breathing slowed. “Randy? A-are… are you there? Randy? No… nonono… Randy… help… I-I’m… I’m scared…”

Randy found himself lost for words.

“Randy? I’m… I’m really scared… Randy… You… you can be commander next time… Randy… I promise…”

And Gus’s breath grew faint… and fainter… until his eyes, wide with terror, dulled to an empty stare, his hands falling limply to the ground.

Randy lingered beside Gus, trembling hands still shaking. In the depths of his mind, he knew he was in grave trouble, but that was the least of his concerns. He could see Gus right there, yet somehow, he understood that Gus was gone. He shook Gus’s shoulder. “Gus...? Gus?”

But there was no answer.

The sun dipped below the horizon, casting a violent crimson hue across the sky. Stars began to twinkle above, and Randy watched them dance, enchanted by their playful shimmer.

He remained seated next to Gus, legs tucked against his body. As daylight waned, revealing the stars and the moon smiling softly down, Randy wept.

“Where is Gus now?” he pondered. “I miss him.”
LLM_2:
The hillside where two young boys once clashed in their endless game of command and captaincy now lay still, bathed in the golden light of a setting sun. Memories of their heated arguments and petty squabbles linger on this tranquil scene, where the sweet scent of blooming wildflowers fills the air. Yet, amidst the serenity, a somber mood settles, like an unspoken secret, over Randy and Gus's beloved knolls.

Gone are the days when Gus would taunt Randy with boasts of wealth and luxury, when Randy's family was reduced to mere spectators, their poverty a constant reminder of Gus' superior status. Now, in this quiet evening, as stars begin to peck at the darkening sky, only silence remains, an eerie silence that wraps around their small, verdant hill like a shroud.

It was on one such evening that their game took a dark turn. "I'm the command!" Gus had shouted, taunting Randy as they stood on their beloved hill overlooking the lush green expanse below. Their words dripped with malice, each one a deliberate jab at their opponent's vulnerabilities. And then, something snapped within Randy – a spark of fury that would ignite a maelstrom of chaos, leaving destruction in its wake.

As the night drew in, shadows danced across their hilltop, silhouettes of two small figures locked in an eternal struggle for supremacy. They hurricaned down the slope, fists flying, until Randy found a jagged rock to strike Gus down. Panic seized Randy; his heart pounded in terror as, for a fleeting moment, reality blurred and all that remained was chaos.

In the aftermath of that fateful night – one that had shattered their innocence – Randy stood beside the lifeless form of Gustave. Tears streamed from Randy eyes as a scream, one of anguish and despair, tore through the evening air, echoing through their knolly hill for all eternity. His words of apology were lost amidst a whirlwind of tears as Randy cradled Gus in desperate sorrow.

And yet, even in death, there existed a glimmer of hope. For in that moment of quiet, amongst the falling stars, two hearts connected – the hearts of Randy the poor boy and Gustav, whose cruel words had left their mark. Even as their world began anew, those two souls intertwined, forever locked, entwined in memory.

Yet, if one were to ask where Guste is now – if there's an afterlife, or if death simply marks the end of life – no one can provide an answer. Perhaps the universe holds secrets beyond our grasp, secrets hidden from us like the delicate petals of wild flowers that Randy would watch dance under the starry sky.

Or perhaps, on some hidden hill in some other world, Gusty's spirit still haunts the shadows, lost and wandering in search of an old friend, now nothing more than a memory. Or maybe, just maybe – in our own world – Gustie's ghost hauntes us still – watching over us, whispering words we cannot hear.

But what we do know is that in those moments of silence, that stillness we find on our hill when day turns to night and stars start to shine, we are reminded of what once was – two childhood friends who became embroiled in chaos. We are left to ponder on what the future holds – for those left behind, searching for solace in memories of yesteryear. So let us cherish the memories we have – cherish them like delicate flowers, fragile and yet resilient in face of adversity. Let us remember that which once connected us – let it be our guiding light in these trying times. 

As night deepens, shrouding our world in darkness, let the spirits of those we love, of our past, guide us through life's journey. May we learn to cherish what has been given to us. To cherish those who have been left in shadows. Those that are no more. Though the world moves forward, though our lives change with each new dawn, may we hold on to what truly matters. What truly connects us.

So we stand on that hill tonight, beneath the twinkling stars that seem to dance above us in celebration. Our hearts filled with longing, our souls yearning for what was. Gently, softly, without a word, remember the ones we lost. Remember their smiles, laughter, stories. Bring them back in your mind's eye, cherish their memories and let them guide you. Because in them, lies a world we once knew – and that world still lives on within us."

human: Appointment of the prime minister of France requires no approval by the parliament either, but the parliament may force the resignation of the government. In these systems, it is possible for the president and the prime minister to be from different political parties if the legislature is controlled by a party different from that of the president. When it arises, such a state of affairs is usually referred to as (political) cohabitation.

In such systems, it is possible for the President and the Prime Minister to belong to different political parties if the legislature is controlled by a party that differs from that of the President. This situation is commonly referred to as political cohabitation.

In such systems, it is possible for the President and the Prime Minister to belong to different political parties if the legislature is controlled by a party other than that of the President. This situation is commonly referred to as **cohabitation** in French politics.

In this study, we investigated the incidence of polymorphic tumor necrosis factor (TNF) genes in 61 patients undergoing treatment for Hodgkin lymphoma. During the treatment, patients were classified as responders or non-responders based on the quantity of CHT required for clinical tumor eradication. The incidence of the TNFa4 microsatellite allele, which is associated with low TNF production in leukocytes, was significantly higher in responders compared to non-responders (25.7% vs. 0%, p=0.04). LLM_2:
---

The response to chemotherapy (CHT) in patients with Hodgkin lymphoma varies considerably across individuals. This study investigated the association between polymorphisms in the tumor necrosis factor (TNF) gene and treatment response in 61 patients undergoing CHT. Patients were classified as responders or non-responders based on the extent of therapy required for clinical tumor eradication. The TNFa4 microsatellite allele, previously linked to reduced TNF production in leukocytes, was significantly more prevalent among responders than non-responders (25.7% vs. 0%, *p* = 0.04). Furthermore, analysis of relapse incidence 2–5 years post-treatment revealed a significantly higher frequency of the TNFa4 allele in patients who relapsed compared to those who remained in remission (41.1% vs. 9.3%, *p* = 0.007). These findings suggest a complex role for TNFa4 in both initial treatment response and long-term disease outcomes, highlighting its potential as a biomarker for therapeutic stratification in Hodgkin lymphoma.

The meeting was a good one. 
 
 Oh, I mean that sincerely. Well-practiced, concise. Obviously something they had repeated many times. Many generations worth of times, I suppose. Much better than the one I had last week on CBR refinements. 
 
 `` I hope you're a big fan of the aether,'' the director began with a smile. 
 
 It sort of surprised me that the first question that I asked afterward was, `` How did you pull it off?'' Not a science question, but a human one. Turns out the big lie really is easier to believe. 
 
 Aristotle was more right than Einstein. Holes in the celestial sphere, letting a little light in from beyond. Probably the most valid explanation at this point. At least as good as any other. But that light, what is it? 
 
 `` Do you believe religion can be good?'' the director asked. `` Regardless of whether it is true or not, can it have a positive effect?'' 
 
 Nodding in the affirmative, I knew where this was going. 
 
 Somebody had a plan. Copernicus or one of his ilk. Science needed to work. We needed more than holes in a curtain. We needed a jump-start. It took a lie to get it going. A wonderful fiction of our ancestors. It inspired the real science that runs our world today. Biology, chemistry, physics. All of it because of an idea that there was logic in the skies, an order in our heavens. 
 
 `` Our progress here,'' he indicated the ground, `` is tied to our progress there.'' He stared somewhat wistfully out the window. `` My belief is that we would still be late middle ages if not for their courage.'' 
 
 Knowledge is neither good nor bad. Simply correct or incorrect. All of this is just one more line to erase and start over. 
 
 `` We still want to know,'' he continued to look out the window. `` The answers are out there. Help us find them.'' 
 
 People who do n't know about science would probably tell me that everything that I had trained for all of my life was a lie and that all of my effort was a waste. That would be the biggest lie of all. 
 
 This is the greatest day of my life. Blank canvas. Give me a brush. Now the real science begins. 
 
 I can be Galileo. A real one, this time.

The meeting was remarkably productive.

Oh, I mean that sincerely. It was well-rehearsed, concise—obviously something they had practiced countless times. Generations of refinement, I suppose. Far superior to the one I attended last week on CBR refinements.

“I hope you're a big fan of the aether,” the director began with a smile.

I was somewhat surprised that my first question afterward was, “How did you pull it off?” Not a question of science, but one of humanity. It seems the grand deception truly is easier to embrace.

Aristotle was more astute than Einstein. Holes in the celestial sphere, letting a sliver of light from beyond seep in. At this point, it might be the most valid explanation—at least as compelling as any other. But that light, what does it signify?

“Do you believe religion can be beneficial?” the director asked. “Regardless of its truth, can it yield a positive impact?”

Nodding in agreement, I sensed where this was headed.

Someone had a vision—perhaps Copernicus or one of his contemporaries. Science needed to thrive. We required more than mere holes in a curtain; we needed a catalyst. It took a lie to ignite the spark. A splendid fiction crafted by our ancestors, inspiring the genuine science that governs our world today. Biology, chemistry, physics—all stemming from the notion that there was logic in the cosmos, an order in our heavens.

“Our progress here,” he gestured to the ground, “is tied to our progress there.” He gazed wistfully out the window. “I believe we would still be languishing in the late Middle Ages if not for their audacity.”

Knowledge is neither good nor bad; it is simply correct or incorrect. This is yet another line to erase and begin anew.

“We still seek answers,” he continued, his gaze fixed outside. “They are out there. Help us uncover them.”

Those unfamiliar with science might tell me that everything I have trained for throughout my life is a lie, that all my efforts have been in vain. That would be the greatest deception of all.

Today is the most significant day of my life. A blank canvas awaits. Hand me a brush. Now, the true science begins.

I can be Galileo. A genuine one, this time.
LLM_2:
---

The meeting was remarkably productive.

And I mean that with unflinching sincerity. It was seamless—rehearsed to perfection, concise without being curt, clearly the product of repetition so ingrained it had become ritual. Generations of refinement, perhaps. A far cry from last week’s droning session on CBR refinements, where time stretched like taffy and every word clung to the air with weary desperation.

“I hope you’re a big fan of the aether,” the director said, smiling as if sharing a private joke with the universe.

What surprised me wasn’t the remark itself, but my first instinctive response: *How did you pull it off?* Not a question of equations or empirical data, but of human craft—of performance, belief, illusion. It struck me then how easily we surrender to grand deceptions when they are wrapped in elegance. Perhaps that’s our nature.

Aristotle, I’ve come to think, saw more clearly than Einstein ever did. Holes in the celestial sphere—tiny punctures through which a sliver of true light might bleed into our world. Absurd? Yes. But at this point, it feels no less plausible than any other explanation. And yet… what *is* that light? What does it mean when myth becomes the vessel for discovery?

“Do you believe religion can be beneficial?” the director asked. “Not whether it’s true—but whether it can do good?”

I nodded. I already knew where he was leading.

Someone, long ago—Copernicus, or someone before him, dreaming in the dark—had a vision. Science needed more than curiosity; it needed fuel. We couldn’t wait for truth to reveal itself. So we told a story. A lie, yes—but a magnificent one. A fiction so beautiful it gave birth to reality. From that spark rose biology, chemistry, physics—the great edifice of knowledge, built not on fact, but on faith in order. Faith that beneath the chaos, there was pattern. That the heavens were not capricious, but knowable.

“Our progress here,” he said, tapping the floor with his shoe, “is tethered to our progress *there*.” He turned toward the window, where the sky hung vast and indifferent. “I suspect we’d still be counting indulgences in candlelit chapels if not for their audacity.”

Knowledge is neither virtuous nor wicked. It simply *is*—correct or incorrect. Another line to cross out. Another page to rewrite.

“We still seek answers,” he murmured, eyes fixed on the horizon. “They’re out there. Help us find them.”

Let the uninitiated say what they will—that my life’s work rests on a lie, that every equation I’ve solved, every hypothesis tested, is hollow. That would be the cruelest deception of all: to deny the truth born from the telling.

Today is the most important day of my life.

Before me lies a blank canvas, infinite and silent. Hand me a brush.

Now—now—the real science begins.

I can be Galileo.

And this time, I’ll be real.

---

### Notes on the Polish:
- **Tone & Voice**: Maintained the introspective, almost reverent skepticism, while deepening the lyrical quality.
- **Rhythm & Flow**: Varied sentence structure for dramatic pacing—short, punchy lines contrast with longer, flowing reflections.
- **Imagery**: Enhanced metaphors (e.g., "time stretched like taffy," "dreaming in the dark") to strengthen atmosphere.
- **Philosophical Nuance**: Clarified the central paradox—truth emerging from falsehood—without oversimplifying.
- **Ending Impact**: Sharpened the final lines for emotional and thematic resonance, culminating in a quiet but powerful declaration of purpose.

human: Epidemiologic studies have demonstrated that daily low to moderate alcohol consumption is cardioprotective as compared with abstainers and high alcohol consumption. Our group reported that alcohol consumption improves angiogenesis in chronically ischemic myocardium. We developed a clinically relevant follow-up study to assess the effect of moderate alcohol consumption on new vessel growth in normal myocardium remote from an ischemic territory in a swine model.Fourteen male Yorkshire swine underwent placement of an ameroid constrictor to induce chronic myocardial ischemia. Postoperatively, animals were supplemented with either 90 mL of ethanol daily (ETOH) or 80 g of sucrose (SUC) of equal caloric value. Seven weeks after ameroid placement, myocardial tissue from a territory remote from the ischemia was harvested for analysis.Both groups had similar microvascular relaxation to endothelial dependent and endothelium-independent vasodilators. Also, both groups had similar myocardial perfusion at rest and with demand pacing. The ETOH group had significantly increased arteriolar and capillary density in the nonischemic myocardium compared with the SUC group. ETOH supplementation also increased expression of pro-angiogenesis proteins vascular endothelial growth factor and vascular endothelial cadherin, and decreased expression of anti-angiogenesis proteins angiostatin and endostatin.
LLM_1: Epidemiologic studies have demonstrated that daily low to moderate alcohol consumption is cardioprotective compared to both abstainers and individuals with high alcohol consumption. Our research team previously reported that alcohol consumption enhances angiogenesis in chronically ischemic myocardium. We developed a clinically relevant follow-up study to evaluate the effect of moderate alcohol consumption on new vessel growth in normal myocardium remote from an ischemic territory using a swine model. Fourteen male Yorkshire swine underwent placement of an ameroid constrictor to induce chronic myocardial ischemia. Postoperatively, the animals were supplemented with either 90 mL of ethanol daily (ETOH) or 80 g of sucrose (SUC), which provided equivalent caloric intake. Seven weeks after ameroid placement, myocardial tissue from a territory remote from the ischemia was harvested for analysis. Both groups exhibited similar microvascular relaxation responses to endothelial-dependent and endothelium-independent vasodilators, and they also demonstrated comparable myocardial perfusion at rest and during demand pacing. Notably, the ETOH group displayed a significantly increased arteriolar and capillary density in the nonischemic myocardium compared to the SUC group. Additionally, ETOH supplementation resulted in elevated expression levels of pro-angiogenic proteins, including vascular endothelial growth factor and vascular endothelial cadherin, while reducing the expression of anti-angiogenic proteins, such as angiostatin and endostatin.
LLM_2:
---

**Abstract**

Epidemiological studies have consistently shown that low to moderate alcohol consumption is associated with reduced cardiovascular risk compared to both abstinence and heavy drinking. Our prior research demonstrated that alcohol intake promotes angiogenesis in chronically ischemic myocardium. To extend these findings, we conducted a clinically relevant follow-up study to investigate whether moderate alcohol consumption enhances neovascularization in nonischemic myocardial regions remote from the ischemic zone, using a swine model. Fourteen male Yorkshire swine underwent placement of an ameroid constrictor to induce chronic myocardial ischemia and were subsequently assigned to receive daily supplementation with either 90 mL of ethanol (ETOH group) or 80 g of sucrose (SUC group), matched for caloric intake. Seven weeks post-surgery, myocardial tissue was harvested from a remote, nonischemic region for analysis. No significant differences were observed between groups in microvascular reactivity to endothelium-dependent or -independent vasodilators, nor in myocardial perfusion at baseline or during demand pacing. However, the ETOH group exhibited significantly higher arteriolar and capillary density in the remote myocardium compared to the SUC group. Furthermore, ethanol supplementation was associated with upregulated expression of pro-angiogenic factors, including vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and vascular endothelial cadherin (VE-cadherin), and downregulation of anti-angiogenic proteins such as angiostatin and endostatin. These findings suggest that moderate alcohol consumption promotes angiogenesis in nonischemic myocardium through modulation of key regulatory proteins, independent of changes in vascular reactivity or perfusion.

human:
This paper presents a new model for composing representations of characters into word embeddings. The starting point of their argument is to include position-specific embeddings of characters rather than just position-independent characters. By adding together position-specific vectors, reasonable results are obtained.

This is an interesting result, but I have a few recommendations to improve the paper.
1) It is a bit hard to assess since it is not evaluated on a standard datasets. There are a number standard datasets for open vocabulary language modeling. E.g., the MWC corpus (http://k-kawakami.com/research/mwc), or even the Penn Treebank (although it is conventionally modeled in closed vocabulary form).
2) There are many existing models for composing characters into words. In addition to those cited in the paper, see the citations listed below. Comparison with those is crucial in a paper like this.
3) Since the predictions are done at the word type level, it is unclear how vocabulary set of the corpus is determined, and what is done with OOV word types at test time (while it is possible to condition on them using the technique in the paper, it is not possible to use this technique for generation).
4) The analysis is interesting, but a more intuitive explanation would be to show nearest neighbor plots.

Some missing citations:

Composing characters into words:

dos Santos and Zadrozny. (2014 ICML) http://proceedings.mlr.press/v32/santos14.pdf
Ling et al. (2015 EMNLP) Finding Function in Form. https://arxiv.org/abs/1508.02096

Additionally, using explicit positional features in modeling language has been used:
Vaswani et al. (2017) Attention is all you need https://arxiv.org/abs/1706.03762
and a variety of other sources.
LLM_1:
This paper introduces an innovative model for generating character representations within word embeddings. The authors argue for the inclusion of position-specific character embeddings, moving beyond the traditional position-independent approach. By aggregating these position-specific vectors, they achieve commendable results.

While this finding is compelling, I have several suggestions for enhancing the paper:

1) The evaluation is somewhat challenging to appraise due to the lack of assessment on standard datasets. There are several established datasets available for open vocabulary language modeling, such as the MWC corpus (http://k-kawakami.com/research/mwc) or the Penn Treebank, despite its typical focus on closed vocabulary modeling.

2) The landscape of models that convert characters into words is vast. Beyond those referenced in the paper, I recommend considering the citations provided below. A comparative analysis with these models is essential for a comprehensive discussion.

3) Since the predictions are made at the word type level, it is unclear how the vocabulary set of the corpus is defined and how out-of-vocabulary (OOV) word types are handled during testing. Although the technique presented in the paper allows conditioning on them, it does not facilitate their use for generation.

4) The analysis provided is intriguing; however, a more accessible explanation could be achieved through the inclusion of nearest neighbor plots.

Additional citations to consider:

Composing characters into words:
- dos Santos and Zadrozny (2014 ICML) [http://proceedings.mlr.press/v32/santos14.pdf]
- Ling et al. (2015 EMNLP) Finding Function in Form [https://arxiv.org/abs/1508.02096]

Furthermore, the use of explicit positional features in language modeling has been explored in:
- Vaswani et al. (2017) Attention is All You Need [https://arxiv.org/abs/1706.03762] 
and various other sources.
LLM_2:
preserving the original meaning and intent while enhancing clarity, fluency, and stylistic appropriateness for an academic review context.

---

This paper presents a novel approach to character-level modeling in word embeddings, proposing position-specific character representations as an alternative to conventional position-invariant methods. The authors demonstrate that aggregating these contextualized character vectors leads to strong performance, yielding promising results within their experimental framework.

The core idea is compelling and contributes meaningfully to ongoing efforts in fine-grained lexical representation. That said, several aspects of the work could be strengthened to improve its rigor, scope, and interpretability:

1) **Evaluation on standard benchmarks**: The current evaluation setup makes it difficult to assess the method’s effectiveness relative to existing approaches. While the proposed model shows promise, its performance would be more interpretable if evaluated on widely used datasets for open-vocabulary language modeling—such as the MWC corpus (http://k-kawakami.com/research/mwc)—or even established benchmarks like Penn Treebank, which, though typically treated as closed-vocabulary, can be adapted for such studies.

2) **Broader model comparison**: The space of character-to-word models is rich and well-studied. In addition to the works cited, the authors should consider incorporating and comparing against additional relevant models from the literature (e.g., dos Santos & Zadrozny, ICML 2014; Ling et al., EMNLP 2015). A more comprehensive comparison would strengthen the paper’s positioning and highlight the unique advantages of the proposed architecture.

3) **Vocabulary definition and OOV handling**: Since predictions are made at the word type level, clarification is needed regarding how the vocabulary set is constructed and how out-of-vocabulary (OOV) items are managed during testing. While the model allows conditioning on unseen types, it does not support generating them—an important limitation that should be explicitly discussed in the context of open-vocabulary modeling.

4) **Interpretability and analysis**: The qualitative analysis offered is insightful but could benefit from greater accessibility. Including nearest-neighbor visualizations of learned representations, for instance, would help illustrate what the model captures and make the findings more intuitive to readers.

**Suggested additional references**:
- dos Santos & Zadrozny (2014), *Learning Character-level Representations for Part-of-Speech Tagging*, ICML — [http://proceedings.mlr.press/v32/santos14.pdf]  
- Ling et al. (2015), *Finding Function in Form: Composing Character-Level Representations for Word-Level Prediction*, EMNLP — [https://arxiv.org/abs/1508.02096]  
- Vaswani et al. (2017), *Attention is All You Need* — [https://arxiv.org/abs/1706.03762], which explores explicit positional encoding in sequence modeling and offers relevant conceptual connections.

Incorporating these suggestions would significantly enhance the paper’s impact, clarity, and situational awareness within the broader research landscape.

--- 

This revised version improves flow, precision, and tone for peer review, while maintaining all substantive points and recommendations.

human:
Authors propose combining Adam-like per-feature adaptative and Nesterov's momentum. Even though Nesterov's momentum is implemented in major frameworks, it is rarely used, so there's an obvious question of practical relevance of proposed method.

Significant part of the paper is dedicated to proof of convergence, however I feel that convergence proofs are not interesting to ICLR audience unless the method is shown to be useful in practice, hence experimental section must be strong. Additionally, there's a veritable zoo of diagonal preconditioning methods out there already, this puts an onus on the authors to show an advantage in terms of elegance or practicality.

Experimental section is weak:
- There are 2 tunable parameters for each method. PA-SGD seems to be a bit better in the tail of optimization for convex problem, but I'm not confident that this is not due to better tuning of parameters (ie, due to researcher degrees of freedom). Authors state that "grid search was used", but no details on the grid search.
- PA-SGD seems quite sensitive to choice of alpha. 
- No comparison against momentum which is probably the most popular method for neural network training nowadays (ie, ImageNet training is done using momentum and not Adam)
- non-linear optimization experiments are shown using logarithmic scale for y for a huge number of epochs. This amplifies the tail behavior. More relevant is measure like "number of steps to reach xyz accuracy", or wall-clock time
- it seems to perform equivalent to Adam for non-linear problem
LLM_1:
The authors propose a novel approach that combines Adam-like per-feature adaptivity with Nesterov's momentum. While Nesterov's momentum is implemented in major frameworks, its practical application remains limited, raising questions about the relevance of the proposed method in real-world scenarios.

A substantial portion of the paper is devoted to proving convergence; however, it is worth noting that convergence proofs may not captivate the ICLR audience unless accompanied by demonstrable practical utility. Therefore, a robust experimental section is essential. Additionally, there exists a plethora of diagonal preconditioning methods, which places a significant burden on the authors to establish their approach's advantages in terms of either elegance or practicality.

The experimental section lacks rigor:
- Each method involves two tunable parameters. Although PA-SGD appears to perform marginally better in the tail of optimization for convex problems, concerns arise regarding the possibility that this advantage stems from parameter tuning (i.e., researcher degrees of freedom). The authors mention that "grid search was used," yet provide insufficient details regarding this process.
- PA-SGD seems to be quite sensitive to the choice of the alpha parameter.
- There is no comparison made against momentum, which is arguably the predominant method for neural network training at present (e.g., ImageNet training predominantly utilizes momentum rather than Adam).
- The non-linear optimization experiments are presented using a logarithmic scale for the y-axis over an extensive number of epochs, which exaggerates the tail behavior. More pertinent metrics would include measures such as the "number of steps to reach a specified accuracy" or wall-clock time.
- The performance of the proposed method appears comparable to that of Adam for non-linear problems.
LLM_2:
**Review Comments on the Manuscript**

The manuscript introduces a novel optimization method integrating Adam-like per-feature adaptivity with Nesterov’s momentum. While the theoretical contribution is noted, several concerns regarding motivation, experimental rigor, and practical relevance must be addressed before the work can be considered suitable for publication.

**Major Comments**

1. **Motivation and Practical Relevance**  
   The authors note that Nesterov’s momentum, though available in major frameworks, sees limited practical adoption. This observation raises a fundamental question: what specific, unmet need does the proposed method address in real-world applications? The authors should more clearly articulate the practical scenarios where their approach offers distinct advantages over existing methods, particularly given the abundance of diagonal preconditioning techniques.

2. **Experimental Rigor and Design**  
   The experimental section requires substantial strengthening to support the claims made:
   - **Hyperparameter Tuning Transparency**: The authors mention using a grid search but omit critical details (e.g., search ranges, granularity, validation criteria). To mitigate concerns about researcher degrees of freedom, full hyperparameter search protocols must be documented, ideally in the appendix.
   - **Sensitivity to Parameters**: The noted sensitivity of PA-SGD to the α parameter warrants further analysis. A sensitivity study or ablation should be included to clarify robustness across tasks.
   - **Comparison to Momentum**: Momentum remains the default optimizer for many large-scale tasks (e.g., ImageNet training). Omitting comparison with momentum, particularly in deep learning experiments, significantly weakens the empirical evaluation. The authors should include momentum baselines across all relevant experiments.
   - **Evaluation Metrics**: The use of a log-scale y-axis over many epochs may visually exaggerate tail performance. More informative metrics—such as steps or wall-clock time to reach a target accuracy—should be reported to better assess optimization efficiency.
   - **Non-Linear Optimization**: The performance of PA-SGD appears similar to Adam in non-convex settings. The authors should explicitly discuss under what conditions their method is expected to outperform Adam, supported by appropriate experiments.

3. **Theoretical Contribution vs. Audience Interest**  
   While convergence analysis is provided, the ICLR community often prioritizes empirical impact alongside theoretical guarantees. The authors should more directly connect their theoretical results to practical insights or algorithmic improvements that would interest a broad machine learning audience.

**Minor Comments**

- The claim that PA-SGD performs “marginally better” in the tail for convex problems should be statistically validated (e.g., via multiple runs with confidence intervals).
- Consider including a table summarizing hyperparameter settings for each method across experiments.
- The phrase “plethora of diagonal preconditioning methods” could be tempered; a short survey or categorization of relevant methods might help contextualize the contribution.

**Recommendation**

The paper presents a theoretically grounded optimizer but currently lacks the empirical evidence and practical motivation required for acceptance. **Major revisions** are needed, particularly in expanding and rigorously designing experiments, clarifying practical utility, and providing fair comparisons to standard baselines (including momentum). Addressing these concerns would significantly strengthen the manuscript’s contribution and relevance to the machine learning community.

human:
> Summary: This paper studies a new and more general way of parameterizing the simplest equilibrium network of the form $\sigma(Wz+Ux+b)$, a form that has been tackled by works like (Winston & Kolter 2020) and (El Ghaoui et al. 2019). The authors provide a computationally (relatively) efficient way of computing Lipschitz-bounded equilibrium networks and a detailed analysis of how the network should be constructed, along with the proof of the existence and uniqueness of the fixed point (and with less restrictive conditions when compared to MON). The empirical results on adversarial robustness shows that the proposed approach is a bit more robust than prior layer-based networks and other implicit networks, and validates most of the theoretical claims made by the authors.

My general opinion is that this paper extends the discussion made in (Winston & Kolter 2020) with its Condition 1 and 2 (e.g., they show that MON is simply a special case of condition 1 with $\Lambda=I$), and thus provides a reasonable method for constructing Lipschitz bounded equilibrium networks. The paper is overall well-written, and the insights are explained in a clear fashion (I especially like the Example 1, where the authors showed that Condition 1 is a less restrictive formulation). The experimental results validates the theoretical claims of the authors by demonstrating the effectiveness of the approach, but they could also be made stronger. But in general, I think this paper offers an insightful extension on the prior work(s) in this direction, and is an important addition to the implicit-depth neural network literature.

Pros:

1. Well-written paper with clearly defined notations and dimensionalities. The proofs are generally easy to follow (and pretty standard, to be honest).
2. The theoretical and empirical results demonstrate the improvement over the previous MON approach.
3. The authors additionally study the relationship between LBEN and neural ODEs, which to my knowledge is new (in terms of formally connecting these two implicit models).

Cons:

1. The empirical results are still on very small scales and not quite convincing.
2. While the relaxation of the constraints is novel, many other theoretical contents were already discussed in the MON paper. For example, the non-singularity of $I-JW$, the monotonicity and non-expansiveness of the proximal operators (a well-known result), Appendix B, etc. Granted, the two papers also have slightly different focuses (e.g., MON talked more about the PR algorithm).
3. The scope of the paper is still on the simplest $\sigma(Wz+Ux+b)$ form, which has been studied before. There is a lack of discussion on the challenge involved in building Lipschitz equilibrium models more generalized than this, and it's unclear how well some of the claims of the authors hold in a general setting (see my questions below).

---------------------------------

Some more questions/comments:

1. I didn't find the proof to Theorem 1's claim on "finite Lipschitz bound from $x$ to $y$" in the paper. I didn't find a formal "proof" to Theorem 1, and the proof of uniqueness is simply on page 4. But what does Assumption 1 and Condition 1 imply about the Lipschitz constant?

2. In the Neural ODE discussion, the paper claims that "for any well-posed equilibrium network, there corresponds a contracting (strongly stable) neural ODE", which intuitively makes sense to me (as one can think of a deep equilibrium model as a backward Euler...?). But more strictly speaking, is this supposed to be a general statement for deep equilibrium neural networks, or just for networks of the form (1) in the paper (i.e., $\sigma (Wz+Uz+b)$)? If the latter, I think the authors may want to clarify this; if the former, I think a proof would be hard (e.g., the (Bai et al. 2019) DEQ-Transformers), but I'd appreciate if the authors can give more theoretical insights on this.

3. One concerning part is the empirical study of the approach. To be clear, I think the authors did a good job validating the approach by comparing with MON and unconstrained DEQs (where their finding seem to agree with prior works that these unconstrained DEQs eventually have pretty bad Lipschitz constant). But I think two important pieces are missing. First, since Condition 1 (and thus Eq. (10) in the paper) provide a less restrictive formulation than MON, one would naturally think that the LBEN built in this way could have stronger representational power. But the results do *not* seem to suggest so. The $\text{LBEN}_{\gamma < \infty}$ seems overall very close to the $\text{MON}$ results in Table 1 and Figure 3(a). Second, (and together with the first point), I think it would be more useful to study a larger dataset, like CIFAR-10/100 (which MON did provide), with a convolutional LBEN. I'm curious to see how it compares with MON and other implicit models there. 

4. Since LBEN also uses similar method(s) as MON to compute the equilibrium point (e.g., Peaceman-Rachford), I'm assuming this method is not "more scalable" than the previous methods as you are solving the same high-dimensional equilibrium system? Can the authors confirm this? What about the memory efficiency during training?

---------------------------------

Some minor things:

- i) I didn't realize that the text following Theorem 2 on page 4 is the proof to Theorem 1 & 2 (as there is a "but first we make some straightforward remarks" sentence). It'd also be helpful, I think, to say something like you are assuming for (the sake of) contradiction that there are two solutions $z_a \neq z_b$. It was a bit surprising to me to see $z_a$ and $z_b$ as the theorem claimed "uniqueness".

- ii) Page 4 "on the other size" ---> "on the other side"?
