Each year the retailer handles a substantial 6 million clicks-and-collection orders, marking a notable surge from the initial 0.35 million in the year 2018, when this service began. Conversely, orders collected at partner Waitroe's stores, part-owned by John's Lewis will, too, be subject to this charge.

A spokesperson for the company explained the operational expenses incurred when all the orders received are processed at the distribution centres before they are transported to chosen retail stores. In the past year alone, nearly 1 in five (18%) of these orders were valued below £39.

Interestingly, competitors Debenham and Mark's and Spenser, have both expressed their intention to maintain their free click-collector service. (

human: The Republic of the Congo's sparse population is concentrated in the southwestern portion of the country, leaving the vast areas of tropical jungle in the north virtually uninhabited. Thus, Congo is one of the most urbanized countries in Africa, with 70% of its total population living in a few urban areas, namely in Brazzaville, Pointe-Noire or one of the small cities or villages lining the 534-kilometre (332 mi) railway which connects the two cities. In rural areas, industrial and commercial activity has declined rapidly in recent years, leaving rural economies dependent on the government for support and subsistence.

In rural areas, industrial and commercial activities have seen a significant decline in recent years, leaving local economies increasingly reliant on government support for sustenance and development.

human: The purpose of this study was to determine the frequency of myocardial ischemia as a potential mechanism for cardiac arrest and syncope in young patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy who experienced such complications.Sudden cardiac death and syncope occur frequently in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Although ventricular arrhythmias account for most of these events in adult patients, the mechanism responsible for cardiac arrest and syncope in young patients has not been established.Twenty-three patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, aged 6 to 23 years, with previous cardiac arrest (n = 8), syncope (n = 7) or a family history of sudden cardiac death (n = 8) were evaluated to determine the prevalence of spontaneous ambulatory ventricular tachycardia (24- to 72-h electrocardiographic [ECG] monitoring), exercise-induced myocardial ischemia (thallium scintigraphy) and inducibility of ventricular tachycardia (electrophysiologic studies).Three of 15 patients with a history of cardiac arrest or syncope had ventricular tachycardia on ambulatory ECG monitoring. However, all 15 patients, had inducible ischemia by thallium scintigraphy compared with only 3 (37%) of 8 patients with no such history (p < 0.01). In contrast, ventricular tachycardia induction was uncommon in all of the young patients (27% in those with cardiac arrest or syncope; 0% in the others). During therapy for ischemia with verapamil alone or in combination with beta-adrenergic blocking agents, only 4 of the 15 patients with cardiac arrest or syncope had further episodes. In three of the four patients, these events were temporally related to discontinuation of verapamil. Among eight patients who had a repeat exercise thallium study while receiving anti-ischemic therapy, seven (88%) had improved regional thallium uptake, of whom three had normal thallium studies.
LLM_1: This study aimed to investigate the prevalence of myocardial ischemia as a potential underlying cause of cardiac arrest and syncope in young individuals diagnosed with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Sudden cardiac death and syncope are common occurrences in this patient population. While ventricular arrhythmias are the predominant contributors to such events in adults, the specific mechanisms leading to cardiac arrest and syncope in younger patients remain unclear. The study evaluated twenty-three patients aged 6 to 23 years with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, including those with a history of cardiac arrest (n = 8), syncope (n = 7), or a family history of sudden cardiac death (n = 8). The assessment included the frequency of spontaneous ambulatory ventricular tachycardia via 24- to 72-hour electrocardiographic monitoring, exercise-induced myocardial ischemia assessed through thallium scintigraphy, and the inducibility of ventricular tachycardia determined through electrophysiological studies. Among the 15 patients with a history of cardiac arrest or syncope, three exhibited ventricular tachycardia on ambulatory ECG monitoring. Notably, all 15 patients demonstrated inducible ischemia on thallium scintigraphy, in contrast to only 3 out of 8 patients without such a history (p < 0.01). Ventricular tachycardia induction was infrequent across the cohort, occurring in 27% of those with a history of cardiac arrest or syncope and 0% in others. During treatment for ischemia, utilizing verapamil alone or in conjunction with beta-adrenergic blockers, only 4 of the 15 patients with prior cardiac arrest or syncope experienced additional episodes, with three of these events coinciding with the discontinuation of verapamil. Of the eight patients undergoing repeat exercise thallium studies while on anti-ischemic therapy, seven (88%) demonstrated enhanced regional thallium uptake, with three achieving normal thallium results.
LLM_2: This study sought to examine the role of myocardial ischemia as a potential pathophysiological mechanism underlying cardiac arrest and syncope in pediatric and young adult patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). Although ventricular arrhythmias are well-established contributors to sudden cardiac events in adult HCM populations, the etiological basis for such manifestations in younger individuals remains less defined. A cohort of 23 patients aged 6 to 23 years with HCM was evaluated, stratified by clinical history: cardiac arrest (n = 8), unexplained syncope (n = 7), or familial sudden cardiac death (n = 8). Comprehensive diagnostic assessment included ambulatory electrocardiographic monitoring (24–72 hours) to detect spontaneous ventricular tachycardia (VT), exercise thallium-201 scintigraphy to assess for inducible myocardial ischemia, and electrophysiological testing to evaluate VT inducibility. Among the 15 patients with prior cardiac arrest or syncope, ambulatory ECG revealed spontaneous VT in three cases. Notably, all 15 exhibited evidence of inducible myocardial ischemia on thallium imaging, compared to only 3 of 8 asymptomatic or low-risk patients (p < 0.01). Electrophysiologic induction of VT was observed in 27% of symptomatic patients and in none of the remaining cohort. Pharmacological management targeting ischemia—primarily with verapamil, alone or combined with beta-blockers—was associated with a reduced incidence of recurrent events: only 4 of the 15 high-risk patients experienced further episodes, three of which occurred following verapamil discontinuation. Repeat thallium scintigraphy during anti-ischemic therapy was performed in eight patients, revealing improved regional perfusion in seven (88%), with normalization of thallium uptake in three. These findings suggest that myocardial ischemia is highly prevalent in young HCM patients with life-threatening events and may play a significant mechanistic role, potentially informing risk stratification and therapeutic strategies beyond traditional arrhythmia-focused models.

human:
After years of her always staying just one step ahead of me, I'd finally managed to catch up to her on Crys-4, a planet made almost entirely out of gigantic, reflective crystals. 
 
 I landed my small scout ship between two gigantic, hexagonal pillars sticking about 10 meters out of the ground. I would've taken a moment to enjoy the scenery, but I had more important business to attend to... to finally stop Sin'lar, the most powerful master of the force to ever exist in the galaxy. Well, most powerful right after myself of course. Why else would she be running from me? 
 
 I stepped out of my ship, my tracking device in one hand and my light saber in the other. According to my tracker she had gone into one of the many maze-like caverns on the planet, likely in an attempt to hide herself from my tracking device, or in order to lure me into a trap. I, of course, had seen through all that right from the beginning. No evil could outsmart me, no user of the force outpower me. As I finally reached the entrace to the cavern, I paused. 
 
 `` You ca n't run from me, you hear?'' I yelled inside, my voice echoing deep into the maze of crystal. 
 
 I gripped my light saber tightly and stepped inside. I chased after her through the crystal maze, occasionally seeing her reflection, often more than one at a time, on the crystals. I gradually closed more and more distance, until eventually I caught up to her in a large room. 
 
 `` Seems you have nowhere to go, Sin'lar.'' I grinned victoriously. `` Finally, you shall answer for your crimes, and I shall be known throughout the galaxy as the only Jedi powerful enough to defeat a legendary Sith like you!'' 
 
 `` You think you're so special, so unique, do n't you?'' She mocked, only her chin visible under the black hood she was wearing. `` Well guess what, you're not at all unique!'' And with those words, she pulled back her hood to reveal her face. 
 
 This was the first time anyone had seen her face, yet it looked so familiar... it looked exactly like mine. `` But... how?'' I stammered. 
 
 `` Surprised?'' She smirked. 
 
 `` This must be some kind of trick! Show your true face, Sith!'' I was visibly angry. Seeing my beautiful face on the body of such a disgraceful individual... I could n't have it. 
 
 `` It's no trick, sister.'' She began. `` You see, we are twins, seperated at birth. One of us was raised by an old Jedi master, taught noble ideals of good and righteousness. The other... well that would be me.'' 
 
 I stood there, stunned. I had learned to be prepared for anything, but even I could n't have anticipated this. 
 
 `` Shocked? Figures you would be.'' She laughed mockingly. `` When I first found out I went into a frenzy, murdered the very people that had raised me.'' She made an overexaggerated sad expression. `` We both share a certain... obsession with being the best, the single most powerful force user in the galaxy, I figure it's genetic. That is why we can not bear to see someone just like us, someone identical in fact.'' 
 
 `` Is that why...'' My initial shock finally started to wear of, and I slowly regained my composure. 
 
 `` Yes, that is why I brought you here.'' She paused. `` So there may only be one!'' She exclaimed, charging towards me.
LLM_1:
After years of staying just one step ahead of me, I had finally managed to catch up to her on Crys-4, a planet composed almost entirely of gigantic, reflective crystals.

I landed my small scout ship between two colossal, hexagonal pillars that jutted ten meters above the ground. I would have taken a moment to admire the breathtaking scenery, but I had more pressing matters to attend to—namely, stopping Sin'lar, the most powerful master of the Force to ever exist in the galaxy. Well, she was the most powerful, right after me, of course. Why else would she be running from me?

Stepping out of my ship, I gripped my tracking device in one hand and my lightsaber in the other. According to my tracker, she had entered one of the many labyrinthine caverns on the planet, likely trying to elude my device or lure me into a trap. But I had seen through her schemes from the very beginning. No evil could outsmart me; no user of the Force could overpower me. As I approached the entrance to the cavern, I paused.

"You can't run from me, you hear?" I yelled into the darkness, my voice echoing through the crystal maze.

I tightened my grip on my lightsaber and stepped inside. I pursued her through the shimmering corridors of crystal, catching glimpses of her reflection, often more than one at a time. I gradually closed the distance until I finally cornered her in a vast chamber.

"Seems you have nowhere to go, Sin'lar," I declared with a victorious grin. "At last, you shall answer for your crimes, and I will be known throughout the galaxy as the only Jedi powerful enough to defeat a legendary Sith like you!"

"You think you're so special, so unique, don’t you?" she mocked, her chin the only part of her face visible beneath the black hood she wore. "Well, guess what? You're not unique at all!" With that, she pulled back her hood to reveal her face.

It was the first time anyone had seen her face, yet it looked hauntingly familiar… it looked exactly like mine. "But... how?" I stammered.

"Surprised?" she smirked.

"This must be some kind of trick! Show your true face, Sith!" My anger flared. Seeing my own beautiful visage on the body of such a disgraceful individual was unacceptable.

"It's no trick, sister," she began. "You see, we are twins, separated at birth. One of us was raised by an old Jedi Master, taught the noble ideals of good and righteousness. The other… well, that would be me."

I stood there, stunned. I had learned to be prepared for anything, but even I could not have anticipated this.

"Shocked? Figures you'd be," she laughed mockingly. "When I first found out, I went into a frenzy, murdering the very people who had raised me." She feigned a sad expression. "We both share a certain… obsession with being the best, the single most powerful Force user in the galaxy. I figure it's genetic. That is why we cannot bear to see someone just like us—someone identical, in fact."

"Is that why…" My initial shock began to fade, and I slowly regained my composure.

"Yes, that is why I brought you here," she paused. "So there may only be one!" She exclaimed, charging toward me.
LLM_2:
After years of staying just one step ahead, I finally caught up with her on Crys-4—a world sheathed in colossal, light-drinking crystals.

I set my scout ship down between two hexagonal pillars that speared ten meters into the violet sky. Under other circumstances, I might have lingered to take in the stark beauty of the place. But I had a more urgent purpose: to stop Sin’lar, the most powerful Force-wielder in the galaxy.  
Well. The most powerful after me, of course. Why else would she run?

I stepped out, tracker in one hand, lightsaber in the other. The device showed she’d vanished into one of the planet’s labyrinthine crystal caves—either hiding from my sensors or laying a trap. Not that it mattered. I’d seen through her schemes from the start. No darkness could outthink me; no rival could overpower me.  
At the cavern’s mouth, I paused.

“You can’t run forever,” I called into the shimmering dark. My voice fractured and echoed through the crystalline maze.

I ignited my blade and stepped inside.  
Through corridors of refracted light I pursued her, catching fractured glimpses of her form—sometimes one reflection, sometimes several—until the path opened into a vast, glittering chamber. There, with her back to a wall of amethyst crystal, she was finally cornered.

“Nowhere left to go, Sin’lar,” I said, a victorious smile touching my lips. “You will answer for what you’ve done. And the galaxy will know that I am the only Jedi strong enough to bring down a legend like you.”

“You think you’re special,” she mocked. Only her chin was visible beneath the shadow of her hood. “Unique. Chosen.” Her laugh was a cold, sharp thing. “But you’re not unique at all.”  
With a deliberate slowness, she drew back her hood.

I had never seen her face before. Yet I knew it.  
It was mine.

“How…?” The word slipped out, brittle and disbelieving.

“Surprised?” Her smirk was my smirk.

“Illusion!” I snapped, anger surging hot and bright. “Show your true self, Sith!” It felt like a violation—my own face worn by something so wretched.

“No illusion, sister.” Her voice softened, almost tender. “We were twins. Separated at birth. One raised by a Jedi Master, taught virtue, light… all that noble dogma. The other…” She spread her hands. “Well. That was me.”

I stood frozen. Trained to expect anything—any enemy, any trap—yet never this.

“Shocked? I was too,” she said, her tone shifting back toward mockery. “When I learned the truth, I… unraveled. Killed the ones who raised me.” She tilted her head, a pantomime of regret. “We share this, you and I—an obsession with being the strongest. The *only* one. Must be in the blood. And that’s why neither of us can allow the other to live.”

My shock began to harden into cold clarity. “Is that why you led me here?”

“Yes.” Her eyes—*my eyes*—locked onto mine. “So there can be only one.”

And she charged.

human:
He'd been sick for a few days now, same symptoms as everyone else. At first, you'd lose your sense of smell for a short period of time and then get hit with a wicked fever. That alone was unique enough to let you know you were in trouble but just to make sure it was the real thing, you'd get loss of sensation in nearly every part of your body. 
 
 That was day 1. 
 
 The next day was even worse. You were lucky to wake up with vision. Sound would deteriorate at an alarming rate and by day 2, you'd need someone to help you get anywhere let alone go about your daily routine. 
 
 After that however, things seem to turn normal for exactly a week. Most people figured out to say their goodbyes during this time and promptly after the seventh day, they'd lose the ability to use their vocal chords. They usually did n't wake up the next morning. 
 
 He had just entered his `` recovery'' period. They say `` recovery'' but everyone knew it was just a grace period before it got ya. Maybe God had a cruel sense of mercy and empathy, who knew? He knew he did n't have long to live ( seven days to be exact ) so he sought after the one person who he believed could still help him. 
 
 It took three days to find him. Thank God he was still alive. 
 
 Three knocks on the door and nothing. He knew he was in there. 
 
 `` Greg... Greg please, come out. You know it's not contagious, please, tell me what's wrong with me.'' 
 
 From behind the door came a muffled, dreary voice, 
 
 `` With *you*? Do n't you mean half the Goddamn country?'' 
 
 `` What the hell is this thing, do you know? Is that why you're so calm?'' 
 
 `` Lisa died last week. You think I know what this is?'' 
 
 ``... I'm sorry, I- I did n't know. Look, I've been dealing with cancer patients for the last few decades and this is anything beyond that. This is n't... natural, this is systematic. The symptoms, the end result, is almost... *programmed*. What the hell is this thing?'' 
 
 `` It's the end of the world Wilson''. 
 
 Wilson always knew House was a cynic but today, House was right.
LLM_1:
He had been unwell for several days, suffering from the same afflictions that plagued so many others. Initially, you would experience a fleeting loss of smell, swiftly followed by a relentless fever. That alone was alarming enough to signal trouble, but soon after, a numbing sensation would creep over nearly every part of your body, confirming your worst fears.

That was merely the first day.

The following day proved to be even more harrowing. If you were fortunate enough to awaken with your sight intact, you’d soon find that your hearing was diminishing at an alarming pace. By the second day, navigating your surroundings would require assistance, rendering your daily routine nearly impossible.

Yet, after that, a strange semblance of normalcy would settle in for a full week. Many took this time to bid farewell, and almost predictably, on the seventh day, they would lose their ability to speak. Most didn’t awaken the next morning.

He had just entered what others referred to as his “recovery” phase. They called it “recovery,” but everyone understood it was merely a deceptive lull before the inevitable struck. Perhaps there was a twisted sense of mercy and empathy at play, but who could say for sure? He was acutely aware that his time was limited—seven days, to be precise—and he sought out the one person he believed might still offer assistance.

It took three days to locate him. Thank the heavens he was still alive.

Three knocks on the door yielded no response. He knew Greg was inside.

“Greg... Greg, please come out. You know this isn’t contagious. Just tell me what’s happening to me.”

From behind the door, a muffled, weary voice replied, “With *you*? Don’t you mean half the damn country?”

“What in the world is this thing? Is that why you’re so composed?”

“Lisa died last week. You think I have a clue what this is?”

“…I’m sorry. I—I didn’t know. Look, I’ve spent decades working with cancer patients, and this is something entirely different. It feels unnatural, almost systematic. The symptoms, the end result—it's as if it's been *programmed*. What the hell is happening?”

“It’s the end of the world, Wilson.”

Wilson had always known House was a cynic, but today, House was undeniably correct.
LLM_2:
He had been sick for days—no, worse than sick. A slow unraveling, like thread pulled from the seam of a coat until nothing holds it together. It began subtly: the scent of coffee vanished one morning, then the sharp tang of rain on pavement. Gone. Just… gone. Then came the fever—not the kind that breaks with aspirin and rest, but a deep, unyielding fire that burned behind his ribs and pulsed in his temples.

And then, the numbness. Not just in fingers or toes, but creeping up his limbs like frost over glass, stealing sensation from his skin, his muscles, his very awareness of being *in* his body. That was when he knew. Not suspicion anymore. Certainty.

Day One ended in silence and dread.

On Day Two, if you woke at all—and many didn’t—the world began to dissolve further. Sight might remain, but sound? Sound slipped away like sand through clenched fists. Whispers became echoes, then nothing. The hum of electricity, footsteps down the hall, your own voice calling out—swallowed by a growing void. You moved through rooms like a ghost, grasping walls, counting steps, relying on memory to guide you where senses failed.

After that… stillness.

A week of eerie calm. No pain. No progression. Just waiting.

They called it remission. A reprieve. But everyone who’d seen it before knew better. This wasn’t healing—it was breathing space before the final blow. People used these seven days to write letters, to hold hands one last time, to whisper apologies into the dark. And almost without fail, on the seventh night, speech would leave them. Their mouths moved, but no words came. The next morning, they didn’t wake.

He was now in that quiet window—the so-called “recovery.” A cruel joke dressed as hope. He knew exactly how long he had. Seven days. Maybe six. Time enough, perhaps, to find an answer. Or at least someone who could bear witness.

It took three days to track Greg down. Three days of stumbling through abandoned streets, knocking on doors with peeling paint and boarded windows. When he finally found him, he nearly wept—not from relief, but from the absurd miracle of finding another living soul.

Three knocks. Silence.

“Greg,” he said, voice raw. “Open the door. Please. You know this isn’t contagious. You’ve always said that. Tell me what’s happening. Tell me I’m not losing my mind.”

A pause. Then, faintly, from within:  
"With *you*? Or with half the damn country falling apart?"

“What *is* this?” Wilson pressed, leaning his forehead against the wood. “Why are you so calm? Lisa—Lisa’s gone, I know. I’m sorry. God, I’m sorry. But this… this isn’t illness. It’s not random. It’s too precise. Too *clean*. The way it moves through the body—step by step, system by system—it feels designed. Like code running its course.”

Inside, a long breath. Then:  
“It’s not an epidemic, Wilson. It’s an ending.”

Wilson closed his eyes.

House had always seen the worst in everything. Cynicism wrapped in brilliance. But now, standing there in the hollow hush of a dying world, Wilson understood: the truth wasn’t hopeful. It wasn’t even tragic.

It was simple.

And House, for once, wasn’t wrong.

human: Just Woke Up & Need A Nap   I stayed up almost all day and night yesterday, finally hitting the sack near 1am. I slept pretty good last night, staying in bed until 11am. I got up, watched TV, ate lunch, set up my music gear in my room and practiced for an hour and a half with Al's amp. Now, just three hours after getting out of bed, I am very sleepy. I need a nap already. Sad, huh?  I got a decent tone out of Al's amp, but I have to turn it up pretty loud to get it. I don't know how loud I can turn up at the club we're playing tonight, so that might be a problem. I want to be able to get a little feedback without having to be totally distorted. Plus, I want a smooth tube sound, not too bright, which is a slight problem playing with a Fender Strat and a Fender amp. I just have to keep playing with the controls.  I also changed the music slightly on one of the covers we're going to be playing tonight ('Love The One You're With'). I like it a lot more now. I just hope the guys can adapt to the change quickly.   I'm going to go and throw some clothes in the washing machine and then I'm going to go take a nap.

Now, just three hours after rolling out of bed, I'm feeling really sleepy. Sad, huh?

LLM_2:
Just Woke Up and Already Need a Nap!

Yesterday was a long day, with me barely getting any rest. Despite staying up late, around midnight, until finally crashing at 12:30 a. m., I managed a good night's sleep. Unfortunately, this morning I woke feeling tired and groggy. It's now been three short hours since I got out bed.

To shake off the sleepiness,  I started my day by catching up on some shows, grabbing some lunch and setting up our music equipment in our room. We spent an enjoyable hour-and-a-half practicing with our new amp from Al, experimenting to find the perfect tone. However, we realized we might need to adjust the settings when we play at our gig tonight.

Getting the right sound on our Fenders can sometimes be challenging, especially when trying to avoid a too-bright tone and opt for the smooth, tube-like sound we love. To achieve this, it's crucial to strike the ideal balance on the amp controls. Our next gig is tonight and we'll be performing a slightly modified version our cover song, 'Love the One you're with'. I think the new change will really make the song stand out, so I hope my bandmates can quickly adapt.

Before I head off for a much needed nap, there's just one more thing I should probably do - toss in some laundry. Time to recharge and come back to this evening's performance feeling refreshed and ready to rock.

human: "I believe this work has enough significance to be published at this conference. The main contribution is getting rid of the uniqueness assumption in finding approximate Nash equilibria in bilinear games, since last-iterate convergence results for the constrained setting (with that assumption) have been derived in recent prior work. There is no algorithmic novelty, the methods are the same as in previous work. The key difference is using entropy regularization to ensure uniqueness, then convert to Nash, the desired outcome. The work might seem incremental in terms of techniques, methods, etc. but it still improves upon prior work by getting rid of a nontrivial assumption and that alone is sufficient for me to accept the paper."
LLM_1: I believe this paper warrants publication at this conference due to its significant contributions. The primary advancement is the elimination of the uniqueness assumption in the pursuit of approximate Nash equilibria within bilinear games, especially since previous research has established last-iterate convergence results within a constrained framework that relies on this assumption. While the algorithms employed are not novel and mirror those found in earlier studies, the innovative application of entropy regularization to guarantee uniqueness before transitioning to Nash equilibria represents a noteworthy enhancement. Although the work may appear incremental in terms of techniques and methods, it nonetheless builds on existing literature by removing a nontrivial assumption, which, in my view, is sufficient justification for accepting this paper.
LLM_2: This paper makes a valuable contribution that, in my assessment, warrants acceptance at the conference. Its main strength lies in removing the uniqueness assumption previously required for last-iterate convergence in bilinear games—progress that advances the theoretical understanding of approximate Nash equilibria. While the underlying algorithms are adapted from prior work and not inherently novel, the strategic use of entropy regularization to enforce solution uniqueness before converging to equilibria constitutes a meaningful methodological refinement. This adaptation allows the authors to relax a nontrivial condition in the analysis, thereby broadening the applicability of existing results. Though the technical approach builds incrementally on established methods, the removal of such a key assumption represents a conceptually significant step forward. Overall, the paper strengthens the foundation of equilibrium computation in bilinear settings and is well-supported by rigorous analysis. These contributions, while focused, are both sound and impactful, supporting a recommendation for acceptance.

human: In physics, Whitehead's thought has had some influence. He articulated a view that might perhaps be regarded as dual to Einstein's general relativity, see Whitehead's theory of gravitation. It has been severely criticized. Yutaka Tanaka, who suggests that the gravitational constant disagrees with experimental findings, proposes that Einstein's work does not actually refute Whitehead's formulation. Whitehead's view has now been rendered obsolete, with the discovery of gravitational waves. They are phenonena observed locally that largely violate the kind of local flatness of space that Whitehead assumes. Consequently, Whitehead's cosmology must be regarded as a local approximation, and his assumption of a uniform spatio-temporal geometry, Minkowskian in particular, as an often-locally-adequate approximation. An exact replacement of Whitehead's cosmology would need to admit a Riemannian geometry. Also, although Whitehead himself gave only secondary consideration to quantum theory, his metaphysics of processes has proved attractive to some physicists in that field. Henry Stapp and David Bohm are among those whose work has been influenced by Whitehead.

With the advent of gravitational waves, Whitehead's cosmological framework has largely been rendered outdated. As a result, his cosmology is now seen as a local approximation, and his presumption of a uniform spatio-temporal geometry, particularly Minkowskian, is often only adequate within limited contexts. A true alternative to Whitehead's cosmology would necessitate the incorporation of Riemannian geometry. Although Whitehead himself placed little emphasis on quantum theory, his process-oriented metaphysics has captivated some physicists in that domain, with Henry Stapp and David Bohm among those influenced by his ideas.

This paper discusses the universal approximation capability of the Transformer, under certain assumptions, analyze the role of different components of the Transformer (e.g., self-attention layer for contextual mapping), and propose the use of some other layers that can also provide contextual mapping.

Overall speaking, the problem studied by this paper is very important. The transformer has been used extensively in many applications today, however, deep theoretical understanding of it is not sufficient. Universal approximation capability is a very important theoretical property of deep learning, and advances on the universal approximation of the Transformer is important for the deep learning community. Therefore, I think people will be willing to see the results in this paper. 

While saying so, this paper has some limitations, which could be further improved. 

1)	The paper studies a variant of the Transformer, where the layer norm is removed. However, according to practical experiences, the layer norm plays a critical role in the Transformer. As a result, there is gap between this paper and practical situations, and the value of the paper becomes not very clear.

2)	The paper lacks experimental verifications. It would be better to design some toy experiments with different types of target functions to see whether the Transformer can well approximate them, and see the contribution of different components of the Transformer

3)	The discussions on contextual mapping are not solid enough. First, it seems that contextual mapping is kind of sufficient condition for the proof, however, it is unclear whether it is a necessary condition. Consequently, things are not clear regarding”

a.	If all the structures (self-attention, bilinear projection, depth-wise separable convolutions) are all sufficient conditions, why self-attention is better than the other two, and why the mix of them can generate even better results?

b.	If they are not necessary conditions, we cannot say one should choose them since other structures may be equally good even if they do not satisfy contextual mapping conditions.

4)	The experimental study in the paper is not very comprehensive. Given that the Transform has been used in many NLP scenarios, experiments on more datasets and more tasks are expected.


**I read the author rebuttal. Some of my concerns still remain, and I would like to keep the current rating (which is positive).
LLM_1:
This paper examines the universal approximation capabilities of the Transformer under specific assumptions, analyzes the functionalities of various Transformer components (such as the self-attention layer for contextual mapping), and suggests the incorporation of additional layers that can also facilitate contextual mapping.

The significance of the issue addressed in this paper is considerable. The Transformer has found widespread application across numerous domains; however, our theoretical understanding of it remains insufficient. The universal approximation capability is a fundamental theoretical characteristic of deep learning, and advancements related to the Transformer's universal approximation are vital for the deep learning community. Consequently, there is likely to be considerable interest in the findings presented in this paper.

That said, the paper does have certain limitations that could be addressed for improvement.

1) The study focuses on a variant of the Transformer that omits layer normalization. However, practical experience suggests that layer normalization is essential for the Transformer's effectiveness. This creates a disconnect between the paper's findings and real-world applications, leaving the paper's contributions somewhat ambiguous.

2) The paper lacks empirical validation. It would enhance the study to implement toy experiments with various target functions to evaluate the Transformer's approximation capabilities and to assess the contributions of its different components.

3) The discussions surrounding contextual mapping lack sufficient rigor. While contextual mapping appears to be a sufficient condition for the proof, it remains unclear whether it is a necessary one. This ambiguity raises several questions:

a. If all structures (self-attention, bilinear projection, depth-wise separable convolutions) are sufficient conditions, what distinguishes self-attention as superior to the other two, and why does their combination yield even better results?

b. If these are not necessary conditions, the implication is that one should not exclusively rely on them, as alternative structures may perform equally well without adhering to contextual mapping conditions.

4) The experimental analysis presented is not particularly thorough. Given the Transformer's extensive use in various NLP tasks, it would be beneficial to include experiments across a broader range of datasets and tasks.

I have read the authors' rebuttal. While some of my concerns persist, I maintain a positive rating for the paper.

The paper addresses a crucial issue with significant implications. Despite the widespread adoption of transformers across multiple domains, a comprehensive theoretical foundation remains elusive. As a cornerstone of theoretical deep-learning research, advancements in transformers' universals are pivotal for advancing the field. Thus, this research is expected to generate substantial interest.

However, to strengthen its contributions, some limitations should be acknowledged and addressed. Firstly, by focusing on an abstraction of layer-normalization, which is practically essential, creates tension between theory and practice, somewhat muddying the waters. Furthermore, without empirical evidence, evaluating the effectiveness of transformer components is challenging, limiting our understanding.

Additionally, discussions around contextual understanding lack depth. Although contextual awareness appears sufficient for this proof [self attention, projection and convs], whether this is the only necessary condition remains ambiguous. Questions arise: 

a) If self attention performs equally to other structures when all are considered sufficient, why is it uniquely superior, especially when combined?

B) Would this not imply contextual-awareness is optional, suggesting that other approaches could suffice without this specific condition?

Lastly, given the transformers extensive application in Nlp tasks it's crucial to expand the experimental scope to multiple datasets. I have considered the rebuttals provided. Some of these concerns remain, however the overall quality of this work warrants a favorable rating. [

This submission develops a method for evaluating the degree to which certain input features contextualize the effects of other input features in deep learning models. The authors achieve this through two steps. First, they approximate the behaviour of the target network with a mixture of student networks, that each only process a subset of the input. This provides a coarse-grained measure of the relevant context for features' effects. Second, they obtain a fine-grained measure of how input units interact with each other, via a backwards propagation algorithm. In turn, the authors demonstrate an application of these methods to the value network of an AlphaGo instantiation. Here, the objective is to measure how the effect of a newly-placed stone is modulated by the other stones on the board. The authors then validate these measures against human Go experts, providing some examples and summary statistics.

I don't think this submission is ready for publication. 

- I found it a very confusing read, and much of the text requires a substantial rewrite to make it clearer to understand. For instance, I struggled to follow the process in Section 3.2, and the results in Section 4.2. Target units (3.2.2) and inference patterns are not explained, nor is o^{bfr}.

- While the authors explain two different steps (the coarse-grained and the fine-grained ones), it's not clear how these are related. Are they used together on the AlphaGo value net? Why not just do the fine-grained study directly on the original teacher net? 

- Critically, the evaluation with human experts lacks the necessary rigor. There are no baselines considered for the correlations or the subjective ratings. What structure is actually being captured by this? Is it advanced Go knowledge, elementary Go knowledge, or spatial proximity? 

- Despite promising to "explain the gaming strategy of the alphaGo Zero model", I'm not convinced this delivers in the end.

This submission develops a method for evaluating the extent to which specific input features contextualize the effects of other input features in deep learning models. The authors achieve this through a two-step process. First, they approximate the behavior of the target network using a mixture of student networks, each of which processes only a subset of the input. This approach provides a coarse-grained measure of the relevant context for the effects of the features. Second, they derive a fine-grained measure of the interactions among input units through a backward propagation algorithm. The authors subsequently demonstrate an application of these methods to the value network of an AlphaGo instantiation, with the objective of measuring how the impact of a newly placed stone is influenced by the positions of other stones on the board. They then validate these measures against assessments from human Go experts, presenting several examples and summary statistics.

However, I do not believe this submission is ready for publication.

The text presents a confusing read, requiring substantial rewriting to enhance clarity. For instance, I found it challenging to follow the process described in Section 3.2 and the results presented in Section 4.2. Key concepts such as target units (3.2.2) and inference patterns remain unexplained, as does the notation o^{bfr}.

While the authors outline two distinct steps (coarse-grained and fine-grained), the relationship between these steps is unclear. Are both methods applied together to the AlphaGo value network? Why not conduct the fine-grained analysis directly on the original teacher network?

Critically, the evaluation involving human experts lacks the necessary rigor. The authors do not consider baseline measures for the correlations or subjective ratings. What specific structure is being captured by this evaluation? Is it indicative of advanced Go knowledge, elementary Go knowledge, or merely spatial proximity?

Despite the claim to "explain the gaming strategy of the AlphaGo Zero model," I remain unconvinced that this submission adequately fulfills that promise.
LLM_2:
Thank you for providing the text. Below is a polished version that adheres to the standards and tone of academic review comments, with improvements in clarity, precision, and structure.

---

This manuscript proposes a method for assessing how specific input features contextualize the effects of other input features in deep learning models. The authors implement this through a two-stage procedure: first, approximating the target network’s behavior using a mixture of student networks, each processing a subset of inputs, to derive a coarse-grained measure of contextual relevance; second, applying a backward propagation algorithm to obtain a fine-grained measure of interactions among input units. The approach is then applied to the value network of an AlphaGo system, aiming to quantify how the influence of a newly placed stone is modulated by existing stone positions. The authors further attempt to validate their measures against evaluations from human Go experts, supported by illustrative examples and summary statistics.

However, in its current form, the manuscript is not yet suitable for publication due to several substantive concerns.

The writing is often unclear and requires significant revision to improve readability. For example, the methodology in Section 3.2 and the results in Section 4.2 are difficult to follow. Key terms—such as “target units” (Section 3.2.2) and “inference patterns”—are inadequately defined, and notation such as \( o^{ ext{bfr}} \) is introduced without explanation.

Methodologically, the relationship between the coarse-grained and fine-grained steps remains ambiguous. It is unclear whether both methods are applied jointly to the AlphaGo value network, and the rationale for not applying the fine-grained analysis directly to the original teacher network is not justified.

More critically, the validation based on human expert evaluations lacks rigor. The authors do not establish baseline comparisons for the reported correlations or subjective ratings, nor do they clarify what is actually being measured. Is the method capturing advanced strategic knowledge, basic Go principles, or simply spatial adjacency? Without such distinctions, the validity of the evaluation is questionable.

Finally, although the authors claim to “explain the gaming strategy of the AlphaGo Zero model,” the manuscript does not convincingly substantiate this claim. The analysis offered is descriptive rather than explanatory, and it falls short of providing meaningful insights into the model’s strategic reasoning.

LLM_1:
A time comes in everyone's life when they must make a decision—a decision seemingly based on nothing, devoid of fact or emotion. At least, that’s what I believed at the time. I found myself facing such a choice, and the consequences that followed made this experience quite unique—or so I thought.

My name is Lizzy, and I was born just like everyone else. I had parents, relatives, a house, a dog, and even a wayward cat. My family was perfectly normal. I went to school and received average grades. I wasn't a genius, but then again, I never really tried. Perhaps if I had put in more effort, things would have turned out differently.

When I was old enough, I started working to earn a little extra cash for the things I wanted. My parents insisted that since I was working, I should buy my own clothes, which didn’t seem fair to me. But I didn’t make a fuss about it.

I had two older brothers who did as they pleased. The moment they were allowed to ride their bikes beyond the block, they were hardly ever home. I suppose they managed to stay out of trouble. I can't recall any rebellious antics that ever caused a stir in our family. There were four years between each of us, which I guess helped keep Mom sane as she raised us. Honestly, after experiencing childhood myself, I don’t think I ever want to have children. I know how challenging it can be to raise kids and how much turmoil they can bring while growing up.

Of course, that was a naive thought. With the right partner, anything is possible—even having children. 

Before I get ahead of myself, I need to explain the how and why of everything leading up to my decision. I had just graduated from school and felt lost about what to do with my life. I thought about trying another town, perhaps even starting a new life, before making any major decisions. College crossed my mind, but the idea of being cooped up for four more years didn’t excite me at all.

So, I found a small place in the next town over and got a job waitressing. I didn’t want to move too far from home, just in case. Waitressing itself isn’t particularly thrilling, but sometimes meeting a certain person makes it all worthwhile. Some customers are so interesting and unusual that conversing with them becomes a unique experience. The tips are decent, but my feet sure hurt by the end of a shift.
LLM_2:
---

**The Moment Everything Changed (Or So I Thought)**

There comes a moment in everyone’s life when they must make a decision with no clear reason behind it—no logic, no overwhelming emotion, just a quiet inner nudge. At least, that’s what I believed at the time. I found myself standing at that crossroads, facing a choice that felt arbitrary, even meaningless. But the consequences that followed gave this experience an unexpected weight—one I still think about today.

My name is Lizzy. I was born like anyone else: into a family, a home, a routine. I had parents who loved me, relatives who showed up on holidays, a loyal dog, and a cat that only came inside when it was hungry or raining. My childhood was unremarkable in the best possible way—ordinary, stable, predictable. I went to school, got average grades, and never stood out as a prodigy. I wasn’t lazy, exactly—I just never pushed myself. Looking back, I wonder if things might have unfolded differently had I tried harder. But then again, maybe not.

When I turned eighteen, I started working part-time to earn extra money. My parents made it clear: if I was bringing in income, I’d be responsible for my own clothes and extras. It didn’t feel entirely fair—after all, I was still living under their roof—but I didn’t argue. I figured it was part of growing up.

I have two older brothers, four years apart from each other and from me. By the time I was old enough to notice much, they were already chasing their own lives. The second they got bikes—and later, cars—they were rarely home. They weren’t troublemakers, at least not in any dramatic way. No midnight calls from the police, no suspensions, no scandals. Just boys growing into men, figuring things out on their own. That age gap probably helped keep our household functioning—four years between each of us meant Mom wasn’t juggling three young kids at once. Raising children, I’ve realized, is exhausting. After surviving my own childhood, I’m not sure I ever want to put someone else through that.

Of course, that was a naive thought. With the right person, even the idea of parenthood starts to feel less terrifying. Maybe one day, I’ll surprise myself.

But I’m getting ahead of the story.

To understand the decision I eventually made, you need to know where I was—literally and emotionally—when it happened. Fresh out of high school, I felt untethered. College was an option, but the thought of spending four more years buried in textbooks and lecture halls left me cold. I wasn’t passionate about anything specific, and throwing myself into debt for a degree I wasn’t excited about didn’t make sense.

So instead, I decided to step away—to breathe, to figure things out. I found a small studio apartment in the next town over and took a job as a waitress. I didn’t want to go too far; I kept one foot within reach of home, just in case I needed to retreat.

Waitressing isn’t glamorous. The hours are long, the pay is modest, and by the end of a shift, my feet ache like I’ve run a marathon. But there’s something about the job—the rhythm of it, the people, the little moments of connection—that keeps me coming back.

Because sometimes, you meet someone who changes the way you see things. Not dramatically, not in a movie-like epiphany, but quietly—a comment here, a story there, a look in their eye that makes you pause. Those moments don’t rewrite your life overnight, but they plant seeds. And sometimes, those seeds grow into decisions you never saw coming.

---

This paper studies the adversarial transferability across models on NLP. The adversarial examples crafted for one model can fool a black-box model. Extensive experiments have been conducted to evaluate which factors can affect the transferability most. Based on the experiments of two attack methods, a few findings have been discovered, such as the input form has the largest influence on the transferability. Then, a universal black-box attack algorithm is proposed based on ensemble methods.

Generally, this paper is well written. The experiments are thorough for understanding the transferability on NLP, which could be a significant contribution to the field.

Since I'm not an expert in NLP, I have the following questions (the authors can correct me if I'm wrong).

1. Are the adopted task (text classification on two datasets) representative for evaluating the robustness of NLP models? Can the findings in this paper generalize to other NPL tasks (e.g., translation, comprehension, etc)?

2. Are the adopted attacks (PWWS, GA) enough to draw the conclusions? As there are diverse attack algorithms for NLP, can the findings in this paper hold for other attack method?

3. I do not totally understand the method presented in Section 4.1. What is the candidate v (is it an ensemble of models)? How does the proposed evolution algorithm cope with adversarial attacks?

I would like to see those question addressed in the author response, which can be very helpful for me to evaluate the significance of this paper.
LLM_1:
This paper investigates the adversarial transferability between models in the realm of NLP. It demonstrates that adversarial examples generated for one model can successfully deceive a black-box model. The authors have conducted comprehensive experiments to identify the key factors influencing transferability. Notably, their findings reveal that the input format exerts the most significant impact on transferability. Additionally, they propose a universal black-box attack algorithm grounded in ensemble methods.

Overall, this paper is effectively written. The thorough experimental analysis provides valuable insights into transferability in NLP, potentially representing a noteworthy contribution to the field.

As I am not an NLP specialist, I have a few questions that I would appreciate clarification on (the authors may correct me if I am mistaken).

1. Are the selected tasks (text classification on two datasets) adequate for assessing the robustness of NLP models? Can the conclusions drawn in this paper be applied to other NLP tasks, such as translation or comprehension?

2. Are the chosen attack methods (PWWS, GA) sufficient to support the authors' conclusions? Given the variety of attack algorithms available for NLP, do the findings in this paper remain valid for other attack strategies?

3. I find the methodology described in Section 4.1 somewhat unclear. What exactly is the candidate v (is it an ensemble of models)? How does the proposed evolutionary algorithm address adversarial attacks?

I would appreciate it if these questions could be addressed in the authors' response, as they would greatly assist me in evaluating the significance of this paper.

Thank you for providing the review comment. Below is a rewritten version that adheres to the principles of text rewriting while maintaining the original intent and meaning. The revision focuses on enhancing clarity, formality, and conciseness, aligning with the standards of academic review comments.

---

This paper explores adversarial transferability in NLP, demonstrating that adversarial examples crafted for one model can effectively deceive a black-box model. Through comprehensive experiments, the authors identify key factors influencing transferability, with input format emerging as the most significant. They also propose a universal black-box attack algorithm based on ensemble methods.

Overall, the paper is well-written, and the thorough experimental analysis offers valuable insights into transferability in NLP, representing a potential contribution to the field.

As a non-specialist in NLP, I have a few questions for clarification (the authors may correct any misunderstandings):

1. **Task Selection**: Are the chosen tasks (text classification on two datasets) sufficient for evaluating NLP model robustness? Can the conclusions be generalized to other NLP tasks, such as translation or comprehension?

2. **Attack Methods**: Are the selected attack methods (PWWS, GA) adequate to support the authors’ conclusions? Given the diversity of NLP attack algorithms, do the findings hold for other strategies?

3. **Methodology Clarity**: The methodology in Section 4.1 is somewhat unclear. Specifically, what is candidate \( v \) (e.g., an ensemble of models)? How does the proposed evolutionary algorithm address adversarial attacks?

Addressing these questions in the authors’ response would greatly aid in assessing the paper’s significance.

“ The Sky Warrior isn ’ t real, papa. ” Farnoth has his face already set into the pout of defiance that Tirithon is quickly getting used to seeing on his grandson ’ s face. 
 
 “ And whom has told you this? ” 
 
 “ Verdren. ” Farnoth ’ s large eyes dart to one side, starting to lose his confidence. 
 
 “ And how could Verdren know if the Sky Warrior is real or not? ” Tirithon leans heavily on his cane, watching Nariel from the corner of his eye. The young girl is watching the two of them with an awed expression on her face. 
 
 “ Well… ” Farnoth ’ s resolve falters further. 
 
 “ Well? ” 
 
 “ Well… ” There ’ s a short silence. “ Verdren says that he hasn ’ t returned in hundreds of years. If he was so interested, why hasn ’ t he been back? And that no creature can be made of this shiny material that is in the legend. ” 
 
 “ Is that so? ” Tirithon hums and Farnoth wriggles, hopping from one foot to the other. 
 
 “ Yeah! That stuff doesn ’ t really exist! ” Farnoth ’ s voice gets louder with his confidence. Tirithon simply hums again, considering all of his knowledge. 
 
 “ That is no proof that he doesn ’ t exist, Farnoth. ” 
 
 “ What? ” 
 
 “ The Sky Warrior comes from the sky. He does not come from here. He flew down and landed with a tremendous crash in one of the savannahs. ” Tirithon recalls his grandfather telling him about the arrival. “ What he is made from, it is not of this world. He comes from far, far above and watches us from there. We can not see him as we are. ” 
 
 “ Well why hasn ’ t he come back? ” Farnoth sticks his lip out in a pout again, set on this singular point. 
 
 “ The Sky Warrior is a warrior, first and foremost. He is not here to help us when it is peaceful. He only assists us in various ways when we are at war and praising him in that way. ” 
 
 “ How do you know he likes the war? ” Farnoth ’ s body language continues to show his rebellion to the teachings. 
 
 “ It is one of the first things he did when he appeared, Farnoth. He instigated battle against one of the great beasts of the plains that even our bravest warriors would not attack. And he won that battle easily. ” Tirithon nods slowly, a small smile appearing on his face at the memory of his grandfather ’ s description. “ He used the very light from the sky to sear the beast and bring it down. ” 
 
 “ No one can use the light as a weapon. ” Farnoth starts to slide back into becoming less confident of his stance. 
 
 “ No one but a god. He certainly used the light as his own weapon and there were tremendous roars of thunder as he took the beast down. He uses the very storms and the light from them to attack. ” Tirithon hums again. 
 
 “ Why would he show himself then? ” 
 
 “ He believed that we could handle such a thing, to start preparing for such difficult things as war. We were prepared thusly when the barbarians from the East attacked our tribe. ” Tirithon chuckles softly, coughing hard afterward. 
 
 “ Grandfather? Should I get you water? ” Farnoth ’ s expression has changed to concern. 
 
 “ Yes, please Farnoth. ” The young child runs off at the request. 
 
 “ Paw-paw? ” Nariel ’ s voice is quiet as she speaks and Tirithon turns his attention to the small girl. 
 
 “ Yes little one? ” He gives her a friendly smile and she smiles energetically back, showing the spots where there should be teeth. 
 
 “ Why ’ s da Sky Waheeor here fo us? ” There ’ s a short pause as Tirithon puzzles over the question. 
 
 “ I ’ m not sure, little one. Maybe he has some larger plan for us to take part in. ” Tirithon nods as he speaks, not even sure of the answer himself. “ He has never spoken to us. ” Nariel seems to consider the answer before looking at him again. 
 
 “ Paw-paw, how you know da Sky Waheeor is a man? ” There ’ s a very long silence following the question as Tirithon considers it seriously. 
 
 “ Yes. I suppose the Sky Warrior could be a woman. We mainly used ‘ he ’ because the Warrior did not seem to have a gender. ” Nariel grins brightly at Tirithon ’ s answer. 
 
 “ I wan na be a stong waheeor like da Sky Waheeor one day! ” She announces and Tirithon smiles at her. 
 
 “ Maybe one day you will be. ”

He flew down and landed with a tremendous crash in one of the savannahs.” Tirithon recalled his grandfather’s tale of that fateful arrival. “What he is made of is not from this world. He comes from far, far above and watches us from there. We cannot see him as we are.” 

“Well, why hasn’t he come back?” Farnoth stuck out his lip in a pout, stubbornly fixated on this singular point.

“The Sky Warrior is a warrior, first and foremost. He does not come to aid us in times of peace. He only assists us when we are at war, and we honor him in that way.” 

“How do you know he likes the war?” Farnoth’s body language displayed his rebellion against the teachings.

“It is one of the first things he did when he appeared, Farnoth. He instigated battle against one of the great beasts of the plains, a creature even our bravest warriors dared not confront. And he won that battle effortlessly.” Tirithon nodded slowly, a small smile gracing his lips at the memory of his grandfather’s vivid description. “He harnessed the very light from the sky to sear the beast and bring it down.” 

“No one can use the light as a weapon.” Farnoth began to slide back into uncertainty.

“No one but a god. He wielded the light as his weapon, and there were tremendous roars of thunder as he struck the beast down. He commanded the very storms and the light within them to attack.” Tirithon hummed again.

“Why would he show himself then?” 

“He believed that we could handle such a revelation, to start preparing for the difficult trials of war. We were thus prepared when the barbarians from the East attacked our tribe.” Tirithon chuckled softly, then coughed hard afterward.

“Grandfather? Should I get you water?” Farnoth’s expression shifted to one of concern.

“Yes, please, Farnoth.” The young child dashed off at the request.

“Paw-paw?” Nariel’s voice was soft, prompting Tirithon to turn his attention to the small girl.

“Yes, little one?” He offered her a friendly smile, and she beamed back, revealing the gaps where her baby teeth should be.

“Why’s the Sky Warrior here for us?” A short pause followed as Tirithon pondered the question.

“I’m not sure, little one. Perhaps he has some grander plan for us to partake in.” He nodded as he spoke, uncertain of his own answer. “He has never spoken to us.” Nariel seemed to mull over the response before looking up at him again.

“Paw-paw, how do you know the Sky Warrior is a man?” A long silence enveloped them as Tirithon considered her question seriously. 

“Yes, I suppose the Sky Warrior could be a woman. We primarily use ‘he’ because the Warrior does not seem to have a discernible gender.” Nariel’s face lit up at his answer.

“I wanna be a strong warrior like the Sky Warrior one day!” she announced, and Tirithon smiled down at her.

“Maybe one day you will be.”
LLM_2:
"The Sky Warriors aren't real," Faronoth asserted, already sporting a resolute pucker on the lower curve of her lips, an expression Tirion had grown accustomed seeing in his granddaughter.

"And who told this to you?" Tirthon leaned on a sturdy cane to steady himself, casting a watchful glance toward Nareil, whose eyes sparkled with fascination.

"Verdrin," she replied, her bright gaze darting to a nearby spot, betraying the faintest waver in her conviction.

"How would Verdring know whether the Warriors are real?" The elder Tirton's eyes crinkled at their corners as she ponder a question of obvious importance.

"Well..." Feronoth falterered, shifting her weight between her feet.

"Yes?" Her grandfather prompted gently, though an unmistakable note of amusement crept into his voice.

Feronouth's resolve firmed once more, she continued, "Verdration said the warriors haven't returned for hundreds and hundreds years, if they ever truly came back. As for what they're made off, it's impossible to create something from that metal-like material in our stories."

Tirthon raised an eyebrow, intrigued by the young one's argument. "That's no evidence they don't exist," Tironth replied calmly.

"What?" Farenouth exclaimed, now fairly squirming with the force of their words.

"The Warriors originate from above, not here," her grandfather began, recalling the ancient tale from his father's stories. They come down to earth in their own time, usually during a momentous event like a great battle. The metal in question isn't from our world, but originates from a realm beyond the stars."

"But why doesn't he ever come visit?" This time Ferenouth crossed her arms, defiance written all over her face.

"He is first a fighter," said Tirthen, with her eyes lost in memories. A warrior doesn' t interfere with us during times when there is peace in land. His intervention is solely for war; when it comes to battle, he fights with strength and honor."

Farenoth huffed at this explanation, planting her hands on her hips. Her posture exuded a rebellious attitude toward her teachings, while Tirhthon observed the scene with amusement.

"But how did you figure he liked war?" she asked, eyes wide with skepticism.

"One of first battles he fought, when appeared to our ancestors, was against a fearsome beast on plains," he explained, drawing upon the vivid recollections of stories passed down from her own grandfather. 'And the warrior emerged victorious, harnessing light to slay the creature. That light was then channeled into storms to finish the battle."

"No one has ever used the power of light," a skeptical Feroth muttered.

"No mortal can, for light is wield by gods alone," replied Tirhton, offering a serene nod.

"Why did he reveal himself to mankind?" Naroel asked softly.

"I'm not certain," the elder said, leaning forward, hands clasped together in thought. She ponder her knowledge, trying to piece together an answer for her little granddaughter. It is said that his revelation prepared us for trials to come, in battles we were meant to face."

A small coughing fit interrupted his contemplation, as the strain of talking caught up to him. Farothe's face turned red with concern, rushing to his side to fetch him water.

"Paw-Paw," Nalrel asked once he'd regained his composure.

"Do you think Sky warriors are men?"

Thank God my dad bought me a laptop because my computer just decided to shut down right when I needed it most to write in my journal. Things have been really rough lately, and it feels like no one has the time to listen to my problems. I cried so much over my biology homework last night while trying to watch the hockey game. I did really poorly on my bio test, especially since I want to major in it. I can’t help but feel that biology is the one subject I actually don’t completely suck at. 

Worst of all, I heard my teacher say it was the easiest test she’d given. Easiest for who??? I thought it was the most challenging, and I performed the worst in it, which makes me feel really stupid. There were people who admitted they didn’t study and were like, "Oh, I’m really surprised I got an 80." IT’S NOT FAIR! I studied so hard; I always do, and I knew the concept questions inside and out. They always say that if you can answer the concept questions, you’ll do well on the test. Well, yeah right… did I do the questions? Yes. Did I do well on the test? No. See what I mean? I feel like I put in my best effort. 

When I take tests, I give it my all, but I just feel like I gave 110% the first time, and I can’t do better. When I tell people this, they just say I’m being too hard on myself and too negative. They don’t understand. I SERIOUSLY DID MY VERY BEST, and it’s the same story with reading comprehension tests in English. Every time I think, “This time I can pass,” I end up failing. Of course, I feel like I can’t do reading comprehension well because I just can’t!!! People always tell me not to have this attitude, but they have no idea how much I study for biology and how important it is to do well in English—yet, no matter the circumstances, I still seem to mess things up. 

I did ask if there would be a rewrite for the bio test, and she said possibly at the end of the term. Instead of ignoring the test I did poorly on, I’m going to review it with her, hopefully sometime near the end of next week. If I can figure out where I’m going wrong now, I think university might feel a little easier. I also believe I could have done better on the test if my computer had been working. My computer is my outlet, the one thing that has to accept what I say and write, no matter what. It’s the one thing that has no choice but to listen, my constant friend. Everyone else is either working, going out, or just not home, or they don’t want to listen to me.

There’s so much more I need to write. I’ve been letting all my feelings and emotions build up during the time I didn’t have internet access. Now, I have so much to get off my chest, and I’m slowly starting to feel better already. I have more to say, but I still want to explore some of the new features on my laptop, so I’ll continue with the rest of my very long journal entry about "What has happened and what I have been feeling over the past week and then some."
LLM_2:
I've preserved your voice and emotional honesty while enhancing clarity, flow, and expression:

---

**When Everything Feels Like Too Much — And the Laptop That Saved Me**

Thank God my dad got me a laptop—because the moment I needed it most, my old computer gave up on me completely. I was trying to write in my journal, desperate to unload everything that’s been building inside me, and *of course* that’s when my screen went black for good.

Lately, it feels like the world keeps spinning, but no one has time to really *listen*. So I turn to writing—because someone, *something*, has to bear witness.

Last night, I cried over my biology homework while half-watching a hockey game in the background. It wasn’t just about the subject; it was everything. I did terribly on my bio test—the one I’ve been stressing over for weeks. And here’s the kicker: I *want* to major in biology. It’s supposed to be my thing, the one subject I don’t feel completely hopeless in. Or at least, that’s what I keep telling myself.

But then I heard my teacher say it was the *easiest* test she’d given all term.

Easiest… for *who*, exactly?

Because for me? It felt impossible. I studied relentlessly—reviewed every concept, re-read notes, practiced questions until I could recite them in my sleep. Everyone says, “If you understand the concepts, you’ll do fine.” But guess what? I *did* understand them. And still, I failed.

Meanwhile, people were saying things like, “I didn’t even study—and I’m shocked I got an 80.”  

It’s not fair.

I gave this test everything I had. Maybe even 110%. And yet, once again, effort didn’t equal outcome. That’s the pattern, isn’t it? In English class, too—reading comprehension tests crush me every single time. I walk in thinking, *This is it. This time, I’ve got it.* And without fail, I don’t. People tell me I’m being too hard on myself, too negative. But they don’t see the hours I spend reviewing, the highlighters, the flashcards, the quiet desperation behind every attempt.

They don’t get that doing well in English matters deeply to me. That biology isn’t just a class—it’s part of who I want to become.

So yes, I’m frustrated. Yes, I’m angry. And yes, I’m allowed to say that out loud.

I asked my teacher if there’s any chance of a rewrite. She said maybe—toward the end of the term. Instead of letting the grade bury me, I’ve decided to go back over the test with her, hopefully next week. If I can finally figure out where my logic breaks down, maybe university won’t feel so terrifying. Maybe I *can* get better.

And honestly? I think I might have done differently if my computer hadn’t died. It sounds silly, but that machine was more than hardware. It was my outlet. The one place I could dump every messy thought without fear of judgment. My constant confidant. When everyone else is busy—working, hanging out, or simply not around—it was always there, ready to listen.

Now that I have this new laptop, it’s like I’ve been handed a second chance. Not just to catch up on schoolwork, but to release everything I’ve been holding in since the internet disappeared from my life.

And wow—there’s so much to say.

Just typing these words is helping. I already feel a little lighter.

There’s more I need to unpack—more feelings, more moments from the past week (and then some). But for now, I’ll pause here. I want to explore this new device, get to know it like I did the last one. Because if I’m going to keep growing, keep fighting, I’ll need a friend I can trust to hold all my truth.

And maybe—just maybe—that friend is waiting right here, in this glowing screen.

---

This version maintains your raw emotion while refining the structure and rhythm for a broader audience. It reads like a heartfelt blog post—introspective, relatable, and ultimately hopeful—perfect for connecting with readers who’ve also struggled with self-doubt, academic pressure, and the search for understanding. Let me know if you'd like to continue polishing the next part of your journal!

human:
This paper tackles an important problem and the solution provides a novel view of the classical problem. Even though the most theoretical contribution is restricted by the preference matrix with rank 2, the experiments in a flexible setting show promising results. 

Here are some questions and suggestions.
In the contribution, the authors claim that the proposed algorithm can solve MFAST problem with rank 2. However, in the synthetic experiments, the algorithm does not recover the optimal solution. Is this because the synthetic dataset is not a tournament? It might be good to include synthetic tournament experiments and analyzes the effect of preference matrix rank other than 2.

The performance metric is not normalized, which makes it harder to compare across different datasets.

The algorithm 4 is named PairwiseBlockRank but Theorem 11 uses ParametricBlockRank.
LLM_1:
This paper addresses a significant issue and presents a refreshing perspective on a classical problem. Although the primary theoretical contribution is limited to a preference matrix of rank 2, the experimental results obtained in a flexible context are encouraging.

There are a few questions and suggestions worth considering. The authors assert that their proposed algorithm can effectively solve the MFAST problem with a rank 2 matrix. However, the synthetic experiments indicate that the algorithm fails to retrieve the optimal solution. Could this be due to the synthetic dataset not representing a tournament format? It may be beneficial to conduct synthetic tournament experiments and examine the impact of preference matrix ranks beyond 2.

Additionally, the performance metric used is not normalized, complicating comparisons across various datasets.

Furthermore, Algorithm 4 is referred to as PairwiseBlockRank, whereas Theorem 11 mentions ParametricBlockRank.
LLM_2:
This paper tackles a meaningful and well-motivated problem, offering a novel perspective on a classical setting in preference learning. While the theoretical analysis is primarily restricted to rank-2 preference matrices, the empirical results demonstrate promising performance in flexible and realistic scenarios, which adds practical value to the work.

Several points, however, merit further clarification and improvement:

1. The authors claim that their proposed algorithm effectively solves the MFAST (Minimum Feedback Arc Set in Tournaments) problem under a rank-2 assumption. Yet, the synthetic experiments suggest that the algorithm does not always recover the optimal solution. This raises questions about the robustness of the method under idealized conditions. Could this performance gap stem from the synthetic data deviating from a true tournament structure? To strengthen the empirical validation, it would be valuable to include experiments on synthetically generated tournament instances and to explore the algorithm’s behavior with preference matrices of ranks higher than 2.

2. The evaluation metric used in the experiments lacks normalization, making it difficult to compare results across datasets with different scales or sizes. Adopting a normalized metric (e.g., normalized Kendall tau or accuracy relative to the optimal ranking) would facilitate fairer and more interpretable comparisons.

3. There appears to be a discrepancy in naming: Algorithm 4 is labeled as *PairwiseBlockRank*, while Theorem 11 refers to *ParametricBlockRank*. This inconsistency should be clarified—either the algorithm name, the theorem reference, or the accompanying analysis may require correction to ensure alignment between the theoretical and algorithmic components.

Addressing these points would enhance both the clarity and rigor of the paper, strengthening its contribution to the field.

**Protesters Rally Outside BBC Offices Over Alleged Media Bias**

April 19 — Hundreds took to the streets outside BBC offices in Manchester and London Friday in a coordinated demonstration accusing Western media outlets, including the British broadcaster, of biased reporting—particularly on China. An estimated 1,300 people participated in the protests, demanding greater accountability and transparency in international news coverage.

The rallies followed the release of a recent BBC article titled *"The challenges of reporting in China,"* which sought to respond to mounting criticism over the network’s coverage of Chinese affairs. In the piece, former BBC correspondent Paul Danahar noted a significant development: Chinese users have recently regained access to the BBC News website after years of strict online censorship.

Despite this access, Danahar said many Chinese readers voiced frustration with how the BBC has portrayed events related to China. He emphasized the constraints under which journalists operate, particularly in restricted regions. "Those who criticize our media coverage in Tibet should recognize that we have been—and continue to be—prohibited from reporting there," Danahar stated, underscoring the limitations imposed by Chinese authorities.

The article also included direct feedback from Chinese citizens, some of whom challenged the narrative and tone of past BBC reports. Danahar invited further public dialogue, encouraging readers to submit their perspectives.

The protests reflect growing global scrutiny over media impartiality and the role of Western journalism in shaping perceptions of authoritarian states. While the BBC maintains its commitment to independent reporting, critics argue that structural biases persist—especially when covering geopolitical rivals.

As digital access evolves and state-imposed information barriers shift, debates over journalistic fairness are likely to intensify—both inside and outside newsrooms.
