Today is a glorious day. For years I have worked to prove to my Master that I am worthy of a place at his side and I believe I have finally shown him that I am worthy of his time. At first hours my master summoned me to his private chambers, but today was not another lesson in pain or even combat practice, today was to be a test. 
 
 Deep black station has been my home ever since my Master found me and took me in. I was a stray on the streets of Trinus Prime; a small rat-girl, living in the gutters with the other sweepings. He sensed me though, sensed a potential in me and picked my out of the filthy and brought my here. At first I feared that he simply wished to torture me; during pain training I felt closer to death than life for weeks at a time, but I survived and learned to hate. 
 
 This is not to be my first test. When I was still a child they began and have grown ever since. The first was an old woman, huddled in fear in the cargo bay, left for me like a Rancor might leave a wounded Koth beast for its cub. I knew what was expected of me and ripped her to pieces with my hands, fearful that at any moment I would be set upon by some worse beast. That was the first and only time I saw my Master smile, when he entered the cargo bay and found me, crouched and ready to kill, covered in blood and gore. 
 
 From there I have done as I was bidden, never questioning, never disobeying. I know I am not my Master ’ s only trainee, I have fought and killed a dozen or more, sometimes with my hands, sometimes with blasters, or blades. In the last year I have been given lightsabers for some fights and I use them and then drop them. They are not mine and these weapons hold no significance, they are only mine so long as I use them to express my masters will. 
 
 I entered his chambers and stood to the side. He has sensed me enter, he knows my every movement, my every thought in this place. This station, *The Gathering Dark* is an expression of his dark will and exists only through his power and manipulation; it is a part of him. I am used to waiting, keeping my mind neutral and letting my senses explore my surroundings, but today I do not have to wait long. He sweeps past me and with the slightest motion I know to follow; today we are going to somewhere new. 
 
 His ship, the *Vituperative* is a thing of beauty, almost out of place among his other ugly belongings, like myself. It was built long ago by a small faction in the Fondor Shipyards, hoping for a contract from smugglers that never came. How he acquired it I have never known, but I have seen it outrun or destroy ships a dozen times its size with seemingly little effort. She is sleek, a long sliver running back to two massive engines, with fins running down the side that make her twist in your vision and seem stranger than she is. This is the only thing of beauty allowed on *The Gathering*. 
 
 We leave and my master plots a course and I see we are headed to the Aleen System. I know a little of this place from my training, the air on the ground is highly poisonous, but it will not bother me. I spent much time being exposed to thousands of compounds and building up immunity to them. The air on Aleen may harm me eventually, but it would take months of exposure and until then I will be able to breath without problems. 
 
 The world though is of little importance, I recall from my lessons that it has a small population, split between the surface and the deep core and I wonder if my mission will be to destroy these people. I would welcome that mission; destruction of a civilisation is something that few can aspire to do and this would technically be two civilisations, a rare prize. 
 
 Soon we touched down on the surface of Aleen and finally my Master turned to me and signalled for me to step forward. I have not heard his voice for more than two years and for a second it surprised me, but I am careful to mask my feelings, so he senses noting. I am surprised that I now have the power to do that, but I have grown strong. 
 
 His gaze travelled over me, as if seeing me for the first time. I am dressed simply, in dark clothes and the usual hooded cloak. “ A ’ Kayi, you have done well, grown strong, passed your tests. I am pleased. Now you will finally pass a test to see if you are truly worthy of any more of my time. ” I bowed my head and waited to hear who I would be killing. 
 
 “ Bring me the two lightsabers from the two Jedi who infect this planet. ” He smiled and then hit the button and behind me I heard the door hiss open. I paused for a moment, expecting to be given a weapon of my own, but none is forthcoming and so I turned, walked to the door and stepped out onto the cold planet. 
 
 **** 
 
 This world is dusty and foul, the wind whips the irritating brown sand into my face and for a moment I allow anger to spark in my heart, but I push it down, I save it for later. Somewhere behind me I hear my Master leaving, the whine of the great engines slowly dying as he ascends into the atmosphere. 
 
 The storm rages around me and I pull material across my face to keep the dust from my mouth, but it irritates my eyes. I close them and let my senses stretch out and I feel the planet around me, feel the storm raging as the air moves and beats against the ground, wearing the rocks into dust and then throwing it against my face. I begin to walk again, but now I use the storm to guide me, to push me onwards, letting it aid me and pull me along, guiding my to what I am looking for. 
 
 There is life here, small pathetic life but still just worthy of the name. In a few short hours I arrive at one of their villages, although it is hardly worthy of the name. The Aleena, a small and pathetic species, but despite their hovels, they can prove dangerous. They are fast and can carry weapons, I will enjoy destroying them. 
 
 The storm has dissipated somewhat, but is still strong enough to keep them indoors. I sense sixteen life forms, ten in smaller hovels but six in the larger structure towards the end of the town, if it can be called that. 
 
 The first door flies off its hinges into the house with ease and I stoop to enter the small house. Three of the pathetic creatures huddle in fear at the other side of the house and I wait to see if they will attack. They do not, they are too consumed with fear and I crush their heads with the force, enjoying the crunching. Their home holds nothing of value and I want nothing so I leave without touching a thing. 
 
 My eyes are still closed, but I am enjoying this, it is like one of the simpler tasks my master would set when I was young, to travel about one of his mazes and avoid the traps with my eyes and hands bound. 
 
 The next hovel contains four and this time I simply open the door and enjoy the fear as they scrabble away from me. Interesting though, one has a gun, a crude rifle. He holds it threateningly and squeaks something at me that I ignore. I dismantle the rifle into thirty seven different parts and then whirl them around to turn the inhabitants into a find red mush. All except the owner of the rile that is, he will be my warning. I sever his spinal cord and leave him on the floor, a witness who is unable to communicate, I like that. Maybe someone will find him before the wild animals of this planet do; after a moment I leave the door open to make it interesting. 
 
 That leaves two buildings with life forms, one with three and then the one at the end with six. I am disappointed by the hovel with three; they make no effort and seem to die almost willingly. You would assume that they value their lives but they make so little effort it is hard to believe. I now approach the last building and finally I have tired of having my eyes closed, I will enjoy this last building fully. 
 
 The doors on this building are larger, it is some sort of town hall perhaps. The beings inside are gathered around a table and I first anchor them to the ground and sense as they begin to panic and squirm, trying to free themselves, unable to work out why they are suddenly stuck firm. I walk in and some primal part of their brains tells them to panic. 
 
 “ Be calm little ones. ” I demand and they relax, becoming open and calm “ I am looking for the Jedi who are on this planet. ” At the mention of Jedi I sense them become alert. They have seen them. I put more power into my words. “ ***Where are the Jedi. *** 
 
 The one who sat at the head of the table now answered in his squeaking voice. “ They are with the Kindalo! ” He pointed towards the wall where a crude map showed the local area and I pulled it to me and strode to the leader. 
 
 “ Where are they? ” I made my voice pleasant but no less demanding. He pointed with a shaking finger to what looked like a cave entrance. Good enough, the Kindalo lived under the surface, these beings were of no more use. 
 
 I reached out with the force and felt their beating hearts, thumping with terror as I pinned them down. I began to massage their hearts with the force, making them slow bit by bit, at first calming them and then as the beats dropped below the point where they normally sat they realised that something was wrong. I released them and they clutched at their chests, their lives slowly slipping away and then as I finally stopped their hearts one by one I watched them gasp their last breaths out. Hardly a challenge but there had been some small degree of fun to be had and at least I now had a location for the Jedi. 
 
 *****

LLM_1:
Today dawns with resplendent glory. For countless years, I have toiled to demonstrate my worthiness to my Master, and at last, I believe I have proven myself deserving of his attention. Initially, my Master summoned me to his private quarters for lessons steeped in pain and combat; however, today marks a pivotal test.

The deep, shadowy station has been my refuge ever since my Master discovered me and took me in. I was a mere waif on the streets of Trinus Prime, a small rat-girl navigating the filth with the other discarded souls. Yet he felt a spark within me, a potential he recognized, and plucked me from the grime to bring me here. In the beginning, I feared he intended only to inflict torment upon me; through weeks of brutal training, I often felt closer to death than life itself. Yet, I survived and learned to embrace the hatred that blossomed within.

This is not my first trial. They began in my childhood and have only intensified since. The first was an elderly woman cowering in fear in the cargo bay, left for me like a Rancor might leave a wounded Koth beast for its young. Understanding what was expected, I tore her apart with my bare hands, terrified that a greater beast might pounce upon me. That was the first and only moment I ever witnessed my Master smile, entering the cargo bay to find me, crouched and bloodied, poised to kill.

From that moment, I followed his commands without question, never once defying him. I am aware that I am not my Master’s sole apprentice; I have fought and slain a dozen adversaries or more, sometimes with my hands, other times wielding blasters or blades. In the past year, I have been entrusted with lightsabers for several encounters, using them only to discard them afterward. They are not mine; these weapons hold no significance beyond serving my Master’s will.

As I entered his chambers, I positioned myself at the side. He sensed my arrival, aware of every motion, every thought I harbored within this space. The station, *The Gathering Dark*, embodies his dark will, existing solely through his power and manipulation; it is an extension of him. I am accustomed to waiting, clearing my mind and allowing my senses to roam, yet today, my wait is brief. He sweeps past me, and with a subtle gesture, I know to follow; today, we venture to an unfamiliar destination.

His ship, the *Vituperative*, is a marvel, strikingly beautiful amid his other grim possessions, much like myself. Crafted long ago by a small faction at the Fondor Shipyards, it was intended for smugglers who never arrived. How he acquired it remains a mystery, yet I have witnessed it effortlessly outmaneuver or obliterate vessels many times its size. Sleek and elongated, its design features two massive engines and fins that create a mesmerizing illusion, making it appear stranger than it truly is. This ship stands as the only beauty permitted aboard *The Gathering*.

As we depart, my master charts a course, and I realize we are bound for the Aleen System. My training has imparted some knowledge about this place; the air on the surface is highly toxic, yet I remain unfazed. I have endured exposure to countless compounds, building resilience against them. Though the air of Aleen might eventually harm me, it would require months of exposure to affect me, and for now, I can breathe without hindrance.

The world itself holds little significance; I recall from my lessons that its population is sparse, divided between the surface and the depths, and I ponder if my mission entails the annihilation of these beings. I would welcome such a task; the destruction of a civilization is a rare honor, and this would represent two, a coveted prize indeed.

Soon, we touch down on Aleen's surface, and finally, my Master turns to me, signaling for me to advance. It has been over two years since I last heard his voice, and for a fleeting moment, I am taken aback. However, I adeptly conceal my emotions, ensuring he discerns nothing. I am surprised by my newfound ability to mask my feelings, but I have grown strong.

His gaze sweeps across me as if seeing me anew. Clad simply in dark attire with my customary hooded cloak, he addresses me, “A’ Kayi, you have excelled, grown powerful, and passed your tests. I am pleased. Now you will face a final trial to determine if you are truly deserving of any further investment of my time.” I bow my head, awaiting the name of my target.

“Bring me the two lightsabers from the Jedi who infest this planet.” He smiles, pressing a button that causes the door behind me to hiss open. I hesitate momentarily, expecting to be handed a weapon of my own, but none is offered. Thus, I turn, stepping out into the cold of this alien world.

***

This planet is dusty and foul, with the wind whipping irritating brown sand into my face, igniting a flicker of anger within me. I suppress it for later. Somewhere behind me, I hear my Master departing, the engines’ whine gradually fading as he ascends into the atmosphere.

The storm rages around me, and I pull material across my face to shield myself from the dust, though it still irritates my eyes. Closing them, I extend my senses, feeling the planet breathe around me, sensing the storm as it whips the air, grinding rocks into dust, only to hurl it against me. I begin to walk again, allowing the storm to guide me, propelling me forward, assisting me in my quest.

There is life here, albeit small and feeble, yet deserving of the name. In a few short hours, I arrive at one of their villages, though it barely warrants such a title. The Aleena are a pitiful species, yet despite their squalor, they can prove dangerous. Quick and armed, I anticipate relishing the destruction of them.

The storm has calmed somewhat, but it remains strong enough to keep the inhabitants indoors. I sense sixteen life forms: ten in smaller hovels and six in a larger structure toward the end of the settlement, if one could call it that.

With a swift motion, I force the first door off its hinges and stoop to enter the cramped space. Three of the wretched creatures huddle in terror at the far side, and I pause to see if they will muster the courage to fight. They do not; their fear paralyzes them, and I crush their skulls with the Force, relishing the satisfying crunch. Their dwelling holds no worth, and I leave without a second glance.

With my eyes still closed, I savor this moment, reminiscent of the simpler challenges my Master once set before me as a child—navigating his mazes with my senses bound.

The next hovel contains four inhabitants, and I simply open the door, enjoying the panic that ensues as they scramble away from me. Fascinatingly, one wields a crude rifle, brandishing it menacingly while squeaking something at me that I disregard. I dismantle the rifle into thirty-seven separate parts and then whirl them around, reducing the occupants to a fine red pulp. All save the rifle’s owner, who shall serve as a message. I sever his spinal cord, leaving him on the floor, a voiceless witness to my work. Perhaps someone will discover him before the planet’s wild beasts do; I leave the door ajar to add an element of intrigue.

That leaves two structures with life forms: one with three and the final one housing six. I am disappointed by the hovel with three; they make no effort to resist, seemingly welcoming their demise. You would think they would value their lives, yet they exhibit such little resolve that it’s hard to believe.

Now, I approach the last building, eager to shed my closed eyes and fully relish this final encounter. The doors here are larger, suggesting it may serve as a town hall. The beings within gather around a table, and I anchor them to the ground, sensing their panic as they struggle to comprehend their newfound predicament. I stride in, and some primal instinct triggers their fear.

“Be calm, little ones,” I command, and they relax, their bodies becoming pliable. “I seek the Jedi who roam this planet.” At the mention of Jedi, I sense their alertness; they have seen them. I infuse my words with power. “***Where are the Jedi?***”

The one seated at the head of the table responds with a trembling voice, “They are with the Kindalo!” He points toward a crude map upon the wall, and I draw it toward me, striding to him.

“Where are they?” I make my tone pleasant, yet it remains unyielding. He points with a shaking finger toward what appears to be a cave entrance. Satisfactory enough—the Kindalo dwell beneath the surface. These beings have served their purpose.

I reach out with the Force, feeling their pounding hearts, thundering with terror as I pin them down. Gradually, I begin to massage their hearts with the Force, slowing each beat, initially calming them, then as their rhythms descend into an abnormal state, they realize something is amiss. I release them, and they clutch at their chests as their lives slowly ebb away. In the end, I stop their hearts one by one, watching as they gasp their final breaths. Hardly a challenge, but there was a modicum of enjoyment in it, and now I possess the location of the Jedi.
LLM_2:
The darkness of dawn breaks, casting an ominous glow over the desolate landscape. Two years of unrelenting toil have led me down this path, driven by an insatiable hunger to prove my devotion to our Master. Each step, each decision, has brought me closer, until today's pivotal trial, which will determine my fate.

In the dimly lit station known as *Gathering Dark,* where shadows dance like specters, our bond has forged a path of mutual understanding. From the grimy streets where I once scrounged for survival as just another discarded rat, to this very moment of reckoning, his guidance has illuminated my darkness. At first, terror gripped my heart as our lessons delved into pain, combat, or what seemed like an eternal twilight. But as time passed, something within stirred, recognizing an opportunity to rise above the sordid existence that had once defined me.

Our Master's ship,*Vitreperative,* a majestic beauty amidst the gloom, stands testament to its mysterious past. A product of Fondorian ingenuity, forged for those who would never claim it as theirs. Our Master has claimed it nonetheless, mastering its power to traverse the vast expanse of space, navigating treacherous waters with ease. Its sleek design and imposing engines have allowed it to outpace and outclass countless vessels. Amidst the darkness, this ship shines like beacons, illuminating a way forward.

A course set for Aleem, where toxic air fills the lungs and resilience is tested. Through lessons and trials, resistance has become my second nature, protecting me against the deadliest of compounds. Here, too, time would tell if the unforgiving environment would claim me or not. Weeks of relentless exposure would be needed to render me powerless. 

The Aleeni world, sparsely inhabited, holds secrets I've only begun to grasp. On its surface lies a sparse population, living between depths and surface alike. As I contemplate the purpose of our mission, an unsettling thought arises: the possible annihiliation of an entire civilization. Rarely would I be granted such an honor; now it's within my grasp.

Upon landing, Aleemi's unfriendly terrain unfolds, like the desert's burning sand. Storms rage, forcing me into a state of heightened awareness, letting my instincts guide my actions. There, amidst this desolation, lies the village, comprising of mere structures barely worthy of that name.

Sixteen beings live within these huts, ten huddled in one hoven, six more in another. With the winds howling, these inhabitants hunker down, unaware of what's to come. Swiftly I take action, bursting open doors, finding myself in cramped spaces filled with fear. Within the smaller dwelling, three inhabitants cower in dread, paralyzed by fear, as my hand ends their pitiable lives. No resistance, no struggle – merely a cruel fate, sealed.

Their hove is of no value to us, so I let it be. Next, four more dwell within a hoved, trembling in panic. One of those, however armed with an antique rifle brandishes it with all the ferocity of its maker. Ignoring their pleas,  I disassemble the rile and let the pieces dance in mid-air, ending their futile struggle. Only one remains, severed and voiceles, serving as testament.

Two structures remain, housing three beings and one more with six inhabitants. Frustration at first grips me – their lack of resistance is almost laughable. Why would they not fight for their right to live? But perhaps their very indifference makes them more pitied. And so, lastly we arrive, at a door much larger than the others, leading into what might be called a community hall.

Inside, seven beings huddles around the dinner table. Using the power of Force to pin down their spirits, fear grips their trembling hearts. Striding in with purpose, some unknown fear triggers in them; as one asks me for calmness, pliability takes over their souls.

"Where do the Jedai reside?" I ask, infusing power into every word. "They live with Kindalos." The being seated, now trembling, points to some crude drawing on a map, toward some cave. Good enough, for this is where our journey ends. Kindolos dwell in darkness; a place where they should not be disturbed. Time to end this, before any more of us are needed.

Within my realm, hearts begin pounding in unison, pulsating with dread. Then I calm them with Force. Heartbeats slow, awareness spreads – something's amss. Releasing them from their restraints, life force begins to egress from each of thier chests. Soon, all their heartbeasts are still, silenced by me forever. Even so – there's satisfaction in this task. Today, i possess knowledge of where the jedai are hidden. Mission accomplished. *

**Rewritten Blog Post:**

This week has felt like a tornado in slow motion.

Ever since the boss stepped out, things have quieted down in tone—but somehow, my workload has only intensified. The office vibe is more relaxed, sure, but my calendar? Anything but. Every day has blurred into the next, a whirl of tasks and half-formed thoughts spinning in my mind like laundry on high spin. By Friday, it’s hard to remember what day it even is.

Take yesterday—exhibit A. I dragged myself to work after barely catching any sleep, only to sprint back home midday to clean up (because adulting waits for no one). Then, exhaustion hit like a freight train. Cue a three-hour nap that left me blinking at the clock in horror—6 PM already?! Late for the meeting. Again.

I bolted out the door, stomach growling like a feral cat. Thank goodness they always stock snacks—those little quiches may have saved my life. The meeting wrapped up around 10 PM, and I drove home on Highway 280 under a sky full of stars. That quiet ride was the first moment all week I actually felt present.

Later, I called my friend Squirl to double-check which dress she’s bringing to V-City. We’d talked about it earlier in the week, but I never got around to replying—afternoon chaos claimed my inbox. And now? Panic sets in: she leaves Thursday morning. My meetings are Thursday night. And I spent yesterday afternoon unconscious.  

Wait… did an entire day just vanish?

Honestly, I’m starting to feel like I’m barely keeping up—like I’m running the race but forgot the route. This week didn’t just fly by. It ghosted me.

This paper proposes Evolving the Proxy Search Space (EPS) as a new RandomNAS-based approach. The goal is to find an effective proxy search space (PS) that is only a small subset of GS to dramatically improve RandomNAS’s search efficiency while at the same time keeping a good correlation for the top-performing architectures. EPS runs in three stages iteratively: Training the supernet by randomly sampling from a PS; Validating the architectures among the PS on a subset of the validation dataset in the training interval; Evolving the PS by a tournament selection evolutionary algorithm with the aging mechanism.


The paper is well written and easy to follow. The idea of efficiently sampling from the search space sounds interesting and the paper aims to bring the help of search strategies to construct the search space by itself. However, it is kind of incremental work since the EPS (Algorithm 1) is exactly similar to the aging evolution in Real et al. (2018, 2019) and this paper is using this search strategy to gradually build the search space on the fly. 

I think any of the existing search strategies 1) random search 2) Evolutionary algorithms (Real et al. (2018)) 4) progresive decision process (PNAS; Liu, et al 2018), etc can be used to find a proxy search space. While a random sample from GS is simply random search, proposed EPS is exactly the evolutionary strategy to build search space. One may even use progressive NAS algorithm as a proxy search space!  Comparing how these different proxy search spaces improve efficiency will improve the novelty and make the paper more strong.
LLM_1:
This paper proposes Evolving the Proxy Search Space (EPS) as a novel approach based on RandomNAS. The objective is to identify an effective proxy search space (PS) that constitutes a small subset of the global search space (GS), thereby significantly enhancing the search efficiency of RandomNAS while maintaining a strong correlation with top-performing architectures. EPS operates iteratively in three stages: training the supernet by randomly sampling from the PS; validating the architectures within the PS on a subset of the validation dataset during the training interval; and evolving the PS through a tournament selection evolutionary algorithm that incorporates an aging mechanism.

The paper is well-written and presents a coherent argument. The concept of efficiently sampling from the search space is intriguing, and the intention to leverage search strategies for constructing the search space autonomously is commendable. However, the work appears to be somewhat incremental, as the EPS (Algorithm 1) closely resembles the aging evolution approach described by Real et al. (2018, 2019). This paper employs this search strategy to incrementally build the search space dynamically.

It is worth noting that various existing search strategies, including 1) random search, 2) evolutionary algorithms (Real et al., 2018), and 3) progressive decision processes (PNAS; Liu et al., 2018), can be utilized to identify a proxy search space. While sampling randomly from the GS aligns with random search, the proposed EPS specifically utilizes an evolutionary strategy to construct the search space. One could even consider using the progressive NAS algorithm as a means to establish a proxy search space. A comparative analysis of how these different proxy search spaces enhance efficiency would bolster the novelty of the work and strengthen the overall contribution of the paper.

human:
The paper proposes a novel Hamiltonian to define the sampling dynamics in the state space. The main difference with the classical Newtonian Hamiltonian is a different kinetic energy. The proposed kinetic energy is $K(v) = d/2\log(v^2/d)$, where $v$ is the momentum, and $d$ is the dimensionality of the state space. The peculiar property (which is the central point of study) of this Hamiltonian is that the velocity $\dot{x} = v/(v^2/d)$ decreases with the increase of the kinetic energy. Intuitively, this energy defines very reasonable dynamics: the particle slows down in the high-density regions and accelerates with the decrease of the density. Note that the classical HMC behaves oppositely.

For the proposed dynamics, the authors carefully develop technical details. They hypothesize that, unlike HMC, this dynamics could actually be ergodic in the state space and the resampling of the momentum is superfluous then. They also develop a specific integration scheme (based on Leap-Frog) that facilitates an efficient simulation of the dynamics. Throughout the paper, the authors claim that the accept/reject step is not necessary for the correct sampling if the integration is precise enough.

For the empirical evaluation, the authors consider several synthetic distributions and compare the algorithm against similar "physical" samplers. For the synthetic distributions, the authors report ESS and MMD. There is also a brief comparison against other samplers on the energy-based models, where the authors report the average energy of the samples and provide visual examples.

There are several major weak points in the paper. The first one is the ergodicity of the procedure. Indeed, the set $H(x,v) = c$ could be disconnected (say like an elliptic curve). Although the authors demonstrate the convergence to the target empirically, this could be achieved by averaging across many parallel chains, which authors use in the experiments. Also, the authors propose an alternative procedure formulating the particle sampling method (flow interpretation in the paper) based on this dynamics. This one doesn't require the ergodicity assumption but is not tested empirically in the paper (the only empirical evaluation is for the 1-D standard normal in the Appendix).

The second weak point is the simulation without accept/reject step. Indeed, if we simulate the dynamics precisely enough we preserve the target measure and the acceptance test always yields 1. However, this also holds for the HMC algorithm. Since no developments facilitating the removement of the accept/reject step has been made, I don't see any reason to remove it. To be more precise, the authors develop a novel integration scheme, but its development is motivated by the difficulties introduced by the novel kinetic energy. Throughout the paper (line 125, lines 264-265) the authors claim that their development avoids accept/reject, but this could be also avoided for HMC in the same manner. If this could be done, I would expect a comparison with the corresponding modification of HMC.

My final concern is the empirical study. The authors demonstrate that the Hamiltonian is approximately preserved in Fig. 12 of the appendix, but they don't report the step size for these simulations. At the same time, the step size in the experiments is quite agressive (as described by the selection procedure in Section 3.1). So I wonder whether the step size is the same for both experiments? Furthermore, the authors compare the training speed of energy models using different samplers as a subroutine. However, for the comparison, the authors rely on the visual quality of the samples. The pictures look like blobs of different colors, no specific patterns are visible. I don't think that the different colors could be interpreted as a faster convergence.

Minor comments:
- The visualization of the dynamics in Fig. 1 seems a bit weird. Does this width of the "ribbon" appear as fast oscillations of the dynamics?
- line 110. I wouldn't claim that the dynamics is actually chaotic. To classify it as chaotic one needs to estimate the Lyapunov exponent or Kolmogorov-Sinai entropy. Moreover, the proposed algorithm heavily relies on the precise simulation of the dynamics (because of the lack of accepts/rejects); hence, the chaotic property could be very unfavorable from this point of view.

Despite all my concerns, I think the paper is a good fit for NeurIPS. The question of ergodicity of deterministic dynamics seems quite challenging, and I wouldn't expect it to be solved in a single paper. The second issue could be easily solved by the recent developments for non-equilibrium sampling see [1,2,3]. I think this will actually improve the performance of the proposed algorithm. Despite some flaws in the empirical study, I think the paper is important for the MCMC field. It gives a fresh look at Hamiltonian Monte Carlo and poses interesting questions for the community.

I think my final score is a bit biased towards positive because I had the same idea before getting this paper for a review. Nevertheless, I think I wouldn't be the only one excited about this paper in the NeurIPS crowd.

- [1] Rotskoff, Grant M., and Eric Vanden-Eijnden. "Dynamical computation of the density of states and Bayes factors using nonequilibrium importance sampling." Physical review letters 122, no. 15 (2019): 150602.
- [2] Neklyudov, Kirill, and Max Welling. "Orbital MCMC." arXiv preprint arXiv:2010.08047 (2020).
- [3] Thin, Achille, Yazid Janati, Sylvain Le Corff, Charles Ollion, Arnaud Doucet, Alain Durmus, Eric Moulines, and Christian Robert. "Invertible Flow Non Equilibrium sampling." arXiv preprint arXiv:2103.10943 (2021).

The paper introduces an innovative Hamiltonian framework to characterize the sampling dynamics within the state space. The key distinction from the traditional Newtonian Hamiltonian lies in the formulation of kinetic energy, defined as $K(v) = d/2\log(v^2/d)$, where $v$ represents momentum and $d$ denotes the dimensionality of the state space. A noteworthy feature, which serves as the focal point of the study, is that the velocity $\dot{x} = v/(v^2/d)$ diminishes as kinetic energy increases. This suggests a logical dynamic: particles decelerate in high-density regions and accelerate in areas of lower density, contrasting sharply with the behavior of classical Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (HMC) methods.

The authors meticulously detail the technical aspects of the proposed dynamics. They posit that, unlike HMC, their approach might exhibit ergodicity within the state space, rendering momentum resampling unnecessary. Furthermore, they present a specific integration scheme, derived from the Leap-Frog method, designed to effectively simulate these dynamics. Throughout the manuscript, the authors assert that the accept/reject step is rendered superfluous if the integration is sufficiently accurate.

For empirical evaluation, the authors investigate several synthetic distributions, comparing their algorithm against analogous "physical" samplers. In their analysis of synthetic distributions, they report Effective Sample Size (ESS) and Maximum Mean Discrepancy (MMD). Additionally, a brief comparison against other samplers is provided for energy-based models, where the authors present average sample energy and visual examples.

However, there are several significant weaknesses in the paper. The first concerns the ergodicity of the proposed method. The level set $H(x,v) = c$ may be disconnected (for instance, resembling an elliptic curve). While the authors demonstrate empirical convergence to the target distribution, this result could stem from averaging across multiple parallel chains, as utilized in their experiments. Moreover, the authors suggest an alternative particle sampling method (referred to as flow interpretation in the paper) that does not hinge on the ergodicity assumption, yet this approach is not empirically validated in the paper; the only evaluation presented pertains to a 1-D standard normal distribution in the appendix.

The second notable weakness pertains to the simulation process that omits the accept/reject step. While it is true that precise simulation of the dynamics can maintain the target measure, thus resulting in an acceptance rate of 1, this characteristic also applies to the HMC algorithm. Since no advancements have been made to justify the removal of the accept/reject step, its elimination appears unfounded. To clarify, although the authors introduce a novel integration scheme, its development seems primarily motivated by the challenges posed by the new kinetic energy formulation. Throughout the paper (see line 125, lines 264-265), the authors maintain that their method circumvents the accept/reject step, yet similar avoidance could also apply to HMC under comparable conditions. If such an approach is feasible, I would anticipate a comparison with the corresponding HMC modification.

My final concern relates to the empirical study. The authors indicate that the Hamiltonian is approximately preserved in Figure 12 of the appendix; however, they do not disclose the step size used in these simulations. Notably, the step size in their experiments appears quite aggressive, as outlined in the selection procedure detailed in Section 3.1. This raises the question of whether the same step size was employed across both experimental setups. Furthermore, while the authors compare the training efficiency of energy models utilizing different samplers, they base this comparison on the visual quality of the samples. The images presented resemble blobs of varying colors, lacking distinct patterns. I do not believe that the diversity in colors can be interpreted as an indicator of faster convergence.

Minor comments:
- The visualization of the dynamics in Figure 1 appears somewhat unusual. Does the width of the "ribbon" correspond to rapid oscillations in the dynamics?
- Line 110: I would caution against labeling the dynamics as chaotic. To classify a system as chaotic, it is necessary to estimate the Lyapunov exponent or Kolmogorov-Sinai entropy. Furthermore, the proposed algorithm relies heavily on accurate simulation of the dynamics (due to the absence of accept/reject steps); thus, the chaotic nature could be detrimental from this perspective.

Despite these concerns, I believe the paper is a suitable candidate for NeurIPS. The exploration of ergodicity in deterministic dynamics presents a formidable challenge, and it is unrealistic to expect a resolution within a single paper. The second issue may be addressed by recent advancements in non-equilibrium sampling methodologies, as referenced in [1,2,3]. I believe these developments could significantly enhance the performance of the proposed algorithm. Although there are some shortcomings in the empirical evaluation, I regard this paper as a valuable contribution to the MCMC field, offering a fresh perspective on Hamiltonian Monte Carlo and raising intriguing questions for the community.

- [1] Rotskoff, Grant M., and Eric Vanden-Eijnden. "Dynamical computation of the density of states and Bayes factors using nonequilibrium importance sampling." Physical Review Letters 122, no. 15 (2019): 150602.
- [2] Neklyudov, Kirill, and Max Welling. "Orbital MCMC." arXiv preprint arXiv:2010.08047 (2020).
- [3] Thin, Achille, Yazid Janati, Sylvain Le Corff, Charles Ollion, Arnaud Doucet, Alain Durmus, Eric Moulines, and Christian Robert. "Invertible Flow Non-Equilibrium Sampling." arXiv preprint arXiv:2103.10943 (2021).

The language has been refined to match the formal yet constructive register typical of NeurIPS-style reviews.

---

The paper proposes a novel Hamiltonian framework for characterizing sampling dynamics in continuous state spaces. The central innovation lies in the redefinition of kinetic energy as $ K(v) = \frac{d}{2} \log(v^2 / d) $, where $ v $ denotes momentum and $ d $ the dimensionality of the space. A key consequence of this formulation is that velocity $ \dot{x} = v / (v^2 / d) $ decreases with increasing kinetic energy—a counterintuitive but deliberate design choice. This leads to a dynamics in which particles slow down in high-density regions and accelerate in low-density ones, contrasting sharply with classical Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (HMC), where motion typically reflects gradient-driven acceleration.

The authors provide a detailed exposition of the theoretical underpinnings of their method, arguing that the resulting dynamics may be ergodic over the state space, thereby eliminating the need for momentum resampling—a standard component in HMC. They also introduce an integration scheme adapted from the Leap-Frog algorithm to handle the non-standard form of the kinetic energy. Notably, they assert throughout the manuscript that, under sufficiently accurate numerical integration, the accept/reject step becomes unnecessary, as the simulated trajectories preserve the target distribution by construction.

Empirically, the method is evaluated on synthetic distributions using metrics such as Effective Sample Size (ESS) and Maximum Mean Discrepancy (MMD). Additional experiments on energy-based models include comparisons of average sample energy and qualitative visualizations. These results are used to support claims about the efficiency and effectiveness of the proposed sampler.

Despite these contributions, several significant concerns remain:

**1. Ergodicity and convergence guarantees:** While the authors claim that the dynamics are ergodic, this assertion lacks rigorous justification. The level sets of the Hamiltonian $ H(x,v) = c $ may be disconnected (e.g., resembling elliptic curves), which could prevent exploration of the full support of the target distribution within a single chain. Although empirical convergence is demonstrated, it may stem from averaging across multiple parallel chains rather than intrinsic ergodicity of the dynamics. Furthermore, the paper introduces an alternative “flow interpretation” for particle sampling that does not rely on ergodicity, yet this approach is only tested on a 1-D standard normal distribution in the appendix, leaving its scalability and practical utility unverified.

**2. Omission of the accept/reject step:** The claim that the accept/reject mechanism can be safely removed hinges on perfect preservation of the Hamiltonian during simulation—an idealization that rarely holds in practice due to discretization error. While it is true that exact Hamiltonian dynamics preserve the invariant measure, so do those of standard HMC; thus, the argument for skipping Metropolis correction applies equally to both frameworks. The absence of a comparison with an analogous HMC variant that also omits the accept/reject step under similar integration accuracy weakens this aspect of the contribution. The novelty of the integration scheme appears motivated primarily by the challenges posed by the new kinetic term, rather than by a fundamental advance enabling rejection-free sampling.

**3. Empirical evaluation limitations:** Figure 12 (appendix) suggests approximate conservation of the Hamiltonian, but crucial details such as the step size used in simulations are omitted. Given the aggressive step sizes implied by the selection procedure in Section 3.1, one must question whether the same integration parameters were used consistently across methods. Moreover, the assessment of training efficiency for energy-based models relies heavily on visual inspection of generated samples. The presented images consist largely of amorphous color blobs without clear semantic content, making it difficult to draw meaningful conclusions about convergence speed or sample diversity based on visual appearance alone.

**Minor points:**
- **Figure 1**: The visualization of trajectory dynamics is somewhat unconventional. Could the width of the ribbon represent rapid oscillatory behavior? Clarification would improve interpretability.
- **Line 110**: Caution is advised in referring to the system as "chaotic." Proper characterization of chaos requires quantitative evidence, such as estimation of Lyapunov exponents or Kolmogorov-Sinai entropy. Given the method’s reliance on precise trajectory simulation—and the absence of a corrective accept/reject step—sensitivity to initial conditions could severely impact stability and reproducibility.

In summary, while the paper presents a conceptually intriguing departure from traditional HMC and raises important questions about ergodicity and deterministic sampling, several theoretical and empirical shortcomings temper its current impact. That said, I believe it constitutes a valuable contribution to the MCMC literature. The challenge of achieving global exploration through deterministic dynamics is profound, and full resolution is beyond the scope of any single work. Recent developments in non-equilibrium sampling ([1], [2], [3]) may offer promising directions for strengthening the method's robustness and performance. With appropriate revisions—particularly in clarifying assumptions, tightening theoretical arguments, and expanding empirical validation—I consider this paper a strong candidate for acceptance at NeurIPS.

---
**References:**  
[1] Rotskoff, G. M., & Vanden-Eijnden, E. (2019). Dynamical computation of the density of states and Bayes factors using nonequilibrium importance sampling. *Physical Review Letters*, 122(15), 150602.  
[2] Neklyudov, K., & Welling, M. (2020). Orbital MCMC. *arXiv preprint arXiv:2010.08047*.  
[3] Thin, A., et al. (2021). Invertible Flow Non-Equilibrium Sampling. *arXiv preprint arXiv:2103.10943*.

Yikes—welcome to unexpected wildlife roommates!  

I recently discovered I’m not the only one calling my house home. Tucked into the narrow gap between my house and the attached garage is a bat. Just hanging out. Literally.  

Before you picture a horror scene, let me clarify: he’s not *inside* the house (phew), and the garage is far from airtight, so he comes and goes as he pleases. And honestly? He’s kind of a good neighbor—insect-wise. This little guy is basically a one-mammal mosquito cleanup crew, chowing down on bugs every evening like it’s his nightly dinner special.  

But… it’s still a *bat*. As in, nocturnal, winged, echolocating creature living three feet from my back door.  

So now I’m torn. Part of me wants to name him Bruce Banner (because *bat*, get it?) and quietly support his eco-friendly lifestyle. The other part is side-eyeing the situation, wondering if this is how all vampire movies start.  

Things got awkward yesterday when I mistook his cozy crevice for a hornet’s nest. In a moment of panic, I unleashed a can of foaming hornet killer right into his hangout spot. Spoiler: It wasn’t a hornet. It was *him*.  

Now there’s a faint chemical funk lingering in the air, and I’m pretty sure he’s judging me. Maybe that smell will convince him to relocate—I wouldn’t blame him. But if he sticks around? Well, as long as he stays out of the house and keeps the bug population down, we might just have to learn to coexist.  

Urban wildlife: cute from a distance, slightly less charming when they move in uninvited.

human:
Summary:

This work proposes that many common issues with GAN methods are based on the weighting of the samples given to the generator’s objective function. They focus on a study of the original GAN objective proposed in Goodfellow et al. where the generator’s objective is the negative of the discriminator’s objective. The GAN community quickly observed that when the discriminator outperforms the generator with this objective, the saturating nature of the sigmoid function causes the gradients to vanish for the generator’s objective. For this reason, a new objective (NS-GAN) was proposed which modifies the generator’s objective to alleviate this gradient vanishing issue.  The authors argue that this modified objective is to blame for a number of common issues with GAN methods -- most notably the mode-dropping issue. The authors present theory that backs up these claims and they propose a new generator training objective which re-weights the gradients of the generator objective to have the same average magnitude as NS-GAN but have the same relative magnitudes of the original GAN objective. 

The authors demonstrate the impact of their new loss function in a series of quantitative and qualitative settings. 


Strong areas:

I am a very big fan of work that questions standard assumptions that are taken almost as fact within our community. When GANs were originally proposed, most researchers saw the NS-GAN objective as a strict improvement over the MM-GAN objective and moved on. This work does a great job to demonstrate that NS-GAN is most definitely not “superior” to MM-GAN and may possibly be a worse choice of objective function. This change may seem insignificant on the surface and the authors here clearly show that it has an impact -- one large enough to consider if it should be used at all. To aid in their claims, the authors provide clear and concise explanations backed up by easy to understand theory. Particularly interesting to me was the argument that the popular Adam optimizer does not alleviate the saturation issues found with MM-GAN even though my own intuition on the optimizer tells us that it should help with issues like this. 

Weaknesses:

The empirical results presented appear promising. The proposed approaches (MM-Unit and MM-NSAT) considerably outperform the NS-GAN objectives. My biggest issues are with the quality of the baselines. I am not an expert in the GAN field, but from inspecting the Conv-4 model with spectral normalization on CIFAR10, it appears like the best performing model achieves an FID of approx 42 and the worst model gets around 48 (figure 8, bottom right). While this difference is notable and the error-bars indicate it is statistically significant, I am concerned because these numbers seem to considerably underperform prior work. The original paper on spectral normalization for GANs reports an FID of 29.3 for standard CNNs. This model uses the NS-GAN objective (to my knowledge) so, I am confused as to why the authors did not simply replicate their setup -- especially since the standard CNN model proposed in the original spectral norm paper can be trained with reasonable compute and the authors have released code. If I am misunderstanding something about the experiments, please do let me know, but I am confused by this choice.

I also took some issues with the D-JS-CD score proposed to score the class distribution of generated samples. There have been a number of proposed metrics like this such as IS and classifier score (https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.10887). I understand that this score (unlike classifier score) does not rely on a conditional model, but if a new score is to be proposed and it is used to convince the reader that a new method performs well, then it should be applied to some baseline models. Pre-trained models from prior GAN papers could be used to obtain these scores. 

As a researcher from a different field, my main concern about the experimental results is that the results are quite far from the current state-of-the-field. State of the art results are by no means required for publication in this venue, but the baseline models presented here perform much worse than they have been shown to in prior work. Since a near 20-point increase in FID can be achieved with a few tweaks to the NS-GAN objective (SN-GAN), I am left wondering if the presented improvement from the MM-NSAT objective will vanish once those improvements are applied or if it will still hold. Since this is not shown, then I am uncertain of the significance of the observations made in this work. 

Some more nit-picky issues:

The text in the figures is too small and near impossible to read. I would present all of the results in Figure 8 in a table instead. There is no information gained by seeing loss curves. A table would save much more space and allow the readers to more easily compare this work to other works. In Figure 7, I find “best” and “worst” picks by qualitative methods to be somewhat unconvincing. You should show the highest and lowest FID or just show random samples.

My recommendation:

I am not an active member of the GAN community so I am more than willing to accept if my recommendation goes against more senior folks who work in that field. 

I found this to be an interesting work that provided a non-trivial insight, backed it up with clear and easy-to-follow theory and demonstrated their observations held on some medium-scale experiments. My biggest issues come from my reservations about the experimental results. The baseline NS-GAN with spectral normalization presented in this work greatly underperforms previously published methods that use the same objective. The difference between the presented baseline and the proposed method is smaller than the difference in performance between the presented baseline and previously published methods with the baseline objective. 

These discrepancies give me sufficient doubt where I am not certain that the insights of this work provide a sufficient improvement when combined with architectural improvements and proper parameter tuning. 

For these reasons, I am advocating against acceptance of this work but making it clear that I think this paper is borderline.

If the experimental setup was more in line with prior work and the same trend in results held, then I would be more likely to recommend acceptance of this paper.

Summary:

This work posits that several prevalent issues associated with Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) stem from the weighting of samples incorporated into the generator’s objective function. The authors focus on an examination of the original GAN objective proposed by Goodfellow et al., wherein the generator’s objective is the negation of the discriminator’s objective. The GAN research community has quickly recognized that when the discriminator outperforms the generator under this objective, the saturating nature of the sigmoid function leads to vanishing gradients for the generator’s objective. Consequently, a new objective known as NS-GAN was introduced, which modifies the generator’s objective to mitigate this gradient vanishing issue. The authors contend that this modified objective contributes to a variety of common problems with GAN methods, particularly the mode-dropping phenomenon. They present theoretical support for these assertions and propose a new generator training objective that re-weights the gradients of the generator’s objective to align with the average magnitude of NS-GAN while preserving the relative magnitudes of the original GAN objective.

The authors illustrate the impact of their new loss function through a series of quantitative and qualitative evaluations.

Strong areas:

I commend the authors for their work that challenges widely accepted assumptions in our community. When GANs were initially introduced, many researchers regarded the NS-GAN objective as a definitive improvement over the MM-GAN objective and moved on. This work effectively demonstrates that NS-GAN is not unequivocally “superior” to MM-GAN and may, in fact, represent a less favorable choice for the objective function. While this distinction may appear trivial at first glance, the authors convincingly show that it yields significant consequences warranting reconsideration of its use. Their claims are supported by clear and concise explanations underpinned by accessible theoretical insights. Of particular interest to me was the assertion that the widely utilized Adam optimizer does not alleviate the saturation issues associated with MM-GAN, despite my own intuition suggesting that it should mitigate such problems.

Weaknesses:

While the empirical results presented are promising and the proposed approaches (MM-Unit and MM-NSAT) notably outperform the NS-GAN objectives, I have substantial concerns regarding the quality of the baselines. Although I do not claim expertise in the GAN field, a review of the Conv-4 model with spectral normalization on CIFAR-10 indicates that the best-performing model achieves an FID of approximately 42, while the least effective model registers around 48 (see Figure 8, bottom right). Although this difference is statistically significant as indicated by the error bars, I am troubled by the fact that these numbers appear to underperform relative to prior work. The original paper introducing spectral normalization for GANs reports an FID of 29.3 for standard CNNs, utilizing the NS-GAN objective, to the best of my knowledge. I am perplexed as to why the authors did not replicate this setup, particularly given that the standard CNN model proposed in the original spectral normalization paper can be trained with reasonable computational resources, and the authors have made their code available. If I have misunderstood any aspects of the experiments, I would appreciate clarification regarding this choice.

I also have reservations regarding the D-JS-CD score proposed for evaluating the class distribution of generated samples. Several comparable metrics, such as Inception Score (IS) and classifier score (see https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.10887), have been previously proposed. While I understand that this score does not rely on a conditional model, if a new score is to be introduced and is employed to substantiate the performance of a new method, it should also be applied to baseline models. Pre-trained models from earlier GAN literature could be utilized to derive these scores.

As a researcher from a different discipline, my primary concern about the experimental results is that they fall significantly short of the current state of the field. While state-of-the-art performance is not a prerequisite for publication in this venue, the baseline models presented here substantially underperform compared to previously reported results. Given that a nearly 20-point enhancement in FID can be achieved with minor adjustments to the NS-GAN objective (e.g., SN-GAN), I am left questioning whether the improvements presented by the MM-NSAT objective will persist once these adjustments are made or if they will diminish. The absence of a demonstration for this aspect leaves me uncertain about the significance of the observations made in this work.

Additional minor issues include:

The text in the figures is excessively small and nearly unreadable. I recommend presenting all the results in Figure 8 in tabular form instead. The loss curves do not provide substantial information, and a table would conserve space while facilitating easier comparisons between this work and others. In Figure 7, I find the identification of “best” and “worst” picks based on qualitative methods to be somewhat unconvincing. It would be more effective to display the highest and lowest FID scores or simply show random samples.

Recommendation:

As I am not an active member of the GAN community, I am open to the possibility that my recommendation may not align with the views of more senior scholars in the field.

I found this work to be intriguing, as it offers a non-trivial insight supported by clear and accessible theoretical frameworks, demonstrating that its observations hold in medium-scale experiments. However, my primary concerns revolve around the experimental results. The baseline NS-GAN with spectral normalization presented in this work significantly underperforms compared to previously published methods utilizing the same objective. The performance gap between the proposed method and the baseline is less pronounced than the discrepancy between the baseline and prior work employing the same objective.

These inconsistencies lead me to doubt whether the insights from this work provide a meaningful improvement when combined with architectural enhancements and appropriate parameter tuning.

For these reasons, I recommend against the acceptance of this work, while emphasizing that it occupies a borderline position. Should the experimental setup align more closely with prior work and the same trends in results be observed, I would be more inclined to support the acceptance of this paper.

**Summary of the Work**  
This study argues that several common issues in Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) originate from the weighting of samples in the generator’s objective function. The authors analyze the original GAN objective (Goodfellow et al.), where the generator’s objective is the negation of the discriminator’s objective. They note that when the discriminator outperforms the generator under this setup, the sigmoid saturation leads to vanishing gradients for the generator. To address this, the non-saturating GAN (NS-GAN) objective was introduced, modifying the generator’s objective to mitigate gradient vanishing. The authors contend that this modification contributes to problems such as mode dropping. They provide theoretical support for this claim and propose a new generator training objective that re-weights gradients to align with the average magnitude of NS-GAN while preserving the relative magnitudes of the original GAN objective. The impact of the proposed loss function is demonstrated through quantitative and qualitative evaluations.

**Strengths**  
The authors are commended for challenging widely accepted assumptions in the field. Many researchers initially regarded NS-GAN as a definitive improvement over the minimax GAN (MM-GAN) objective, but this work effectively demonstrates that NS-GAN is not unequivocally superior and may in fact be a less favorable choice. While this distinction may appear subtle, the authors convincingly show that it has significant implications, warranting reconsideration of its use. Their claims are supported by clear, concise explanations and accessible theoretical insights. Of particular interest is the assertion that the widely used Adam optimizer does not alleviate the saturation issues associated with MM-GAN, contrary to intuitive expectations.

**Weaknesses**  
Although the empirical results are promising and the proposed approaches (MM-Unit and MM-NSAT) outperform NS-GAN objectives, there are substantial concerns regarding the quality of the baselines. For instance, the Conv-4 model with spectral normalization on CIFAR-10 achieves an FID between approximately 42 and 48 (Figure 8, bottom right). While this difference is statistically significant, these values underperform relative to prior work. The original spectral normalization paper reports an FID of 29.3 for standard CNNs using the NS-GAN objective. It is unclear why the authors did not replicate this setup, especially given that the standard CNN model from the original paper is computationally feasible and the authors have made their code available. Clarification on this experimental choice is needed.

Additionally, there are reservations about the proposed D-JS-CD score for evaluating the class distribution of generated samples. Several comparable metrics, such as Inception Score (IS) and classifier score, have been proposed previously. While the D-JS-CD score does not rely on a conditional model, if a new metric is introduced to substantiate a method’s performance, it should also be applied to baseline models. Pre-trained models from earlier GAN literature could be used to derive these scores.

As a researcher from a different discipline, my primary concern is that the experimental results fall significantly short of the current state of the art. While state-of-the-art performance is not a prerequisite for publication, the baseline models here substantially underperform compared to previously reported results. Given that a nearly 20-point improvement in FID can be achieved with minor adjustments to the NS-GAN objective (e.g., SN-GAN), it remains unclear whether the improvements from the MM-NSAT objective will persist once these adjustments are made. The absence of a demonstration for this aspect leaves uncertainty about the significance of the observations.

**Minor Issues**  
- The text in the figures is excessively small and nearly unreadable. Presenting the results in Figure 8 in tabular form would conserve space and facilitate easier comparisons.  
- The loss curves do not provide substantial information; a table would be more effective.  
- In Figure 7, identifying “best” and “worst” picks based on qualitative methods is unconvincing. Displaying the highest and lowest FID scores or random samples would be more effective.

**Recommendation**  
As a non-expert in the GAN community, I acknowledge that my recommendation may not align with the views of senior scholars in the field.

This work is intriguing, offering non-trivial insights supported by clear theoretical frameworks and demonstrating validity in medium-scale experiments. However, my primary concerns revolve around the experimental results. The baseline NS-GAN with spectral normalization presented here significantly underperforms compared to previously published methods using the same objective. The performance gap between the proposed method and the baseline is less pronounced than the discrepancy between the baseline and prior work.

These inconsistencies raise doubts about whether the insights from this work provide meaningful improvements when combined with architectural enhancements and appropriate parameter tuning.

For these reasons, I recommend against acceptance of this work, though it occupies a borderline position. Should the experimental setup align more closely with prior work and the same trends be observed, I would be more inclined to support acceptance.

The paper presents a class-agnostic method for tracking multiple moving objects (MOHART) that extends an existing single-object tracking method (Hierarchical Attentive Recurrent Tracking, HART). Similarly to HART, MOHART utilizes an attention mechanism and LSTM units. The extension from HART to MOHART is done in two main steps: HART is applied to multiple objects in parallel, with a presence variable attached to each, and a permutation-invariant network that learns the interactions between the objects.

The method is tested in two groups of experiments: synthetic data of moving circles, and on several real datasets. The results on the moving circles are enlightening. The paper shows that although MOHART outperforms HART in all circumstances, if the forces between the circles change randomly every number of steps, MOHART outperforms HART by a very large margin. This is because the forces between the circles are determined by their color, which is observable by the network, and MOHART, which is capable of learning their interaction, learns the pattern of changing forces. HART, being an independent-particle model, cannot learn the interactions.

The results on the real datasets demonstrate superiority over HART, and in a series of ablation experiments, the Authors are able to show that MOHART's ability to utilize interactions between objects is responsible for the improvement. For example, the improvement over HART is greater when egomotion is significant, because egomotion creates correlations between the movement of objects in the camera frame, which MOHART can utilize.

I found the paper enlightening, based on a neat idea. The experimental results are extensively analyzed and the Author's insights about their algorithm are substantiated by the experiments. 

However the difficulty I had with the paper is that the results are only compared to HART. HART was published in 2017, and the field of scene understanding and tracking had been addressed in multiple papers since then. It is one of the more competitive and application-driven fields in computer vision. Comparing MOHART only to its sister-method from over two years ago significantly limits the usefulness of paper IMHO. The expectation IMHO is not that MOHART outperform each and every method out there, but that the reader know where MOHART stands compared to other methods (e. g. tracking by detection).

I will refrain from pointing to specific papers to compare to, because I believe the Authors should choose the settings, datasets, criteria, and metrics that are the most convenient for them for comparison. The papers surveyed in Section 2, especially under "Tracking-by-Detection", have many followups. Recent papers from those that claim state of the art could good candidates for comparison.

In view of the above, I am inclined at this stage to reject the paper.

This paper explores the knowledge graph embedding (KGE) task by adapting the random walk framework introduced by Arora et al. (2016a) in the context of word embeddings, and attempts to extend it to structured relational data. While the idea of transferring insights from language modeling to KGE is conceptually interesting, I have several concerns that limit my enthusiasm for the current work.

1. **Lack of Novelty**: The primary contribution appears to be an application of Arora et al.’s methodology to a new domain, rather than the introduction of a novel algorithmic or theoretical advance. While cross-domain adaptation can be valuable, the paper does not clearly articulate what new conceptual tools, modifications, or insights are necessary or provided in the transition from text to knowledge graphs. As such, the extent of the contribution beyond straightforward transfer remains ambiguous.

2. **Heuristic Assumptions in a Supposedly Principled Framework**: The authors position their approach as a principled generative alternative to heuristic-based KGE methods. However, the use of random walks on knowledge graphs—combined with the specific choice of an exponential scoring function—introduces strong modeling assumptions that themselves resemble heuristic design choices. In particular, the justification for using the exponential function over other possible forms (e.g., polynomial, sigmoidal, or learned transformations) is underdeveloped. A more thorough discussion of this functional choice, including its implications and identifiability within the model, would strengthen the theoretical foundation.

3. **Ambiguous Evaluation Goals**: The evaluation section lacks a clear objective. The authors explicitly state they do not aim to achieve state-of-the-art performance, which is acceptable when proposing a theoretical framework. However, if the proposed model is grounded in sound theoretical principles, one would still expect it to exhibit competitive behavior on standard benchmarks—especially since the analysis claims explanatory power over existing methods. Without either strong empirical validation or novel theoretical predictions, it becomes difficult to assess the utility of the framework beyond conceptual reinterpretation.

In summary, while the motivation to develop theoretically grounded models for KGE is important, this work falls short in demonstrating a meaningful advancement over prior art. It largely repurposes an existing framework without sufficient adaptation or deeper theoretical innovation, and the claims of moving away from heuristics are undercut by the introduction of new, unvalidated assumptions. As currently presented, the paper reads more as a preliminary exploration than a substantial contribution to the field.

human:
Summary: Proposes a framework for performing adversarial attacks on an NMT system in which perturbations to a source sentence aim to preserve its meaning, on the theory that an existing reference translation will remain valid if this is done. Given source and target metrics for measuring similarity, an attack is deemed successful if the source difference is smaller than the relative decrease in target similarity to the reference. A first experiment measures correlation with human judgements of similarity between original and perturbed sentences, and concludes that chrF is better than BLEU and METEOR for this purpose. Next, standard gradient-based adversarial attacks are carried out, replacing the three tokens that result in the biggest drop in (approximate) reference probability, either 1) with no constraints, 2) constrained to character swaps of the original token, or 3) constrained be among the 10 closest embeddings to the original token. In comparisons on three language pairs from IWSLT,  the constrained attacks are found to preserve meaning and yield more successful attacks according to the current framework. The Transformer architecture was also found to deal less well with attacks under the 10-closest embedding constraint. Finally, adversarial training with the character-swap constraint confers some robustness to this attack, without degrading performance on normal text.

I think it is a good idea to formalize a method for carrying out and assessing adversarial attacks, but the framework proposed here seems too narrow, as it excludes adversarial inputs that are sensible but not a close perturbation of an existing source/reference pair, or ones that contain varying amounts of noise. It is more difficult to measure output quality for such attacks, but that doesn’t seem like a good reason for excluding them from what is intended to be a general framework. Note also that “more difficult” doesn’t mean impossible, since good attacks can produce severely degraded output that is relatively easy to detect.

I found some of the methodology questionable. Limiting source perturbations to character swaps and neighbors in embedding space, then using automatic metrics to measure semantic distance seems both unnecessary and unlikely to succeed. Unnecessary because knowing the class of perturbation already gives you a lot of information about semantic distance. Unlikely to succeed because automatic metrics are too coarse to reliably distinguish among different perturbations. This is particularly obvious in the case of using character ngram distance (chrF) to determine which character swaps preserve meaning best. The experiments that support the viability of automatic metrics in 4.2 do so by measuring correlation with human judgment when the number of perturbed tokens varies from 1 to 3. I think the good correlation is likely due to the metrics being able to detect that, eg, changing 3 tokens makes things worse than changing only one. To be convincing, the experiments would have to be repeated with number of perturbations fixed at 3, to match the setting in the remaining experiments. 

Apart from the interesting observation about the Transformer’s performance on embedding-neighbor attacks mentioned above, it is difficult to know what conclusions to draw from the experiments. In 4.3 it seems obvious a priori that perturbations intended to be relatively meaning preserving would indeed preserve meaning better than unconstrained ones. Similarly, it is not surprising that character swaps that by design produce an OOV token will cause more damage than choosing a near neighbor in embedding space. In 5.3, training with OOVs (resulting from character swaps) is of course not likely to hurt performance on test sets containing few OOVs, and, as is known from previous work, it will improve robustness to the same kind of noise. A final comment about the experiments is that word-based systems are not state of the art, and it isn’t clear how much we could expect any conclusions to carry over to sub-word models.

To conclude, although this is an interesting initiative, both the framework and the methodology need to be tightened up.

Details:

End of 2.1: this would be easier to interpret if you had previously specified the allowed range for s_src.

3.2 For kNN, being semantically related doesn’t imply that the relationship is synonymy, as would be required for meaning preservation. It also doesn’t imply that the substitution will be grammatical, which could jeopardize meaning preservation even if the words are synonyms.

CharSwap seems odd. If you’re just going to replace a work with an OOV symbol in any case, why go to the trouble of swapping characters? No matter what actual semantic shift is caused by the swap, the model will always see exactly the same representation.

4.1 “Following previous work on adversarial examples for seq2seq models (Belinkov & Bisk, 2018; Ebrahimi et al., 2018a)” - this is misleading: Ebrahimi et al only work with classification, and don’t use IWLST.

4.1 Should mention the size of the training sets in this section.

Table 1, first sentence, CharSwap example omits “faire”.

4.3, “Adding Constraints Helps Preserve…” last sentence: but here you need to reason in the opposite direction.

5.2 It would be good to also give absolute scores for table 6, so we can judge how much the systems actually benefited, and whether these gains were statistically significant.
